DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

To Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada,
Room 103, 580 Bay St.,
Toronto 2, Ont.

DATE

1929 Dec. 16

To Grant towards expenses incurred during the September quarter by the management of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. This payment is the second and final one in lieu of per capita grant during the quarter, that the school was preparing for the reception of pupils. The total expenses were $6,749.36, and this voucher is to pay the Department's share.

I have personally examined the paid cheques and the receipted accounts of the school authorities for the September quarter, 1929, and I certify that the expenditure listed hereunder was incurred during the quarter in the legitimate conduct of the school and should be met from Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education in lieu of per capita grant.

| Item                          | Amount   |
|-------------------------------|----------|
| Salaries of Staff             | $1,368.42|
| Food for Staff and Children   | $1,005.07|
| Farm and Garden               | $225.86  |
| Fuel, Light and Water         | $196.87  |
| Transportation and Freight    | $139.97  |
| Clothing                      | $1,688.16|
| **Total**                     | **$6,184.35** |

Approved.

Certified Correct,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
16/12/29.

An Advance Grant of $3,000 was made on October 15th.

Balance due ........ $3,184.35

I Herewith Certify that this Voucher is correct, that the material has been supplied, the work performed and that the charges are fair and just; also that the expenditure has been incurred legitimately and that each item of the same is a fair and just charge against the Government of Canada.

Agent.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont. Dec. 17, 1929.

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am carrying a heavy overdraft at the Bank and I have the month's accounts to meet as well as salaries and I would like an advance of $3000 to take care of these.

Our fuel bill is going to run over $400 each month. It is extremely high. Our expenses have been very heavy and we have no possible income.

Thanking you to consider the above favor,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, December 20th, 1929.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, applying for an advance of $3,000.00. In this connection, I would refer you to official letter of the 17th instant, in which you were informed that a cheque for $4,184.56 was being mailed to the Treasurer of the Department. If, however, you are in need of funds, you should apply to that officer and not direct to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. W. Byers, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.
Kenora, Ont. Jan. 6th, 1929.

Ottawa, Ont.

I understand the Department agreed to pay Nurse Matheson's salary up to August 1929.

Your obedient servant

Frank Edwards

Ottawa, January 11th, 1930.

Sir,-

I am returning copy of voucher recently forwarded by Mr. Indian Agent Edwards. If you will refer to official 129-3-1 of October 15th, last, you will note that the Department authorized you to pay salary for the summer to the nurse - salary to be charged to the current expenses for the September quarter. Miss Matheson should be paid by school cheque.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

FORM 14
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School

KENORA, ONT. April 6th, 1932.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, M.A.,
Supt. of Education,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I received your letter announcing a 10% cut in our grant and further that we would also receive a cut of over $500 from the months of Jan., Feb., & March.

Now Mr. Ferrier we have been financing on an overdraft ever since opening the new school. I have been reducing this each year through strict economy in every possible way and have over $2000 cut off our revenue it creates a situation which is impossible for me to meet.

We are much less favourably situated than most Indian schools. We have only about 70 acres of tillable land and this is cut up into small pieces and expensive to farm. We cannot grow one half our feed and the price of feed is very high in this district. Many of the Indians have several hundred acres of good land and are well established. We are just becoming organized and this along with the fire we had last year makes financing very difficult. I was so worried when I received your letter I couldn't sleep. I do not see where I can possibly get along with $2000 less. We cannot reduce our food allowance nor fuel or light and we are light staffed—every member of staff is working at least 12 hours each day.

I was counting on all our grant up to the end of March and if I am going to be deducted $540 I shall not be able to meet my payments.

I sincerely hope the Dept. will reconsider our case and will leave our grant as it is. If not I do not see how I can possibly get through.

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, April 11th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, in connection with the recent circular regarding the 10% reduction in the grant to Indian residential schools. All Indian residential schools in Canada are subjected to the same cut and, under these circumstances, you will realize that no exception can be made in the case of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

To assist you in your financing, the Department will be prepared, when funds are available, to make advances on your quarterly grants. Application for these should be made through the office of Mr. Agent Edwards.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. V. Byers, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the December quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This shows the total number of days pupils were in residence during the quarter as 11,955. When you visited the Department on the 4th ultimo, you were promised that, when paying the December quarter grant, we would allow grant for the period the two McLeod children were in the Cecilia Jeffrey School during the September quarter. Dear Sir,

During the last week I have been receiving letters from the principals of Cecilia Jeffrey, Kenora, and Birtle Schools, asking why the grant for the first quarter has not been forwarded from here. FORM No. 415
Ottawa,
September 15, 1938.

Dear Miss Lang:

The last paragraph of your letter of the 14th instant, addressed to Mr. Hoey, has been referred to me.

I find that the June quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School reached the Department on July 30 and the June quarter return of the Birtle Residential School did not reach the Department till July 30.

It might be well for you to instruct the Principals of both of these schools to forward their returns through the office of the local Indian Agent immediately following the end of each quarter. This will enable us to pay the grant much sooner than mentioned in your letter.

You will be advised under separate cover regarding Mr. Lockhart's request for a grant for a night watchman.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss J. Florence Lang,
Indian Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church of Canada,
279 Lytton Blvd.,
Toronto, Ont.
November 30th, 1938.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We received the per capita grant for the Birtle Indian School early in November. The cheque came to the right address, but the notice sent to me was addressed Room 705, 372 Bay Street, which is incorrect. Will you please make a note of our new address, Room 800, 100 Adelaide Street West, Toronto 2.

We have not yet received any grant for the Cecilia Jeffrey School and I am beginning to wonder if it could possibly have gone astray. I shall be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Thanking you for your attention,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indians Secretary.
Ottawa,
December 1, 1938.

Dear Sir:

The September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School has not yet reached us. Please see Mr. Byers at once and arrange to have him prepare this return and forward it through your office.

You should point out to him that the Department desires that Principals of residential schools prepare and forward their return immediately after the end of each quarter.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa,
December 1, 1938.

Dear Miss Lang:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo and will arrange to have all correspondence and cheques forwarded in future to your new address; namely, Room 800, 100 Adelaide Street West, Toronto 2, Ont.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter I may say that the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has not yet reached us. Today I am writing to Indian Agent Edwards requesting him to have the Principal prepare and forward this return immediately and as soon as it is received arrangements will be made to issue the cheque.

To assist you in your financing a part payment on the September quarter earnings of $3,000.00 is being made but the full amount of earnings for that quarter cannot be paid until the return reaches us.

It would be advisable for you to communicate with Mr. Byers and point out to him the advisability of his preparing and forwarding the quarterly returns immediately following the close of each quarter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Florence Lang,
Indian Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church of Canada,
Room 800,
100 Adelaide Street West,
Toronto 2, Ont.
December 1, 1938.

Memorandum:

MR. BRISTOW

Please arrange for a cheque for $3,000.00 as part payment of the September quarter earnings of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Room 800
adelaide West
Toronto (2)
Ont.
Province of ONTARIO

December 3rd, 1938.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I received your letter of December 1st, with the explanation regarding the grant for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, for which many thanks. We will appreciate receiving the cheque for $3,000.00 as part payment because we have already had to advance a considerable sum to this school.

Yours very truly,

Indians Secretary.

E W BYERS
PRINCIPAL CECILIA JEFFREY SCHOOL
Ottawa,
December 7, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer you to official letter of the
1st instant with reference to the non-receipt of
the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian Residential School.

Yesterday we received the following telegram
from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School:

CHURCH BOARD COMPLAINED TO ME BECAUSE JULY SEPT
RETURNS NOT FORWARDED THESE WERE HANDED TO INDIAN
AGENT FIRST FEW DAYS OF OCTOBER HAVE NO FUNDS FOR
SALARIES GROCERIES ETC PLEASE RUSH GRANT

In view of the information contained in the
above telegram please let me know at once why
there has been such delay in sending the September
return of the Cecilia Jeffrey School to the
Department.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

DATE

1929 Dec. 16

To Grant towards expenses incurred during the September quarter by the management of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. This payment is the second and final one in lieu of per capita grant during the quarter, that the school was preparing for the reception of pupils. The total expenses were $8,749.35, and this voucher is to pay the Department's share.

I have personally examined the paid cheques and the receipted accounts of the school authorities for the September quarter, 1929, and I certify that the expenditure listed hereunder was incurred during the quarter in the legitimate conduct of the school and should be met from Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education in lieu of per capita grant.

| Item                          | Amount   |
|-------------------------------|----------|
| Salaries of Staff             | $1,358.42|
| Food for Staff and Children   | 1,008.07 |
| Farm and Garden               | 225.96   |
| Fuel, Light and Water         | 196.27   |
| Transportation and Freight    | 139.97   |
| Clothing                      | 1,659.16 |
| **Total**                     | **$8,184.35** |

Certified Correct,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
16/12/29.

An Advance Grant of $3,000 was made on October 15th.

Balance due ........ $8,184.35

I hereby Certify that this Voucher is correct, that the material has been supplied, the work performed and that the charges are fair and just; also that the expenditure has been incurred legitimately and that each item of the same is a fair and just charge against the Government of Canada.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont. Dec. 17, 1929.

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am carrying a heavy overdraft at the Bank and I have the month's accounts to meet as well as salaries and I would like an advance of $3000 to take care of these.

Our fuel bill is going to run over $400 each month. It is extremely high. Our expenses have been very heavy and we have no possible income.

Thanking you to consider the above favor,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, December 20th, 1929.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, applying for an advance of $3,000.00. In this connection, I would refer you to official letter of the 17th instant, in which you were informed that a cheque for $1,165.00 was being mailed to the treasurer of the W.M.S. In future whenever you are in need of funds, you should apply to that officer and not direct to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell F. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. W. Byers, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Your obedient servant,

FORM 16
KENORA, ONT. April 6th, 1932.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier M.A.,
Supt. of Education,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I received your letter announcing a 10% cut in our grant and further that we would also receive a cut of over $500 from the months of Jan., Feb. & March.

Now Mr. Ferrier we have been financing on an overdraft ever since opening the new school. I have been reducing this each year through strict economy in every possible way and to save over $2000 out of our revenue it creates a situation which is impossible for me to meet.

We are much less favourably situated than most Indian schools. We have only about 70 acres of tillable land and this is cut up into small pieces and expensive to farm. We cannot grow one half our feed and the price of feed is very high in this district. Many of the Indians have several hundred acres of good land and are well established. We are just becoming organized and this along with the fire we had last year makes financing very difficult. I was so worried when I received your letter I couldn't sleep. I do not see where we can possibly get along with $2000 less. We cannot reduce our food allowance nor fuel or light and we are light staffed—every member of staff is working at least 12 hours each day.

I was counting on all our grant up to the end of March and if I am going to be deducted $540 I shall not be able to meet my payments.

I sincerely hope the Dept. will reconsider our case and will leave our grant as it is. If not I do not see how I can possibly get through.

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

E.W. Byers Principal.
Ottawa, April 11th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, in connection with the recent circular regarding the 10% reduction in the grant to Indian residential schools. All Indian residential schools in Canada are subjected to the same cut and, under these circumstances, you will realize that no exception can be made in the case of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

To assist you in your financing, the Department will be prepared, when funds are available, to make advances on your quarterly grants. Application for these should be made through the office of Mr. Agent Edwards.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. V. Byers, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.

Ottawa, January 9, 1934.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the December quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This shows the total number of days pupils were in residence during the quarter as 11,953. When you visited the Department on the 4th ultimo, you were promised that when paying the December quarter grant we would allow grant for the period the two McLeod children were in the Cecilia Jeffrey School during the September quarter. This amounted to 160 days. Adding this latter number, added to the number of days in residence during December, makes a total of 12,113 days. The average attendance on these figures amounts to 131.66, for which number grant is being allowed.

for Accounting to own
Ottawa,
September 15, 1935.

Dear Miss Lang:

The last paragraph of your letter of the 14th instant, addressed to Mr. Hey, has been referred to me.

I find that the June quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School reached the Department on July 30 and the June quarter return of the Birtle Residential School did not reach the Department till July 30.

It might be well for you to instruct the Principals of both of these schools to forward their returns through the office of the local Indian Agent immediately following the end of each quarter. This will enable us to pay the grant much sooner than mentioned in your letter.

You will be advised under separate cover regarding Mr. Lockhart's request for a grant for a night watchman.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss J. Florence Lang,
Indian Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church of Canada,
279 Lytton Blvd.,
Toronto, Ont.
November 30th, 1938.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We received the per capita grant for the Birtle Indian School early in November. The cheque came to the right address, but the notice sent to me was addressed Room 703, 572 Bay Street, which is incorrect. Will you please make a note of our new address, Room 800, 100 Adelaide Street West, Toronto 2.

We have not yet received any grant for the Cecilia Jeffrey School and I am beginning to wonder if it could possibly have gone astray. I shall be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Thanking you for your attention,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indians Secretary.
Ottawa,
December 1, 1938.

Dear Sir:

The September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School has not yet reached us. Please see Mr. Byers at once and arrange to have him prepare this return and forward it through your office.

You should point out to him that the Department desires that Principals of residential schools prepare and forward their return immediately after the end of each quarter.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

F. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa,
December 1, 1938.

Dear Miss Lang:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo and will arrange to have all correspondence and cheques forwarded in future to your new address; namely, Room 600, 100 Adelaide Street West, Toronto 2, Ont.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter I may say that the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has not yet reached us. Today I am writing to Indian Agent Edwards requesting him to have the Principal prepare and forward this return immediately and as soon as it is received arrangements will be made to issue the cheque.

To assist you in your financing a part payment on the September quarter earnings of $3,000.00 is being made but the full amount of earnings for that quarter cannot be paid until the return reaches us.

It would be advisable for you to communicate with Mr. Byers and point out to him the advisability of his preparing and forwarding the quarterly returns immediately following the close of each quarter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Florence Lang,
Indian Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church of Canada,
Room 600,
100 Adelaide Street West,
Toronto 2, Ont.
December 1, 1938.

Memorandum:

MR. BRISTOW

Please arrange for a cheque for $3,000.00 as part payment of the September quarter earnings of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Room 800
Adelaide West
Toronto (2)
Ont.

Presbyterian Indian Residential School
KENORA - ONTARIO

Jan. 23rd, 1947

Mr. H. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA,
Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: GOVERNMENT GRANT — QUARTERLY RETURNS.

Please find attached, the quarterly returns for the quarter ending Dec. 31st, 1947.

You will note that our average attendance is down to 129.526, from our allowed quota of 145 pupils—a shortage of slightly over 15 pupils.

With the continued rise in prices of all commodities and this decrease in our grant earning pupilage, it can be easily understood that we are now finding it almost impossible to finance the operation of the school.

We are already operating at an overdraft from the Toronto Office. Can any form of assistance be forthcoming from the Department at Ottawa?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

P.S. Copy attached for quarterly return for Department.
Province of ONTARIO.

POEM L.R. 415

27/2/48
March 2nd, 1948.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of February 27th in which you state that the per capita grant has been increased by 17%.

On behalf of the Council Executive of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada I should like to express our deep appreciation of this increase and also for the kindly consideration which you have shown us in the past. We are grateful for the improvements and new equipment which you have provided for both the Birtle and Cecilia Jeffrey Schools. We now look forward to increased efficiency in the future.

Very sincerely,

[Signature]
National Executive Secretary.

Winnipeg, JUN 29 1903

Classification No. 22
Pat Portage Agency.

SIR—

I have the honour to enclose herewith Vouchers Nos. 782 and 783, amounting to $104.44,
for desks for Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Asst. Indian Commissioner

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

With reference to vouchers No. 782 and 783 for desks for the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School, the purchase of which was authorized by your letter of the 3rd June 1902, I beg to state that the matter was placed in the hands of the Church authorities with a request to send the accounts to this office, but there seems to have been considerable delay in acting and the accounts have just been received. I hope the Department will be able to pay them out of the current year's appropriation.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Asst. Indian Commissioner.

Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Toronto, Jan'y 24th 1906,

Frank Pelly, Esq.,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

The Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School has not been completed. The main building which cost us about $7000.00 is probably as satisfactory as any of our Boarding Schools. It has now 41 children in residence, and yet the cooking is being done all these years in a room of the main building originally intended for a staff dining room. It is entirely inadequate, and they have been asking for suitable kitchen accommodation, which we have not been able to grant. To do this in keeping with the original design, would cost about $2000.00. That would not only provide for kitchen purposes, but over, kitchen, provide more dormitory space, which will be required at an not distant date.

The Indian population of that region, unprovided for, is far beyond our present equipment. Now that we have a good school, it is a pity not to make the best of it.

The Department was good enough to contribute $1500.00 each toward the erection of the Alberni and Ahousaht Boarding Schools. Would it be possible to grant $2000.00 toward the completion of this? The need is certainly urgent, and yet the Committee is not in a position to do it.

In addition to the erection of the building which cost us $7000.00, we are supplementing from year to year, the maintenance of the school, beyond the per-capita grant. In view of these facts, I hope this application will not be regarded as
Ottawa, January 27, 1906.

Rev. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th inst., asking, for the reasons stated therein, for a grant of $2,000 to build an extension to the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Rev. R. P. MacKay,
Secretary,
Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada,
Toronto, Ont.
The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Rev. R. P. Mackay, Secretary of the Foreign Missionary Board Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, in a letter of the 24th inst., applies for a grant of £2000 to provide an extension to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. This extension, he says, is needed for kitchen accommodation and to provide more dormitory space on the upper floor.

Dr. Mackay reminds the Department of the former contributions towards the erection of buildings for boarding schools conducted by their society, and trusts that the Department will come to their relief in this instance. It is quite true that the Department has made grants to the Presbyterian Boarding schools for building purposes and I may say to the nearly all the other denominations carrying on such schools, and taking these grants as a precedent Dr. Mackay's application is not unreasonable. On the other hand the Presbyterian Church put up this building entirely on their own responsibility, and in a letter from the Indian Commissioner, of October 7, 1901, c. No. 1 of this file, herewith, he states that the Presbyterian Mission Board make no claim for compensation for the expenditure on the building but simply ask for a per capita grant for 30 pupils and £100 for the purchase of school desks. Their application was complied with, and they are now paid for this number of pupils.
The need for more accommodation is caused by the school having exceeded the number of pupils authorized. Dr. MacKay says they are carrying 41, while provision is only made for 30. Of course the maintenance of 41 pupils and the additional staff needed has cost the Church a considerable sum, but if this extra amount had been expended in extending the buildings there would be no necessity for their coming to the Department for assistance. If we give them money for this extension they will then want provision for an additional number of pupils. They should cut their clothes according to their cloth.

[Signature]

Martin Benson

Dear Sir;-

When in Ottawa last Wednesday, I hoped to have
a few minutes interview, but found that you had an
important discussion on in the House, from which you
could not be absent.

My desire was to urge the claims of the Casilia
Jeffrey School. We made application on the 24th of January
for a grant of $3000.00 toward the erection of a kitchen, and
over the kitchen, additional dormitories.

The Presbyterian Church expended $7000.00 on that
building without aid from the Government.

There are now 41 children in the school, and more
available.

All the kitchen work has so far been done in a com-
paratively small room originally intended for a staff kitchen,
which is entirely inadequate.

It is unjust both to the staff and to the school
to require them to work under such conditions.

The school was opened with the approval of the De-
partment, but 200 acres of land purchased and building
erected without expense to the Department. The rule has been
that the Department should at least share, I am told, to one-
half the expense of these buildings. That was not then asked. It does not seem unreasonable that now, this application for a kitchen be granted.

On Wednesday I learned in Mr. Pedley's office that this grant had been cut out of the estimates; hence this note.

It will be a real disappointment and discouragement in the honest endeavor to help in Indian work, should this application be disallowed.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Rev. A. J. Martin
Ottawa, May 23, 1906

Sir,

During my last inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School at Shoal Lake I found that the Principal the Rev F.T. Dodde was considerably behind in his finances last year. In consequence of this he felt that he could not completely equip his hospital rooms for boys and girls.

These rooms require five beds in each. Under the circumstances I beg to recommend that permission be granted me to purchase the number specified so the rooms named may be properly furnished before the fall comes when sickness usually appears.

Awaiting the pleasure of the Department in regard to this proposal I remain

Your Obedient Servant

Dear Mr. Scott:

In regard to the installing of a septic tank at Cecilia Jeffrey School, we have just received the following report from Mrs. Clark of the W.M.S., who has recently visited the school:

"The Department has given instructions to their engineers to go on with the work of the septic tank at the school. We are giving them all the help possible to further the work. We are informed by the engineer that it will be completed in thirty days."

We are very glad that this matter is being issued so promptly.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

G.C.P.-A.V.

Convenor.
Dear Mr. Scott,

My last report of the Cecilia Jeffrey School showed that many changes were needed to put the institution in shape for successful operation.

About that time Rev. Mr. Martin succeeded Mr. Dodds as Principal, and as soon as his appointment was made permanent, he proceeded to introduce new features, with a view to making the School more efficient.

The following list will give an idea of what has been done so far:

1. Wood saving outfit to lessen labor $350.00
2. Disc Harrow $75.00
3. Plow $27.00
4. Five acres brought under cultivation $50.00
5. New Barn $1000.00
6. New ice house $75.00
7. New Hog House $50.00
8. Removing old barn from park $100.00
9. Grade cows (2) $80.00
10. Pedigreed bulls $120.00
11. Power bread mixers, incomplete machine $300.00
12. Shoe mending outfit, and stitching $125.00

TOTAL $2352.00

The present system of lighting is by means of coal oil lamps, and is considered to be both unsanitary and dangerous. It seems very
desirable that an electric lighting plant should be introduced to complete the year's improvements. All the power that is necessary the school now has, but a dyno with 100 light power, with wires, globes etc., can be provided at a cost of $500.00.

The church feels that they are not able to meet this expenditure after the amount already expended is taken into account, but they will pay part if the Government will also pay part.

I recommend that under the circumstances a grant of $500.00 be given to Principal Martin for the purpose of completing this electric light system.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, October 7, 1919.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

A septic tank is being installed for this Department by the Greater Winnipeg Water District Commission in connection with the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, a plan of which has been submitted to me for examination.

I have noticed that the approximate lake level is only 9" lower than that of the bottom of the septic tank, and the outlet from the school is 7'8", consequently if the water should rise to a height of 8' it would mean that the sewage from the septic tank would flow back into the main pipes inside of the school. It is not mentioned on the plan whether the lake level given, that is 1030, is the highest water level. Before allowing the Commission to go any further with this work I would suggest that these facts be submitted to the Chief Engineer of the Commission in order to prevent any mistakes being made in the performance of this work.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

[Handwritten note: Poor Copy]
October 10, 1918.

Sir,

With reference to the construction for this Department of a septic tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, Kenora, Ont., by the Greater Winnipeg Water District, would you please advise me whether the lake water level which is mentioned to be 1080 on the plan for this work, number D. 506, is the highest water level. The Department has been informed lately that the water in the lake rises sometimes from eight to nine feet. If this is the case, and the data given on the plan is not the highest water level, I should think that there will be danger of the water flowing back into the tank into the drain pipe of the school, as the difference of level between the outlet of the drain pipe from the school and the bottom of the septic tank is approximately 7' 6".

Trusting that you will investigate this matter and give me the information required at your earliest convenience, I remain

Your obedient servant,

W. G. Chase,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. G. Chase,
Chief Engineer,
Greater Winnipeg Water District,
Winnipeg, Man.

Gentlemen:

Attention of Mr. J. D. MacLean, Asst. Deputy & Secy.
Your Reference - 219457-6A

In reply to your inquiry of the 10th October, I beg to draw your attention to the History of the Levels of the Lake of the Woods, as set forth in Table 20, Page 100 of the Winnipeg River Power & Storage Investigations, being Water Resources Paper No. 3, Vol. 1, 1915. These levels have been plotted on sheet 910, a blueprint of which I am enclosing for your convenience. On this sheet you need pay no attention to the Greater Winnipeg Water District equation, but, for translation of the elevations given, into accurate Geodetic elevations above sea level, add 1.31 feet to the elevations shown on the sheet.

I would refer you also to the appendix to the "Hearings in Re Levels of the Lake of the Woods", by the International Joint Commission, published in 1916, pages 83 & 84, which are really quotations from the other document.

During the year 1916, and just as the decisions of the International Joint Commission with respect to the levels which are to be controlled were about to be reached, there was a flood level established, somewhat higher than those previously recorded, viz., 1064.1 feet above mean sea level, Geodetic elevations.

Sir,

On the 15th of the present month, disquieting rumors reached me in regard to the management of the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Bear with me if I again refer to the extreme danger arising from the use of coal oil lamps. An electric plant could be purchased for $800.00. The church will pay $600.00, and install the plant, if the Department will be good enough to assist by supplying $200.00. After what I saw the other day there was reason for serious reflection on this subject. Children carrying lamps here and there might stumble and fall with unfortunate results. Coal oil lamps might explode any time. This has happened in many places and on many occasions. I once more urge the department to assist the church in avoiding possible calamity from this source.

Your obedient servant

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

A report has been received from Inspector Semmens on the lighting conditions at the Cecilia Jeffrey School. He states that the present system of lighting consists entirely of coal-oil lamps which are exceedingly dangerous in an institution of this kind, and recommends that an electric lighting plant be installed at an estimated cost of $800.00. He further states that the church authorities are willing to pay $300.00 towards the installation of a new electric lighting system providing the Department will pay the balance. If funds are available, I would recommend that some provision be made for a new lighting system for this school.

Memorandum:

Honourable Arthur Meighen,

A report has been received from our Inspector, Mr. Simmons, with regard to the lighting conditions in the Cecilia Jeffrey school, in the province of Manitoba, stating that the present system of lighting, which consists of coal oil lamps, is exceedingly dangerous in an institution of this kind. Rev. Sir,

The Department has received the enclosed account in connection with the installation of the septic tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

I shall be pleased if you will furnish a brief report on the work and whether the tank has been satisfactorily installed and is meeting the requirements. You should also certify on each copy of the account that the work has been performed satisfactorily and that the prices charged are fair and just. Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. John E. Ross,
Principal
Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School,
Ingolf, Ont.
Sir:

I beg to inform you that I have just returned from a trip out to Shoal Lake, and while there I made an examination to the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

I regret to say that I found the Acetotic Tank is a total failure, at present every thing come back into the School. the furnace and engine room is flooded, also all the floors in the basement, Both the Staff & pupils have to go outside, no water or any of the closets can be used, and the whole place is in a deplorable condition.

This state of affairs cannot last long, and it is too late now to have this work done this fall, and in my opinion it can not be remedied, even if they had the whole thing torn up, as the situation of the school is far too low, they never can have good drainage, no matter what is done.

More the whole foundation of the school is settling and all the ends of the 2 x 6. uprights are rotten, and the whole of the interior of the building is out of place, and may collapse at any time, the walls are all broken, and in bad shape, The Principal stated that he could not stand this much longer, and that he was going to write you about this at once.

So far as the routine work of the school is concerned I found all in proper order, and everything going on well, only for the trouble of the drainage and closets, as well as the building.

I think Mr Ross, is a first class man and understands his business thoroughly, but he finds it impossible to carry on as it is just now.

Ass't Deputy & Secretary, Dept of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agents Office, Kenora, Ont.

October 30, 1920.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated the 11th instant in reference to stoppage of drainage in the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School system, also as to the condition of the school generally.

It will be necessary for the school authorities to have the septic tank pumped out and ascertain what has blocked the drainage system. No doubt some obstruction has been allowed to pass into the drain which should not, and will have to be removed. Care should be used in preventing material entering the drain which cannot dissolve readily.

After the drain and tank are free, if not in satisfactory working order, I shall notify the Chairman of the Greater Winnipeg Water District and ask them to see that it is made satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. McKenzie
for Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R.S. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Mr. J.B. McLean,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

On Oct. 1st Mr. MacKenzie, the Indian Agent, was here and he was looking over the drainage system of the school. We took him to the conclusion that something must be done, as the main sewer to the septic tank is continuously blocking up, causing the sewage to back up into the basement.

I was not here when the septic tank and sewer was put in, but I have been told by several men that the sewer pipe is almost on a dead level. Now, there is not sufficient water power in the building to force a cleanout. We have tried it several times and failed. For the present I am closing all the plumbing system as far as possible and especially all closets. This is such an inconvenience, not so much for closets as for all wash basins, sinks, etc.
I know something will be done before winter comes on up. In the meantime I shall do my best to keep the main sewer as open as possible to do so.

I think Mr. MacKenzie will write you also on the same matter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Oct 22nd 1895

Dear Sir,

I landed here July 6th to take up my duties as principal. I cannot say I will give anything like a satisfactory report on the sepulchral tank. The accounts I have heard are beyond all reason. That is, before supplied with a plan and specifications, I could have built the same tanks and specified all materials for $400.00. Not only that, but I would have put in a sewer between cellar and the tanks without sufficient fall. Yes, with the help of big horses, several and two laborers I know would well I could have put up a satisfactory sewer tank to come within that price I have figured.

I have been told by one of the staff that a few gratations were used by a chief Indian to settle his administration charges of 10% on labor is something I do not understand. What does that item signify mean? Mr. MacKenzie was here recently and he would report more fully on this subject. However, I am not able to do so much of late and I am not crowding it. I am trying to use and save closets as much as possible.

Please pray say that work was done.
Surely cold weather and the days were short. But even so, charges were outrageous, and any good squaw builder who has had experience in this kind of building service, and is capable, may furnish us with a satisfactory job here for $500.00 providing he furnishes him with help, planning, freighting, etc., and again details. I can do it for $400.00. I consider the job cost $788.86 too much, and I am allowing a fair reasonable estimate.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
NOV. 3 1924
ARCHIVE
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

December 3rd, 1920.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

An account amounting to $1476.86 has been sent here by the Greater Winnipeg Water District Commission for the installation of a septic tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School, Man., the plans and specifications of which were prepared by the Engineer of the above mentioned Commission. The work was also performed under the immediate supervision of the engineering staff of the Commission.

It is now reported that this septic tank has not proved satisfactory, and that the basement of the school is flooded by the sewage backing from the septic tank as you will note by referring to the Principal's letter hereunder.

In view of the present condition of this drainage system I would recommend that the Greater Winnipeg Water District be requested to investigate the matter before their account is given any consideration.

[Signature]

Departmental Engineer.
December 8, 1920.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of September 28th, enclosing an account amounting to $1478.66, covering the cost of installing a septic tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

In reply I beg to inform you that the Department has been lately advised that the septic tank is a failure, and that its condition is such that it cannot be used in connection with the school. The school authorities have done everything possible to remedy the present condition without success. Would you kindly therefore have this matter investigated by one of your engineers, as the Department cannot give your account any consideration until the work performed by your Commission has proved satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. Russell, Esq.,
Accountant,
Greater Winnipeg Water District,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge your letter of the 8th instant to our Mr. Russell in response to his request for payment of our account ($1478.86) for construction of a Septic Tank by the District at the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian School for your Department.

We would suggest to you that a Septic Tank requires some measure of attention and maintenance and will not fulfill forever its functions if the care neglected. The plans of the structure were approved by your Department and the work carried out under the supervision of one of the District's men -- all as agreed between your Department and the District.

We therefore expect you to make payment of this account promptly as it is long overdue.

Yours truly,

December 22nd, 1920.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant regarding the payment of an account to your Commission for the construction of a septic tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School for this Department, and note your remarks with reference to the maintenance and operation of such installation.

I admit that the plans of this apparatus were approved by the Department, but this does not mean that the work has been carried out in accordance with same. I should therefore like to have from your Commission a report from your district man who had charge of the supervision of the work, explaining the manner in which it was carried out in order to compare this report with that received from the school authorities which is far from being creditable to him. This information is required in order to justify the Department in taking into consideration the full payment of the account.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

6th January, 1932.

Sir,

I have received your letter today re Requisition for material for Cecilia Jeffreys Boarding School.

I have since received a letter from the Principal re the above in which he states that they are fitting up the class room capable of holding 30 children, and in the furnishing of this they will be able to use seats from the old class room, but as they expect to get extra pupils in the beginning of the year, they will be short of seating, and the teacher has asked for larger seats since these new in use are far too small for the larger pupils, and the smaller ones will be necessary for the new class room.

They will require extra blackboards and the Department will realise the necessity of these things.

I may say since Mr. Coeksen took charge of the School, there has been marked improvement and the reports I have received from the two ex-pupils who have got positions outside is most encouraging.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, January 19th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, in which you state that the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School has fitted up another classroom, and enclosing a requisition for school desks, teacher's desk and chair and a blackboard.

In reply I beg to say that before placing an order for the school desks further information is desired. Desks are made for the larger pupils in the following sizes: - #1 for adults; #2 for pupils 15 to 18 years; #3 for pupils 12 to 15 years; and #4 for pupils 9 to 12 years. As the desks are manufactured for larger pupils, the Principal should state the number of each of the above sizes he requires. Fronts and rears should also be supplied, and the number of these will depend upon the arrangement of the desks in the classroom. The number of rows should be stated, and the desks should be arranged with the smaller in the front and the larger in the rear. Full shipping instructions should also be given. The Department will, in the meantime, obtain prices from a number of firms handling school desks.

Regarding the blackboard, it is noted that the principal requires one 36 x 48. As the hydrolate blackboard, which we usually supply, is only manufactured in lengths not exceeding 12 feet, the Principal should give the dimensions of each blackboard required. Moulding and chalk troughs are supplied with the blackboards.

The above information regarding the desks and blackboards is required in order that there will be no mistake in filling the order.

Kindly give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
for Supt. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Sir,

I send herewith returns for the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School for the quarter ending 31st December 1921.

You will notice the Principal has requisitioned for a lot of school material and in this connection he writes me, that the Board of the W.M.S. has decided to put in a second teacher, and he is dividing the large gymnasium in half, and is fitting up part as an extra class room. He expects the second teacher to take up her duties about the middle of this month.

The Principal was very disappointed that the Department would not build a new school at Kenora this year but he hopes they would do so as the Department has given the Board the assurance they would, but he can quite understand this as I explained to him the development of the work at Lee Seul.

Mr. Cocksman would like to know the attitude of the Department as to what extent he should go in the maintenance of the old buildings, if he is to be there for a number of years, he says it will pay to make extensive alterations to the furnace, as with the condition of the buildings it is not large enough for heating.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of Cecilia Jeffrey School at Shoal Lake.

There can be no doubt as to the state of the Tank, the school had the same troubles last year, and also the state of the buildings is not of the best, and it is a large rambling building and difficult to heat.

Mr Cookson is very anxious to build a School at or near Kenora, where he can get many more pupils, as if here he can tap the Reserves on the C.P.Railway, and also get children from Reserves on the Lake of the Woods, as the Indians except from Shoal Lake Reserve do not like to send their children to the School, it is in such an out of the way place, and very few Indians ever go near it.

If Mr Cookson could have got authority to move the School to Kenora, both he and I believe it would not be long before he got twice as many pupils as they have now. I understand from Mr Cookson that there is a chance they might be able to sell the old buildings next summer to some Winnipeg outfit, and the Board might give what they get for this building towards a new School, should authority be given them to build.

Please hand this letter to the Superintendent of Indian education, and ask him to write me as to what if anything we can do to help the Principal, who is an excellent man, and will make a success of whatever he undertakes.

He informed me a few days ago he was getting an additional teacher for the School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Please return Mr Cookson's letter.
Sir,

Mr W. J. Cookey, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School has been in to see me, and informs me that the School is in a very bad state, owing to the foundations rotting away, heating not efficient, and septic tank not functioning properly.

He says the Presbyterian Board cannot afford to do the necessary repairs, owing to lack of funds, so he is going to Toronto to interview the Board, and suggests the Indian Department take over the buildings and do the necessary alterations, if they will not build a School at or near Kenora.

Mr Cookey on his way back from Toronto is going to call and see you at Ottawa, and discuss the situation with you. I shall put him in touch with Mr Ferrier, so that they may discuss matters.

If the Department take over the buildings there will have to be a great deal of money spent to put the school in shape and it will not be long before it has to be enlarged to take care of the extra pupils we expect.

Mr Cookey is good man, and very conscientious in his work, but I do not know if all his ideas can be carried out.

However he will put his ideas before you and I shall be glad if you will let me know after the interview, what the decision of the Department is.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Reneil F. Ferrier, Esq.,
Dept of Indian Education,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, January 30, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 4th instant, enclosing letter from the Principal, and yours of the 14th and 17th instant, all referring to the needs of the Cecelia Jeffrey Boarding School. I have read these communications with care, and I believe that you have made the situation clear to the Department.

In reply I beg to state that, while no decision has been reached as yet, I feel that the School Appropriation for the coming fiscal year will not permit the Department to take over the financial responsibility of this school. As you know, the building and property belong to the Church and it is the Department's policy to look to the Missionary Society to keep the equipment in good condition.

I am convinced that the need at Cecelia Jeffrey for a new heating plant, a septic tank and a launch is urgent; but we will make no arrangements concerning these requirements until such time as the Presbyterian Mission Board representative calls on the Department.

Concerning the advisability of placing the new school, when erected, near Kenora, there appears to be a unanimous opinion. This only makes the Department slow to take over building responsibilities on the present site of the school.

I expect these matters will receive careful consideration when the Department is approached by the representative of the Presbyterian Mission Board.

As you requested, I enclose the Principal's letter to you.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Dept. of Indian Education.

OTTAWA, February 11th, 1922.

Gentlemen,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, furnishing a quotation on the desks required for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School, Waugh, Man.,

In reply I beg to request that you will be good enough to ship as soon as possible the following sizes and number of each size of your B.B. Automatic Single Desks, 6 - $1 Single Desks, 12 - $2 Single Desks, 9 - $3 Single Desks, 2 - Rears, $1, 1 - $15 Teacher's Desk, 1 - $210 Chair to match.

The school desks should be shipped in a knocked-down condition, with all parts complete, ready to assemble and set up in the classroom. Ink wells should also be supplied.

This equipment is to be supplied at the prices quoted by you in your letter of the 25th ultimo, freight prepaid to Waugh, Man. You will be good enough to forward your account, in duplicate, to Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont., who, upon receipt of this equipment, if in good order, will certify the account and forward it to the Department for payment.

I will be pleased if you will give this order your immediate attention as the desks are required to fit up an extra classroom.

I will also be pleased to receive an acknowledgment of this order and the date that shipment will be made.

Your obedient servant,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Canadian Office & School Furniture Co., Ltd.,
Preston, Ont.
OTTAWA, February 11th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, stating the sizes of the desks required for the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School and the number of each size.

In reply I beg to say that an order is today being placed with the Canadian Office and School Furniture Co., Ltd., Preston, Ont., to forward to the Principal, Waugh, Man., c/o Greater Winnipeg Water District, Civic Building, Winnipeg, Man., the following desks, viz:

- 6 - No. B.B. A. Single Desks,
- 12 - No. 3,
- 2 - Rears, No. 4,
- 1 - Rear, No. 2,
- 1 - Teacher's Desk,
- 1 - Teacher's Chair.

These desks will be shipped in a knocked-down condition, all parts complete, and they can be assembled and set up in the classroom upon arrival.

The above firm has been requested to send their account, in duplicate, to you covering the cost of the desks and, after ascertaining that this equipment has arrived in good condition, you should certify the account and forward to the Department in order that payment can be made.

The prices quoted by the above firm are $9.25 each for the Nos. 1 and 2 desks, $9.00 each for the No. 3 desk, $7.85 each for the rears, $40.15 for the teacher's desk and $14.50 for the teacher's chair. These prices are F.O.B. Waugh, Man.

It is hoped when this equipment arrives that it will be satisfactory.

We are not ordering the No. 2 double rear seat or the bookcase. It is considered that a bookcase suitable for this purpose could be built locally at much less expense than having one sent in. If the school authorities can arrange to have this done at a reasonable cost, they may do so, and the Department will pay the expense involved upon receipt of properly certified vouchers.

Regarding a clock for the classroom, you should obtain competitive prices for a serviceable clock from a number of dealers, and you may purchase the same from the one quoting the lowest price. Certified accounts should be forwarded covering the expenditure.

You have already been advised regarding the blackboards.

Frank Edwards, M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
We do not supply waste paper baskets to residential schools.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The Indians of Shoal Lake Bands No 39 & 40 have decided to erect a Hospital building at Shoal Lake close to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and the Principal has received offers from parties in Toronto to donate the lumber for the roof, windows and doors.

The Indians intend taking the logs from the Reserves and erecting the building with the assistance of the Principal.

This Hospital is for cases that are not able to be taken into the School Hospital, and there will be a room attached so that any families having a patient in the Hospital can stay round and give assistance to the Nurse (Miss Alberta C. Reid) who will have full control.

I trust I did right in granting permission to cut the logs from the Reserve for this purpose.

In the erection of this building there will be no expense to the Department or the Bands concerned.

Yours obediently,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Ass't Deputy & Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
Ottawa, February 15th, 1923.

Sir—

In reply to your letter of the 8th instant regarding the desire of the Indians of Shoal Lake Bands numbers 39 and 40 to cut logs on their Reserves for the purpose of erecting a hospital building at Shoal Lake close to the Cecilia Je. Grey School, I note that you have already granted permission to them to do so.

The Department is of the opinion that negotiations are pending with regard to remodeling of the school or its removal to another suitable location. It would be wise for the Indians to embark on any work or expenditure of their own towards the erection of a hospital building adjacent to the school until those negotiations are completed. Furthermore, I have to remind you that Reserve number 40 is under timber license to the Kenora Lumber Company.

Under these circumstances, I would ask you, therefore, to cancel any permission you have given to these Indians to cut logs for the purpose of erecting a hospital building until such time as you are further advised.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Sir,— Re your 129/3/5 of January 30th.

Cecilia Jeffrey School

I have made an inspection trip to the School, and find that the Presbyterian Board are not doing their duty in the upkeep of the school.

It is absolutely necessary that something be done at once in the way of supporting the interior of the building. In some places it has sunk at least five inches. The Principal suggests that if $15,000 is spent this Spring the School should be good for another ten years, and he is now in favor of keeping it running, and if necessary, a new one built nearer Kenora.

Mr. Cookson suggests that $15,000 should be spent in raising the centre of the building, build two wings, enlarging the furnace, painting the hall and extra plumbing work.

I think it is advisable that after the Presbyterian Board have seen Mr. Ferrier, that he take a trip and see for himself the conditions which are very bad.

They must have a boat in the Spring and the Principal has suggested that I might ask the Department to
Buy him an engine, propeller and shafting and his Board would pay for the balance.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Ass't Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, March 29, 1922.

Memorandum

Mrs. Scott:

I beg to report that on Wednesday, March 15, 1922, in company with Rev. Mr. Coats, Superintendent of Presbyterian Missions for Manitoba, I made an inspection of the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School.

The school building, the property of the Presbyterian Church, is situated on the west shore of the Lake of the Woods. In the Summer it is reached by motor-boat from Kenora, a day's trip, and in the Winter by travelling from Winnipeg to Waugh on the Greater Winnipeg Waterway Railroad, and driving from that point across the lake, a distance of seven miles. For one month in the Spring and one month in the Fall, the school is completely isolated. The building is of frame construction on a stone foundation, and was built some twenty-five years ago. At different times since its construction, alterations and additions have been made to the building. The school outwardly presents a good appearance and is apparently substantially built, economically divided, and fully occupied. The accommodation and arrangement of rooms, while generally commendable, is in some respects faulty, particularly the lack of recreation rooms for boys and girls.

The heating system is a one-pipe steam, the steam being generated in a Gurney Oxford Section Boiler. Wood is used as fuel. Generally, the system satisfactorily heats the building, but, in a one-pipe system the circulation is not as free as it should be, and at times some of the radiators do not heat, which partly due to the improper working of the air valves.
The water used in the Institution is pumped from the Lake. The pump is installed in the basement, and connected to a Five Horse-power Gas Engine. The water is pumped into a two-thousand gallon pneumatic tank, and an average pressure of forty pounds is maintained throughout the building. The building is equipped with modern plumbing fixtures which are in a good state of repair.

The building is lighted by oil lamps, and in a school entirely of frame construction there is great danger of fire; but, the Staff appear to take every precaution to guard against same. New fire-hose is required on each floor to replace the existing ones which are unfit for further use.

It was reported to the Department that the building was sinking. A settlement has occurred in the two main supporting partitions across the building, which is due to the rotting out of the plates which rest on the basement floor and support the partitions. The partition is constructed of 2 x 6" studding resting on a 2 x 6" plate. This plate should be replaced by a new one on a proper foundation.

The ceiling in the dining-room has sagged considerably, which is due to the weight of the bearing partitions above. At some time in the past when alterations were carried out to the interior of the building, a supporting partition was evidently removed from what is now used as a dining-room, and no provision was made for the supporting of the floor at that point. To prevent further sagging, a beam supported on posts should be built in the dining-room. The inside of the building is in a very good state of repair throughout. The floors are of hardwood, the walls, plaster and ceilings of metal. The exterior is badly in need of paint and the Principal is prepared to supply the necessary labour if the Department will furnish him with the paint.

In the present location of the school, it is impossible, owing to the lack of land fit for cultivation, to successfully operate the Institution. There are only three acres under cultivation, and it is, therefore, necessary for the Principal to purchase all potatoes, vegetables, butter, etc., in fact all provisions required for use in the Institution, and this will always entail a heavy drain on the finances of the Church. An institution
in which seventy-five Indian children are cared for, requires at least three-hundred acres of good farming land in order to provide itself with the necessary amount of staple articles of food required.

The principal advised me that one of the greatest needs of the school is a new launch, the estimated cost of which is $2400.00, and he stated that he has, available, $750.00, to be used towards the purchase of this launch. The boat is required in order to bring in their supplies in the Summer time across the lake from Kenora.

A washing-machine is also required in the laundry, which is otherwise complete.

Taking into consideration the unfavourable location of the school, I cannot recommend any extensive alterations to the building. The repairs required to the interior partitions should, however, be carried out in order to prevent further settlement. The cost would not exceed $250.00, and the principal advised that, if the Department would furnish the materials, he would have the work done.

Registered Architect.

Write Dr. Edmiston

1. Giving unfavorable location, no extensive Dept. alterations
2. Urgent needs: Beam plate, fire box
3. Desirable - launch, laundry equip., painting
4. Important finding is: work should not be carried along
5. Dept. offers
Ottawa, April 5, 1922.

Dear Dr. Madison:

I have to refer to the report of Mr. R. G. Orr, of this Department, on the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School.

The most important finding of our Architect is that in his opinion the site of the Cecilia Jeffrey is unfortunate. He stated that it is impossible to successfully operate the institution, owing to the lack of arable land. Institutions situated like the Cecilia Jeffrey would always be a heavy drain on the finances of the Church and the State.

Mr. Orr reports that the building has sagged considerably and there is urgent need of a beam supported by posts in the dining-room. Further, settlement has occurred in the main supporting partitions in the building, which is due to the settling out of the plates which rest on the basement floor and support the partitions. The partition is constructed of studding resting on a wooden sill on a concrete floor. This plate should be replaced by a new one on a proper foundation. Another urgent need is new fire hose for each floor, to replace the present unfit equipment.

The Deputy Superintendent General, who is at present away from the office due to an injury, was favourable to Department action in connection with the urgent needs of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School. I have to inform you that the Department is writing to the Rev. Mr. Cockson, authorizing him to put in a beam, new plate and fire hose. Mr. Orr reports that the Rev. Principal is qualified to supervise the carpentering activities and will have the labour performed without cost to this Department.

Certain laundry equipment and a launch are desirable for the use of the school; but the Department feels that no large expenditure should be undertaken when the building is in such an unfavourable situation. The repairs which we are authorizing the Principal to undertake will, of course, be financed by this Department.

Yours very truly,

Russell I. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J. H. Madison, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
434 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Toronto, Ont.
April 6, 1932.

Rev. Sir,

Mr. Orr, who recently made an inspection of the Cecelia Jeffrey Boarding school, reports regarding the sagging of the floors of the building, that repairs are required to the two cross partitions in the basement, and the providing of a support for the ceiling of the dining-room by building in a beam with posts supported from basement floors up.

I am informed that Mr. Orr discussed these points with you when there, and that you are acquainted with the nature of the work required.

The Department is prepared to pay for the materials required, and it is understood that all labour will be furnished by you.

You may also purchase four 50 ft lengths of fire hose to replace the existing hose which is reported as unfit for further use.

In the purchasing of lumber and the fire-hose, competitive prices should be obtained and the purchases made from the firm quoting the lowest price.

When sending in the accounts to the Department, a memorandum should be attached showing the names of firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

I am writing Mr. F. Edwards, Indian Agent, advising him of the contents of this letter.

If it is your intention to purchase the lumber in Kenora, Mr. Edwards might be able to arrange this and have it shipped across the lake.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. W. J. Cookson,
Principal, Cecelia Jeffrey School,
McMun, Man.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I have just received a communication from the W.M.S. emphasizing the need for a new launch for the Cecilia Jeffrey School. The old boat is beyond repair and I understand it is not being used at all now, nor could it be in rough weather.

I find that the staff at Cecilia Jeffrey have purchased a disappearing propeller boat of the John Bull type for their own use. This serves for short trips to the island end to Waugh. I understand the cost of this boat was between $500 and $600.

Will the Government be prepared to purchase a boat of sufficient size to meet the requirements of the work at Cecilia Jeffrey? I am told this could be built at the Caronie Boat Works at Kenora and it should be completed within the next two months. The waters of Shoal Lake, as you know, are rough, and with a poor boat the lives of our staff and the children are in danger.

We will have no way of transporting the children from the School to Kenora to their homes, July 1st, nor can we bring them back August 1st, unless a Kenora boat is engaged to come in for them. For a 45 mile trip, this will mean quite an outlay. Our Women's Missionary Society feel that a boat should be provided, at the latest, in August.

Hoping to hear from you in the near future,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

JHE/HU (w)
Ottawa, June 7, 1923.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, emphasizing the need for a new motor launch for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, and requesting that we purchase a boat of sufficient size to meet the requirements at this school.

I regret that we have no funds available during the present fiscal year to purchase a launch; but, in order that the school will not be handicapped in transporting the children to their homes in July and returning them to the school in August, we will be pleased to pay a reasonable charge for the services of a boat for this purpose. I hope that this assistance will solve the difficulty of transportation during the present summer.

The need of a launch for this school will be noted for our estimates for the next fiscal year, and I hope it will be possible to provide for the same.

If payment of the hire of a launch to transport the children this summer will be satisfactory, I will be pleased to be advised to that effect, in order that our agent and the principal of the school may be informed.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General,

Sir,

At Cecilia Jeffrey School, I made a visit there on Sunday 16th instant, and was informed by the Principal that he was going ahead with the work authorized by the Department's Architect.

He brought up the matter of enlarging the hospital and dormitory. He figures that the alterations required will cost roughly about $750 for materials and labour that will have to be hired; the rough labour he can hire Indians for, but for the finer work he would require two carpenters.

Mr Cookson informs me that if the Department will pay $750 he and Nurse Reid will pay $200 which he believes will cover all that he needs at the present time, to take care of the infectious cases and other cases that will have to be isolated.

Mr Cookson informs me that he received a telephone message to prepare a sketch of the proposed enlargement (which he calls a sleeping porch) as the Department had approved of this.

The principal is submitting sketch to the Home Mission Board in Toronto to be taken up with the Dept. This estimate of his is without the cost of labour as he has offered to do this himself so far as the work that would have to be carried out by the Church with a grant from the Department to help, on the other side he says if the Department is going to carry out the work he would be willing to take charge and be responsible for the hiring of labour etc., but he is very busy at present ploughing, building a root house, and clearing land, together with the other repair work on the building.

Mr Cookson wishes to get the porch erected this summer if at all possible and as our Mr Paget is visiting the School with me next week I will get him to go into the matter with me and will issue instructions as advised by him.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Indian Agent
Department of Indian Affairs

Letter No. 110

Office of the Kenora Indian Agency,

10th August, 1922.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Vouchers Nos. 2754, amounting to $7.20, in favour of Johnson's Drug Store, Kenora, Ont., for supplies for Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

This expenditure was authorized by Departmental Letter No. 129-3-4, dated July 12th, 1922.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

On the 27th instant Mr. F. H. Paget and I made an inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey School and the Principal showed us the alterations and repairs he is making as instructed.

Both Mr. Paget and I consider that the buildings want painting, the sleeping porch built, and that quite a lot of repairs are necessary, whether the Presbyterian Board or the Church do this is a question for the Department. The buildings should also have electric light; the school has a motor but no dynamo.

If the school is going to be continued these things should be attended to.

On Mr. Paget's return to Ottawa, he will no doubt be able to inform you as to what he advises.

John Edward Kipling, a pupil from the School has contracted T.B., and we have been able to get him admitted to Minette Sanatorium, where he will be treated and also instructed in the care &c. of the Indians for this disease, on his discharge he will be in a position to instruct and help the others in combating the disease. This is a sad case as the boy was studying for the Church and the Bishop of Kaswatin was endeavouring to get the Missionary Society to give him an education at St. James College Winnipeg, but unless he recovers there will be no good in going to any further expense in the matter.

Trusting the Department approves of our action in this matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 139-55 dated Aug. 16th which I received by the last mail from Winnipeg.

In regard to the question of rent, I have kindly forwarded to Stephen Edwards, Secretary of the Board, an estimate of the amount of the school necessary at this date. I cannot judge to do the work. This is reply to a letter that has come from him a few days ago. He mentions his sleeping porch, his beds and other arrangements for the time being. He also mentions the school in Winnipeg and wishes me to have a house built there within a few days with the intention to plan and build a new building. But he does not say if he requires any help from him. I expect to be in Winnipeg shortly and will then be able to give you more information and forward all the facts that we know at this present time.

I am sure that you will receive news as soon as possible and hope to hear from you soon.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

By way of making the emergency, I have been able to utilize the dormitories and laundry as a matter of 16 ft. Of facilities we found and also storage was as much before than it has been in the recent equipment for the town.
