Sir,

In reply to your letter No 129-3-b of 16th ult. I now enclose plans drawn by J.H.G. Russell, Architect of Winnipeg showing the proposed alteration to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, he estimates the cost will be about $3000 but Mr Cookson thinks that with the use of Indian labour this will be very materially reduced and he would place the amount at about $2000 to $2500.

Mr Cookson is a practical carpenter and can well be trusted to look after the work himself.

Re painting the School, Mr Cookson estimates the following will be required:

For painting Roof,
24 gal black shingle stain.
8 gal red for gables.

For painting Outside walls,
25 gal cream or white
4 gal green finishing
1 gal black washes.
2 gal white verandah.

For painting wainscoting in halls & dormitories,
8 gal inside gray, for doors and windows.
3 gal colour to match.

For Painting of Children's & staff dining room & sitting room
4 gal flat milk paint.
1 gal for doors and windows.

For kitchens and sculleries,
2 gal light green inside paint.

For painting Barn,
2 gal black shingle stain.
4 gal red paint.
½ gal White.

Further with the painting it will be necessary to do considerable calsoining in parts of the building that was not done last year, this will take about twenty packets.
With regard to labour Mr Cookson says he will be able to undertake this himself with a little outside help and the use of Indians.

The inside work could be done during the winter, as he is at present busy on the extension of the laundry and dining room.

With the proposed alterations completed he could take care of 8 or 10 more pupils.

Mr Cookson would like if possible to get the paint &c soon so that he could get it up before the Lakes freeze up.

I would suggest if the Department intends to get the paint for the School that I call for tenders from the wholesale houses in Winnipeg for the necessary colour, oils turpentine &c and the School could do the mixing themselves and so effect a considerable saving.

Awaiting your instructions,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Frank Edward

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

P.S. I should like to get a copy of the blueprint of the proposed alterations for my files, and do check up as the work proceeds.
September 13th, 1922.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Keenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re Cecilia Jeffrey School

At the request of Mr. W. J. Cookstone, I am sending you under separate cover plan showing the proposed alterations to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, also the original blue prints.

Mr. Cookstone asked me to send you an estimate of the value of the proposed changes, these I think will cost about Three Thousand Dollars, it is rather hard to arrive at a basis from which to work, owing to the outside location of the building, but as they are intending to do quite a large part of the work themselves I think the above figure will about cover the cost.

Yours very truly,

P.S. Drawings Enclosed.

Copy to Mr. Cookstone.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, September 19, 1922.

MR. SCOTT,

With reference to the building of a small addition to provide more accommodation to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I beg to advise you that the estimated cost of this work is approximately $3,000.00.

If the work is authorized, Mr. Cookston has offered to furnish most of the labour required. The estimated cost of the paint required to paint the building would be approximately $350.00, and the Principal has also offered to provide the necessary labour.

You will remember that Mr. Paget spoke to you about these matters on his return to the Department, after visiting Cecilia Jeffrey School.

If it is your wish that this work be carried out, instructions should be sent as soon as possible, in order that materials required may be shipped in before the lake freezes up. Indian Agent Edwards could purchase the materials after obtaining competitive prices.

[Signature]

I cannot recommend that the site accommodation be divided until the Church authorities agree to the future policy at Cecilia Jeffrey School.

[Signature]
A meeting of the Indian work Committee was held in Manitoba College on Friday evening September 9th. There were present:- Revs Hugh Robertson, D.D.Miller, W.J.Cookson, Mrs Watson, and R.J.MacPherson.

Mr Cookson reported regarding the progress and condition of the work at Cecilia Jeffrey School and asked the Board of Home Missions be responsible for a plumber to go out to the School and lay fifty feet of iron piping, also for the iron piping, trap, and catch basin, also field tiling to the Lake, about 200 feet. It would be necessary for a plumber to leave Winnipeg, about 1 o'clock on a Thursday afternoon and he would be absent until noon on Monday. Mr Cookson reported that this drain was absolutely necessary to relieve the present septic tank and also as a means of carrying off the water from the laundry. It was unanimously decided to make this recommendation to the Board in the expectation that the Board might afterwards reimburse itself out of the Government Grant. The Chairman was instructed to get an estimate regarding the cost of the work.

(James MacKie estimated cost of cast iron pipe (f.o.b. Winnipeg) and plumbing to be about $250.00. The tiling would cost (f.o.b.W'peg) about $22.80.)

After full discussion of the requirements of the School it was unanimously decided to recommend that the Department of Indian Affairs appropriate the sum of $10,000 in improving the equipment and plant of the School during 1923, as follows:-

| Item                                      | Cost     |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|
| Boat & Boat house                         | $4500.00 |
| Electric light in School                  |          |
| Engine, generator, switch board, wiring   | $2500.00 |
| Heating plant and plumbing systems        | $2000.00 |
| to be put into proper condition           |          |
| Incidental repairs to same, drains out    | $1000.00 |
| houses &c.                                |          |

Total. $10,000.00

Mr Cookson suggested that the Indian Department be requested to make it unlawful for a pupil or ex-pupil of the School to marry or be married without the permission of the Indian Agent, the penalty in case of breach to be no Treaty money for the children of such marriage, until they have reached the age of twenty-one years, and no permission to these children to attend school. After full discussion it was decided to make this recommendation.

It was also decided to recommend to the Home Mission Board that an ordained Missionary be appointed to the Indians of Shoal Lake.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(Signed) R.J.MacPherson,
Chairman Committee.
Sir,

Enclosed please find copy of a meeting of the Indian Work Committee of the Presbytery of Winnipeg, which has been forwarded me by Mr. Cookson, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

You will notice the Committee decided to ask our Department to appropriate $10,000 for Boat, Electric Light, and repairs &c.

All this is in addition to what has already been recommended by Mr. Paget and myself, viz.: painting and material &c for the School, see my letter #108-13 of 14th instant.

There is no doubt that all these things are needed very badly at the School, but that is no reason why the Church should not bear some of the expense, it does not seem right that all this expense should be paid by the Department unless the Church bears some of the expense.

As regards the last paragraph in the report re children marrying without the permission of the Agent or School. On several occasions girls have run away from the schools whilst on holidays and have been living with men, so that they would not have to be sent back to School, as they could say they were married Indian fashion.

Mr. Cookson's idea of stopping the Treaty money seems a way out of the difficulty, but is a very radical one and I do not know if it would have the desired effect. This is a matter that is difficult of solution, and I should be glad if the Department would suggest what they consider a reasonable way to deal with the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Sept. 25, 1922.

Sir:

I have your No. 108-13 of the 19th instant, concerning the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. I have noted the copy of the minutes of the meeting of the Indian Work Committee of the Presbytery of Winnipeg, and beg to state that this will receive the attention of the Department when it is officially presented from the Church Authorities.

Concerning the recommendations of your letter of the 14th instant, of the same file number, I wish to inform you that the Department has decided to proceed with the painting without delay. The proposed alterations to permit of added accommodation will have to remain over another future agreement has been reached with the Church Authorities. I have noted that the total paint required for the roof, outside walls, interior woodwork and barn is about 100 gallons and that 20 packets of calcimine is needed.

You should call for tenders for this material and for the necessary oil and turpentine and make the purchases. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded to the Department and a memo showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. It is understood that the school authorities will arrange for the mixing and other labour required in connection with the work.

That portion of your letter dealing with school children marrying while on holiday will be dealt with in a separate communication.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.C.S., Litt.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I have just had a letter from Rev. D.D. Millar, who is our Home Mission Convener for Winnipeg Presbytery. Part of his letter reads as follows:

"I am writing you in regard to Cecilio Jeffrey School. You may remember that at the Executive meeting I intimated that we were doing some repairs in the basement and to the sewage system which were absolutely necessary. I have now received the bills for the work and will enclose them. They have passed the Home Mission Committee and Presbytery. The bills amount to £286.27. Mr. Cookson was with us last week and assured us that the sewage system was in first class shape. The septic tank has been thoroughly cleaned and the Principal did the work himself as he could not trust it to anyone else. A new sewer has been opened into the lake in order to lessen the work the septic tank would have to do. This new sewer will have to carry all the water from the washroom and the water from the sewer troughs, etc. This had to be rushed through before the frost came. We are sending these on to you with the expectation that the government shall pay for these repairs."

I am enclosing the accounts and hope the Department will take care of them.

I received your communication in which you asked for a rough estimate of the further repairs that would be necessary to make this building comfortably and sanitary, and I referred this to our District Superintendent and to Winnipeg Presbytery. I should have a reply soon.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

JH Edmison

Enc. 5 Accts.

JHE/EC

Sir,

Enclosed please find personal letter I have received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, for your perusal, which I shall be glad if you will return so that I can keep same on my files for reference.

I do not know exactly what the Department has promised them in the way of a launch, but they need it very badly. You will see by the enclosed letter that the principal is very reasonable and does not wish to saddle the Department with more than their share of the expense; he agrees with me that the Church should bear a portion of the cost of improvements etc.

The Principal's letter was not written with the knowledge of the Church authorities, and therefore should be considered confidential by our Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, Nov. 20, 1922.

Sir:

I have your No. 108-15 of the 13th instant, enclosing a personal letter from the Principal of the school to yourself, referring to the needs at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

In reply I beg to state that we are now preparing the Estimates for the fiscal year 1923-24, and the claims of this institution will not be overlooked. Consideration is being given to including items for the boat and boat house, the alterations to permit of more accommodation and for the overhauling of the heating system and the provision of a new furnace. It is felt by this Department that the Church authorities should provide funds for electric lighting plant. It might be possible for the Principal to assist in this matter from the per capita earnings.

I am enclosing Mr. Cookson's letter to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Dr. Emison,

With reference to the C. J. School we have looked into the question of repairs. The lighting system will cost about $1800 for an 80 light system.

To put the present furnace in good condition will cost about $400, but to heat the balcony for consumptive patients, an additional furnace will be required, making an outlay of $2,000 instead of $400. Mr. Cookson says he can repair the present plumbing system without expense to the Church or Department.

Yours very sincerely,

Sgd. John A. Cormie,
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.S.C., Litt.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

November 20, 1922.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

The Presbyterian Church authorities have decided to continue the activity at Cecilia Jeffrey for some years. Mr. Orr reports the buildings in fair shape and that it would not be a waste of money to make any alterations necessary. The requests are as follows:

Boat and boat house ........................................ $4500.
New furnace and overhauling heating system 2000.
Alterations to permit of more dormitory accommodation 3000.

I believe that the Church should be asked to put in the lighting system themselves. Mr. Cookson, the principal, has expressed to Mr. Agent Edwards his ability to care for nearly one half of the expense in this connection from per capita earnings. If it is your wish, I will note for the Estimates the other items that appear to be so necessary, and will direct a letter to Dr. Edmison to that effect.

Sup't of Indian Education.
Ottawa, Nov. 20, 1922.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, estimating the cost of overhauling the heating and lighting systems of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. I have noted that the Principal will be responsible for any repairs that are necessary to the plumbing.

I will have to include items in the Estimates, which we are now preparing, for the requirements of this institution. Parliament will be asked to vote items providing for a boat and boat house, alterations to the building and for a new furnace and other heating fixtures. I wish to recommend that the Church authorities and the Rev. Principal make arrangements for the electric lighting at the school. If this arrangement provides funds for the other more expensive requirements, I am of the opinion that church funds, supplemented perhaps by per capita earnings, should arrange for the proper lighting of the building.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. J. H. Maclean, D.D.,

Dear Sir:

Your enquiry of the 5th has just been received. We can assure you that we appreciate very much the opportunity given us to quote you on the paints, stains, etc., required for Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, Shoal Lake. We are also pleased to note from your enquiry that the materials you wish us to quote on are to all first-class quality. This is the only quality of paints, varnishes, etc., that we manufacture. We do not make a second quality goods in order to compete with this class of goods, which are sold principally by mail order houses.

Doubtless you are familiar with the high quality of our goods. If not, we might mention that we have been manufacturing paints and varnishes in Winnipeg for the past 40 years. Our goods are sold by exclusive agents in practically every town in the three western provinces. We also have a very active account in your town, Canniff & Williams.

Our business with the large consumers of paint, such as the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, The Canadian National Railways, and the different Line Elevator Companies throughout the West is very extensive. We have also sold large quantities of our materials to the Indian Agent at Gleichen, Alta. In fact, during the past few months we have furnished them with several barrels of paints and stains, and they have always been successful in getting satisfactory results from our materials.

Dear Sir:

Further, with reference to our tender for paint material, we would like to point out that we are figuring on Genuine Elephant White Lead & all colours ground in oil, & all liquid for paint & stain is pure Linseed Oil.

We know that this is unusual, generally paint manufacturers supply cheap oil for stain, and often adulterate oil for mixing paint which they claim gives good results. However we know that paint made from pure linseed oil & white lead gives better covering quality and is much more durable, and this is what we guarantee to supply.

We have made an estimate of the material, which in one case would cost about $243.58 and if ground and mixed in the factory it would cost about $293.45. We believe the latter would be the best way to get these goods, as they would be better mixed and would have uniformity in colour, which we are sure would give better results.

Hoping to be favored with your valued order, we are

Yours very Truly,

A.T. Fife & Co.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

We note in your favor of 27th ultimo an enclosure from the Indian Dept., Ottawa, which states that items for requirements of Geo. Jeffrey Indian Boarding School for 1923 will be placed in the estimates for the approval of Parliament. The items stated are as follows - "Boat and boat house", alterations to the building - a new furnace and other heating fixtures etc.

The only alterations to the building we have asked for was a sleeping Balcony, for T.B. children, which would require a separate furnace for heating purposes but since making this request some months ago the Dept. have removed the tubercular children to Ninette or St. Boniface Hospital in Winnipeg. Our W.M.S. Board feel if this is to be the policy of the Dept. in future that cost of Balcony and additional furnace might be dispensed with. This would lessen the estimate at least $1,000.00. In view of the many devastating fires in institutions and the extreme isolation of C.J. Indian Boarding School we would urge the Dept. in this instance to place an electric lighting plant in this Boarding School. In event of a fire there is not a building of any description within miles of our school to shelter staff or children.

Our Women's Missionary Society would not recommend the extension of our present building at C.J. but make it safe and comfortable for staff and children. We are relying on the promise of the Dept. of over a year ago to give us a new school in a different location where we could have some land around and make more adequate provision for the many children in the Lake of the Woods region who are not being cared for by any organization.

With the approval of the Dept. we would even carry on our present work at C.J. indefinitely besides assuming the responsibility of a new staff for the new school which we have hoped for so long - the desire to add another B.School to our list and to the best of our knowledge believe the opportunity is at our door. In the untouched regions in and around the Lake of the Woods. There are many Pagan Indians even in parts of our own Province of Ontario.

With kind regards, I remain

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Adelaide Clark.
The Presbyterian Church in Canada

Dear Dr. Scott:

In your communication of Nov. 20th you suggested that the Church authorities and Principal make arrangements for the electric lighting at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School.

I referred your suggestion to the W.M.S. They have gone very carefully into the whole matter and I have today received a communication from Mrs. Clark, Convener of the Indian Committee. Copy of this, I enclose. From this, you will see that the W.M.S. are not in a position to expend $1500 on an electric lighting plant. Apparently, the W.M.S. have given up the thought of the balcony, and now that you have decided to remove the tubercular children to Ninette or St. Boniface, the new furnace will not be required.

My judgment is, that it would not be wise to put a heavy expenditure on the old building, if there is to be a new one erected soon. On the other hand, if there is going to be any undue delay in securing the new Boarding School, the old one should be made safe and comfortable.

You will note also, that the W.M.S. are of the opinion that there may be room for another school and they seem prepared to accept some responsibility in connection with it, should it be established.

Yours sincerely,

JHE/JDF.

[Signature]

OTTAWA, January 25th, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, also your telegram and letter of the 23rd instant, regarding the accounts for launch hire for the transportation of pupils at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $60, being the amount of these accounts, is being made payable and will be sent to the Treasurer of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, as this Society has settled the amount of the charges for the launch hire with McDonnell Bros. and the J. W. Stone Boat Mfg. Co.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Rev. T. H. Edmison, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
434 Confederation Life Building,
Toronto, Ont.
Dear Captain Edwards,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th. In regard to the matter of Pete Redsky, I will attend to this as soon as he calls. He is making fair progress with his wood, for one thing he is not handing out the same amount of supplies. The only help that he gets is that of Indians from North West Angle.

In regard to the matter of permit for cutting wood on Reserve 40 for school purposes, since that Chief Redsky is away I will be unable to attend to this matter until later.

I have a communication from the Ontario Department giving permit for 250 cords within one mile of the School Land boundary, also to cut any small tamarack that may not be saleable owing to size. The wood to be cut where Pete Redsky is cutting for Kron.

I note your remarks re sleeping porch and extensions. I received a communication from our Board in Toronto in which I have been severely called to account for what may seem to be an action on my part by way of trying to establish matters on a more permanent basis, in face of the promise that the Department have made for a new school. For a man to sit at his desk without any practical knowledge of working conditions and dictate a policy to me is absolutely absurd. This is the position we have it in the case of Dr. Edmison. The action was taken on the ground that they did not believe in the expenditure of so large a sum of money on the school as they believe it would only delay the matter of a new building.

In sending in my yearly report last month, I took the matter up in detail and I have advised the board that in taking the matter out of the hands of the Department that they must face the facts themselves. Something has got to be done.

Besides the two children that were sent away of whom we have not heard anything, we have two other children in the hospital here bearing the same symptoms, and others in the main building receiving treatment. It would welcome an examination by medical officials as a way of ascertaining what might be the cause of all this, and with all the Department is doing by way of caring for these children when they must pass out of our hands. The providing of a Nurse and supply of dispensary, it is the duty of our Church at least to supply the proper accommodation for the care of patients. In face of the action that the Church has taken in view of the help of the Department in this respect, I consider that it is quite in order that the Doctor should complain to the Department as to the working conditions and demand that the Church should at least refit its present hospital. In this respect I would suggest that the Nurses room and dispensary should be located next to the main building, that the whole of the two sides and end made available for this use should be fitted up with glass and storm windows to let in plenty of daylight and a better system of ventilation. At the same time I would insist that suitable storm windows be fitted up to all dormitories that the dormitories could be ventilated so as to avoid the draft that we have at the present time that must needs have some effect upon the lungs.

I am not taking up the matter with any spirit of antagonism in view of the action that the Church has taken in this matter. While I would be loyal to the Church at the same time I would consider it my duty to impress upon them any condition within the bounds of their sphere of labour that might be improved upon.

I am hoping there will be no difficulty in the matter of a launch for at the present time we are absolutely tied up. It is not my intension to offer to take the launch from where
it now lies without that it should be put in thorough working order or rather a new launch be provided.

We cannot possibly carry on the work even with the conveniences that may be offered in the hiring of a launch as in the case of last year. At that time our old launch was available for emergency at the present time it is absolutely tied up.

I appreciate the help that you have always given us in these matters and I can assure you of my hearty cooperation in the carrying out of any matter pertaining to the interest of the Department and its work amongst the Indians.

Referring to the matter of Sinclair the Indian who was the means of making trouble in the case of Jessie Wapato I have seen this matter in a new light. We have still the proof that is necessary to know that this is only a put up job as we say by way of getting a discharge from School. This is the third time as I understand that the girl has come with the same story and in looking back over the history of the School find that there are numbers of pupils that have been discharged where it has been proved afterwards that no such case existed. I find this to be a common practice among the elder pupils of our schools. I am ashamed to report that I find that we have three of our older boys and girls who have sought contact in this way with no other object in view than to have a heart to heart talk with older boys and have given them clearly to understand that in so far that in this way they should necessitate the discharge of any girl that they first must pay the price with a term of imprisonment. I believe that this is quite in order with the law of our country. It is not a question of the right or wrong as the case may be of their getting married but to teach that such an action on their part is a criminal offence against the most sacred laws of nature and we must teach our Indian boys and girls the value of that law as far as it affects the development of true womanhood. I believe that the same rule should apply for the protection of our older girls while they are absent from School. It would be a good thing to have a straight talk with the Indian at Treaty time, living them clearly to understand that such an action will be taken if consistent with law and order.

I shall be pleased to know your opinion in this matter, for it is my intention to take a firm stand by way of preventing this practice.

I remain

Yours truly

(Signed) W. J. Cookson.
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

Kenora, Ontario.

578904. 7th February, 1923.

Sr.— Enclosed please find copy of letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School for your information.

Dr. Ferguson who is also the Public Officer for Health here, suggests that if there is no sleeping porch built, there should be some sort of isolation hut or semi tent built for the reception of sick children, he says they would only cost a very little. There should be two, one for boys and one for girls, and they could be easily heated with small stoves; they should have glass windows for bad weather and mosquito screens for the summer.

Mr. Cockson in my opinion is quite right that the repairs and additions are very badly needed, but Dr. Edmison seems to think the School will soon be removed or rebuilt, there will be enough children at the Shoal Reserves to keep the School going for many years, and in my opinion if we are going to still keep this school in operation something must be done.

As regards the launch I understand the Department has put in the estimates an amount to cover this, if they cannot get a boat, they will be very seriously handicapped as it is not always possible to hire a boat when needed.

The other matters dealt with in the letter are being dealt with from this office.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Feb. 28, 1925.

Sir:

I have your No. 108-13 of the 7th instant, enclosing a copy of a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Boarding School, relative to the needs of that institution. I have noted that you recommend some provision for the isolation and care of sick children, even if the Department is not prepared to expend a large sum for an addition and general renovation of the school building.

In reply I wish to state that, as you were informed in official communication of this file number, of the 23rd ultimo, it is not the intention to undertake extensive improvements. This decision was reached, after some correspondence with the Presbyterian Board of Home Missions. It was thought advisable to arrange for the reception of tubercular children at various points near to the school. However, if the Rev. Principal and yourself are of the opinion that some provision must be made for an infirmary, I would be pleased to have a definite recommendation and an estimate of the probable cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
March 2nd

Dear Captain Edwards,

In regard to the question of a launch for the new school at Waupaca. The cooperation that the Department has assured us in this matter, and we are anxious to know what steps have been already taken on the matter. If you are aware that we are absolutely held up at the present moment from the launch, so much that it will be utterly impossible for us to make any use of it this summer. It was impossible for us to bring in our next quarter's supply across the ice, but in the matter of our summer work we cannot possibly manage without the service of a launch at this stage.

This has to be considered as a point of safety and as means of communication with both Kenora & Waupaca. There two men at the school ready to start on the journey to go for boat house and I am anxious.
To know whether I should continue with this work as the time is short. Please let me know in this matter as early as possible.

I am pleased to report that after the outbreak of flu that we have had at the school that there have been no serious results and the children are progressing favourably.

Remain

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

W. J. Cookson

Passage. All children have to pass here many times daily. They hang around, it is difficult to keep them away.
Sir,

I reply to your letter #129-3-5 of 22nd ultimo re needs of the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Mr. Cookson the Principal has been in to see me and we have discussed your letter.

The Principal informs me it is absolutely necessary that something be done to provide for isolation of children, and under the circumstances, as the Department doesn't intend to undertake extensive alterations, he suggests that the present Hospital should be altered as shown on the accompanying sketch. The present building is shown in black and the alterations in red. It will prevent all the school children having to use the hospital doors and the infection is carried to them. But with the alterations as shown there would be no danger of the infection being carried into the school proper.

The position of the Nurse's room and dispensary are changed and the wards moved to the outside, the walls would have to be cut away and large windows inserted all round, for fresh air and ventilation, storm windows would also have to be got. We figure the alteration would not cost more than $500.00 and might be done for considerably less. But a Plasterer would have to be got from Winnipeg and also alterations made in the heating arrangements but the carpenter work could be done by the Principal and the carpenter at Selkirk.

It appears to me that the co-operation between the Principal and his Board is not very good, he tries to do his best according to his own views, and does not get the support he thinks he is entitled to. I believe if the Presbyterian Board visited the School, and saw for themselves what was required, they would be more willing to fall in with the Principal's ideas, as he is on the spot and has a better idea what is required.

As regards a boat for the School, I enclose a letter received from the Principal. They will have to have one and unless arrangements are made very soon it will be too late to have one built to be of use to them this
Spring, and it will be a big expense to the School to hire one when they need it, and also it is not always possible to get one when required.

Kindly let me know how to answer the Principal's letter.

Mr Cookson has asked several firms to tender on a suitable boat and has sent the tenders to me, but I have informed him that I have no instructions to call for tenders, but that I will hold them in this office until arrangements, if any, are made.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

March 12, 1923.

MR. [Signature]

Although the Presbyterian Church authorities have not urged for extensive improvements at Cecilia Jeffrey, the Rev. Principal and Mr. Indian Agent Edwards have drawn to our attention the advisability of providing better infirmary arrangements for the school. The Presbyterian Board of Missions has not gone on record as favoring either a development or a closing of the work of this institution; and, as the present needs of the school must not be overlooked, I would recommend that your authority be given for an expenditure not to exceed £500, on repairs to the hospital building. Funds are available from the present appropriation.

IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

Kenora, Ontario.

580828 18th March, 1923.

In reply to your letter #129-3-5 of 15th instant, re Launch for Cecilia Jeffrey School.

I herewith submit tenders already received also a letter from the Principal of the School Mr Cookson recommending Cossey's Launch.

The Stone Boat Company will submit tenders in a few days as soon as they can be got out. They have a launch in course of construction similar to the one we got last Spring for this Agency, that might be suitable, this could be delivered at the opening of navigation.

It will be late in the summer before any of the boats already tendered for can be delivered as the tenders were made I understand so that the firms could build the boat during the slack period i.e. the winter months.

Mr Cookson seems to prefer a cabin cruiser sort of boat but I personally do not think it will be as serviceable as the more open kind. The cabins are always stuffy, and it does not appear so easy to get at the engine for repairs.

As soon as the tenders are received from the Stone Boat Company I will forward them for consideration, the Launch they built for us last summer has given every satisfaction, and this firm also has an arrangement to build a boat for the Provincial Government.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

PRINCIPAL CECILIA JEFFREY SCHOOL HAS BEEN LAUNCH AND SAYS ENTIRELY SATISFACTORY STONE CANNOT REDUCE PRICE.

FRANK EDWARDS

1158
April 9th, 1923.

MEMORANDUM

HON. CHARLIE STEWART,

In the Main Estimates, 1923-24, there is an item to provide for the purchase of a launch for the Ogilvie Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. The old boat is beyond repair and a new one is absolutely necessary to the satisfactory conduct of the school this coming summer. The school is located on the Lake of the Woods some 35 miles from Kenora, and all transportation in the summer must be by water.

Funds will not be available until after the interim supply bill has been assented to by His Excellency, but as it is desirable that the matter be given at the earliest possible date, I will be pleased to have your authority to secure a minute number from the Purchasing Commission. The price of the launch will be in the neighborhood of $4250.00

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your telegram of 4th instant re Launch for Cecilia Jeffrey School.

As the Principal of the School was coming to Kenora on the 7th, I delayed replying until he had seen the boat at Stoneham. I then wired you that the boat was entirely suitable.

Mr. Cockson saw the boat and approves, in every way. I may say the Launch is almost exactly similar to the one we purchased for the Department last spring, with the exception that it is a little higher in the bow, and the planking is a little stronger in places which are improvements suggested from our boat.

The engine supplied is of the same manufacture as ours except that whilst ours is four cylinders, the one for the School will be only three cylinders, and she will therefore not be so fast a boat, but I think she will be plenty fast enough for anything they may require, and should be a good serviceable boat for transportation of freight or passengers.

Your Chief Accountant Mr. Paget, was our in our boat last summer and can give you his views.

The only thing against the deal is the price as you only have allowed $3500 and Stone will not take less than the amount asked i.e., $4200.

For your information I may say that Colonel Maclean Manager of the Mikado Mine here informs me that if we do not purchase this boat, his Company will most likely do so in the Spring.

Your obedient servant

Frank Edwards

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 16, 1923.

Gentlemen:

Our Agent at Kenora, Mr. Frank Edwards, informs us that you have a motor launch in course of construction, which will be ready for delivery on or about May first, next. In compliance with the requirements of the Purchasing Commission of Canada, we are calling for tenders from a number of manufacturers for the supplying of a motor launch conforming to the following specifications:

The hull, engine and all equipment and fittings must be in excellent condition.

Length; over all: 40 ft.
Beam: 8' 6"
Engine: 21 h.p.
Speed: 10 miles per hour.
Cabin built over engine.
Suitable covered locker, seats and berths and lavatory.
Electric light.
Space for two tons freight.

We understand that the boat you are building is similar to the above in all respects. It may be that you would desire to amend your quotation made Mr. Agent Edwards for the supplying of a boat of the above type, and we would be pleased to receive your lowest price.

The boat must be delivered in the water at Kenora between May first and 10th, next, and under no condition later than the last named date. No quotation received by this Department later than Monday April 23rd, at noon, can be considered. Before any offer is accepted by this Department, the boat will be rigidly examined by our representative.

Yours truly,

F. H. Laget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

The J. W. Stone Boat Mfg. Co., Ltd.,
Kenora,
Ont.
Ottawa, April 16, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, referring to the quotation received by you from the J. W. Stone Boat Manufacturing Company Limited, Kenora, Ont., for the supplying of a motor launch for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that the Purchasing Commission of Canada have instructed us to call for tenders from a number of dealers, for the supplying of a launch of a type similar to that which the above firm are now building and will have ready for delivery on or about May first, next. Tenders will be received until April 23rd, at noon, and the above firm have also been asked to submit a price. The firms asked to quote have been informed that it is necessary that delivery be made at Kenora between May first and 10th, next, and under no conditions later than the last named date.

We will inform you later as to the successful tenderer and when delivery of the boat secured will be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

LACHINE, April 18th 1925.

F.H. Paget, Esq.,
Dep't of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

We understand that your department is in the market for a boat approximately forty feet long for use as a supply boat.

For your information we are enclosing descriptive folders on some of the boats which we have on sale.

We are also forwarding under separate cover specifications and photo of our model "E" work boat which we think might interest you. These boats are being used extensively by the various lumber companies for tow and supply boats and have given every satisfaction. They are essentially a heavy duty knockabout boat.

Should one of these boats suit your requirements we shall be very glad to have one of our representatives call upon you and furnish any further information desired.

Awaiting an early reply with interest, we are,

Yours truly,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

REQUIREMENTS.

This Department requires for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, for service on the Lake of the Woods, a semi-cabin cruiser, 35 to 40 feet in length. The boat is needed for the purpose of carrying children and supplies from Kenora to the school, a distance of 35 miles. It is desired that there be accommodation for at least two tons freight, and that the launch is capable of towing a small scow.
Ottawa, April 26, 1923.

Memorandum.

The Purchasing Commission of Canada:

I have to refer to my memorandum, of this file number, of the 13th instant, relative to the purchase of a launch for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, on the Lake of the Woods. A copy of this last memorandum is attached. Following your instructions of the 14th instant, letters were addressed to 10 manufacturers of boats, outlining our needs and asking for quotations.

Four firms offered launches that conformed somewhat to our requirements. Their descriptions and prices are enclosed in the attached envelopes. With the assistance of your Colonel Hartran, we secured the services of Engineer Commander T. C. Phillips, a consulting naval engineer of the Department of National Defence (on loan service). This expert was made acquainted with our requirements and shown a copy of the enclosed abstract of tenders. After a careful examination of this form, he asked to see the motor boat "Kay", owned locally by Mr. G. M. Faqueter of Rockcliffe. Mr. Ferrier and myself accompanied Commander Phillips to the wharf and we unhesitatingly pronounced the boat as suitable for our requirements, if in good condition. Commander Phillips' report is immediately hereunder.

Since this comparison of prices and boats, the communication which is attached has been received from T. F. Bonner, Naval Architect and Vessel Broker, of Toronto. He offers two boats, but they would not officially draw your attention to the fact that they are 6 and 9 years old respectively. I wish to recommend the purchase of the motor boat "Kay" from R. A. Sproule & Son, who are handling the article. The price is $2750.00 f.o.b. cars Ottawa. The Superintendent of Indian Education concurs.

If your authority is given, before a cheque is directed, it is our intention to secure a written certificate to the effect that the boat is as represented in the enclosed letter of R. A. Sproule & Son. The Minister's authority has been secured.

J. H. Laget,
accountant & Purchasing Agent.

PORT ARTHUR, ONTARIO

A.B. CONNIE

April 13th, 1923.

MEMORANDUM

Purchasing Commission of Canada.

This Department requires for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School a 40' motor launch. The school is located at Shoal Lake on the Lake of the Woods, about 35 miles southwest of Kenora. The boat is required for the purpose of freighting supplies from Kenora to the school and delivery on or about May 10th, next, is necessary. As funds were not available in our appropriation for the last fiscal year, prices have not yet been obtained.

Our Agent at Kenora has wired that the W. J. Stone Boat Manufacturing Co., Kenora, have a motor launch, 40'x5'9", 21 H.P., 4 cycle "Campbell" engine, nearly completed, which they will have ready for delivery about May 1st, next. Their price is $4,200. This is the same type of boat as was supplied in the spring of 1922 for the use of the Kenora agency, and which was purchased after competitive prices had been obtained, upon authority of your Minute No. 15-2225, of December 12th, 1921. The price quoted at that time was $4,418.70.

As we desire to obtain a boat as early after navigation opens as possible, and so it would greatly delay the work at the school if the boat had to be built after the contract is given, I would recommend that authority be granted for the purchase from the above named firm of the motor launch which they will have ready for delivery the last of May, at the price quoted, viz: $4,200. This boat has been examined by our Agent and the Principal of the school, and would be entirely satisfactory for the purpose for which it is intended. It was upon our request by wire for their lowest price that they quoted the price of $4,200. Our Agent learned from other builders that it would take from 90 to 120 days after receiving contract to complete a boat of the kind required.

I shall be pleased to have your Minute authorizing the purchase of the motor launch from the W. J. Stone Boat Manufacturing Company, Kenora.

Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

To H. Forget, Esq.,

Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

Your communication of April 14th, to Messrs. Ditchburn Boats, Limited of Oraveshurst, has been forwarded to us by them, as we are in a better position to supply your requirements than they are. We regret that in this forwarding some delay has been occasioned, but hope that we shall not be too late.

We take pleasure in enclosing, herewith, descriptions of our File No. 529 - "TORONTO" and File No. 541 - "ROB ROY" either of which we believe would suit your purposes in every respect.

The "TORONTO" you will note, is at Wasaga Beach. We have gone into the question of loading, chocking up and securing, and find that this will cost in the neighbourhood of $126.00. The freight rate to Kenora from Penetang or Wildwood will be $184.00, and the unloading charges at Kenora should be in the neighbourhood of $25.00 and at the outside should not exceed $50.00.

The "ROB ROY" is at Hamilton. The freight rate from Hamilton to Kenora is $184.00 and the loading charges we estimate to be the same as for the "TORONTO".

If it is advisable to have the space for the two tons of freight open, the forward cabin of either of these boats could readily be removed and a light derrick fitted on the fore deck for handling, but if the freight is in small packages convenient for handling, we would advise merely the removal of some of the windows.

April 23rd., 1923...

F. H. Faget Esq.,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

We beg to thank you for your kind inquiry re. Launch for Kenora and in reply would state that we have here in Ottawa a boat that we think will meet your requirements most acceptably. It is the property of Mr. G. E. Faquier, "Ardvar" Rockcliffe, who is anxious to discontinue cruising and be offering his boat at a very low figure, or about one third of its replacement value. Snap is enclosed.

She is a very heavily built V. Bottom boat, 35' long, nearly 9' beam, good freeboard, has a small cabin with wash room and toilet forward, which will comfortably take care of two people. The engine is under a bridge deck to which all controls are lead, leaving a very roomy cockpit aft for passengers or freight. The motive power is a four cylinder STERLING 4-8 H.P. motor, which gives her a cruising speed of 13 miles and an easy maximum of 15 miles, which would be ample power for the worst blows on Lake of the Woods.

She is an exceptionally fine boat in every way, built under Mr. Faquier's supervision for his personal use, regardless of expense, is a very able sea boat and in fact the best buy we have handled in a number of years.

The price is $2750.00, f.o.b. ears, Ottawa.

We shall be pleased to have you inspect this craft.

Awaiting your further commands,

Faithfully yours,

R. A. Sproule & Son.
Memorandum.

Motor Boat "MAY."

An examination of the above Motor Boat shows the following:

The hull and scantlings are of good design and workmanship throughout, no signs of deterioration or wastage are evident, and the outside planking is, to all appearances, sound and watertight.

A trial run was made at 2:30 p.m., on the 24th instant, the engine running fairly smoothly, but calling for certain adjustments and rejointing work.

Arrangements were made with Mr. R.M. Sproule, with regard to the adjusting of the engine and other work, that this be done forthwith and another trial run made at 10 a.m. this morning.

Results of this second trial were very satisfactory, the boat attaining high speed, with the engine running smoothly. Manoeuvring trials were also made, the boat answering promptly to calls for ahead and astern as required.

Certain working parts of the engine were opened up after the run and found to be in very good condition.

The auxiliary services of the boat, lighting, etc., appear to be satisfactory, also the general equipment; a spare propeller is on board.

I am pleased to advise that the general condition of the boat, with regard to both hull and machinery, and also equipment, may be described as good, and that she appears to have been well kept, showing little signs of wear.
With regard to the list of Motor Boats under consideration, No. 1 is eliminated as being unsuitable structurally for your requirements. Nos. 3 and 4 are 10 and 9 years of age respectively, and even if of exceptional construction, it is considered they will have suffered serious wastage, deterioration and wear and tear, due to age. No. 5 Boat is 5 years of age, and upon examination her hull is found to be in every way sound and in good condition, the engine running almost equal to new.

In view of the above, I have no hesitation in recommending No. 5 Boat as the best proposition for purchase, and can safely say that she would be good for many years' useful service with reasonable upkeep and care.

The purchase price of No. 5 Boat, in my opinion, is not unreasonable.

T.C. Phillips,
Engineer Commander, R.C.N.,
Consulting Naval Engineer.

Mr. R.T. Ferrier,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, April 27th, 1923.

Ottawa, April 27th, 1923.

Sir:

As you were informed by our telegram of yesterday's date, we have purchased here a 35' launch for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School. The purchase of this boat was made on the approval of the Public Works Commission of Canada, after a thorough inspection and trial in the water by a consulting naval engineer of the Naval Service.

The boat is a very heavily built V bottom boat, 35' long, nearly 9' beam, good freeboard, has a small cabin with washroom and toilet forward, which will comfortably take care of two people. The engine is under a bridge deck to which all controls are led, leaving a very roomy cockpit aft for passengers or freight. The active power is a four cylinder, 45 H.P., motor, which gives a cruising speed of 15 miles and an easy maximum of 18 miles; she is a very quiet sea boat. The name of the boat is "May", but, if the Principal wishes, he may change this to any name he desires. The price is $2,750 F.O.B. case Ottawa. The boat was built by Meloche, Montreal, and is three years old. It is in perfect running order, and has capacity for at least two tons of freight. We are quite satisfied that this boat will meet the requirements, and will be found satisfactory in all respects for the purpose for which it is required. You will be advised of the date of shipment, which, it is expected, will be in the course of the next few days.

I am returning, under separate cover, the quotations which you received and forwarded under cover of your letter of the 16th of March last. I also forward blue prints of a boat similar in respects to the one which has been obtained for the use of the school. These plans you should hand to the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Motor Launch for Kenora
Attention Mr. Ferrier.

Gentlemen,

I am authorized by Mr. G. E. Faquier of "Arvax" Rockcliffe Park, City, to state that the motorboat "Naze" which you contemplate purchasing built by A. Meloche, Boatbuilder, Berroy Street Montreal, under Mr. Faquier's supervision was launched and brought to Ottawa by him in July, 1920. Thus the boat was in use for a short time in 1920, and the seasons of 1921 and 1922.

With reference to shipment, we have arranged to have this loaded by the C.P.R. at their Sussex Street yard. The equipment of running lights, anchor, cushions, etc., will be carefully packed in the cabin, a list posted in the cabin, and a copy given you. The motor hatches and stair hatch will be securely fastened from inside, then the cabin doors locked and the keys handed to you for delivery to your agent.

Trusting that you will find these arrangements sufficiently attractive to forward us your order and thanking you for the inquiry, we are,

Faithfully yours,

R. A. Sproule & Son.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your telegram re Launch for Cecilia Jeffrey School, and replied as follows:

"J. D. McLean,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Launch can be unloaded and placed in water at Kenora more conveniently and cheaper than at Raney River.

Frank Edwards."

Raney River is quite a long way from here and we would have to go there to get the Launch, but there is every facility here for unloading the boat, as there is a C.P.R. spur that runs down close to the water's edge there is also a firm that makes a speciality of unloading boats.

In addition to this none of the School authorities ever go to Raney River, but use this Port.

Therefore this place is very much better than Raney River to have the launch delivered at.

Yours obediently

Frank Edwards.

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 1, 1923.

Attention Mr. R. E. Sproule

Gentlemen:

I beg to inform you that the Purchasing Commission of Canada have approved of the purchase, from you, of the motor launch "May", which this Department requires for use in connection with one of its Indian residential schools near Kenora, at the price quoted in your letter of April 23rd, last, viz.: $2750, f. o. b. cars Ottawa. This launch has been inspected by a consulting naval engineer of the Department of National Defence, who reports it to be entirely satisfactory for the purposes for which it is required.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to have the boat properly and securely placed on a flat car and shipped, via C. P. R., addressed to Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont. It is expected that this boat will be placed on the car free from any damage, and securely blocked in order to prevent injury in transit. When this has been done, I shall be pleased if you will phone Mr. Ferrier, or this Department, in order that we can notify our agent to accept delivery and make arrangements to have the boat placed in the water on arrival at Kenora.

You should prepare your account in duplicate and forward same to Mr. Edwards who is being requested, upon receipt of the boat, to certify and send the account to the Department so that payment can be made.

We are pleased to receive your letter of the 28th ultimo, giving particulars as to the date the boat was built and the service it has seen since that time. We note the arrangements you have made to have the boat loaded on the car and the protection of the equipment in transit mentioned.

Yours truly,

F. H. Lege,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Messrs. R. A. Sproule & Son,
Beechwood Ave.,
Ottawa, Ont.

10th May, 1923.

Sir,

I have received a letter from Mr. W. J. Coekeen, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School, in which he says:

"Our mail service has been cut off for a few days, and we are waiting for means of transportation to Waugh.

Have the foundation for boathouse laid, but was unable to get the balance of material over the ice.

I asked you in regard to the cost of boathouse, and I believe you assured me that no provision had been made.

I spoke of the matter of the Church making provision for such as I thought it would be unfair to ask the Department for this assistance after what it appeared they were having to do in putting up another $700 over the amount asked for in the Estimates viz; $3500 (Coekeen understands we are getting the boat from Stone at $4200).

I brought this matter before a member of our Committee in Winnipeg and while it was impossible for us to call a meeting I was told to go ahead in the purchase of materials and they would see it was alright.

I received a letter from Toronto calling me to account for my action in the matter since that it is claimed that the Department was making provision for both boathouse and boat. I am asked what assurance I have given the Indian Agent that the Church will pay for the boathouse."

When Mr. Coekeen was here I told him we were getting a boat for the School, and that I thought the Church authorities should pay for a Boathouse.

Have the Department promised to supply material for a boathouse, if so kindly let me know so that I can make the necessary arrangements, as the Principal has already purchased the materials from the Rat Postage Lumber Company, Winnipeg.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, May 17th, 1923.

Sir:

I am to inform you that the motor launch purchased here for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School is being loaded on a flat car, and will likely be forwarded to Kenora, C.P.R. freight, today. You should make the necessary arrangements to have this boat unloaded and placed in the water upon arrival. Care should be taken to see that no damage occurs to the boat in the unloading. Any expense incurred will be paid upon receipt of properly certified vouchers covering the amount. The cost should be kept down to the lowest possible point.

The suggestion has been made that this boat could be more satisfactory for agency purposes, and that the boat which you have been using be transferred to the school. The Principal's office should discuss the relative merits of the boats for the purpose for which they are required, and if you mutually agree to an exchange this Department would offer no objections.

At a later date please inform me what arrangements have been made by yourself and the Principal. A copy of this letter is being sent to Mr. Cookson.

Your obedient servant,

Enc. 1.
Sir:

The Launch shipped from Ottawa has arrived in good condition.

It is not as suitable for the Cecilia School as the one we had built here, owing to the amount of freight the School have to transport, and the Principal very much prefers to have the one we had. I have therefore given him ours, and will keep the one sent from Ottawa.

To make this Launch suitable, we shall have to put a shoe and deadwood on same, lower the floor in the afterpart about 8 or 10 inches, have a light roof built over the boat strong enough to carry a light canoe, install a small generator and wet battery for electric lights and horn, also put in larger tanks for gasoline, and we shall then have a more suitable boat than our old one, and it will not be a credit to the Department.

These alterations will not cost a great deal, and I shall be glad to receive instructions to have these things done at as little expense as possible.

Your obedient servant,

(Spd.) Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent.

October 1, 1925.

Memorandum: Hon. Charles Stewart,

A new electric light system is required at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School on Lake of the Woods, and funds are provided in this year's vote for Indian Education for this purpose.

Owing to the nature of the work it will be advisable to have it carried out by a competent electrical contractor on a proven cost plus 10% basis. Will you please advise me of the name of a reliable firm in Winnipeg to whom this work could be entrusted.

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM

October 12, 1937

Minister's Office

With reference to your memorandum of the 1st instant regarding the installation of a new electric light system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School on Lake of the Woods -

The Schumacher-Gray Company, Limited, Contracting Electrical Engineers, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, may be engaged to carry out this work.

J.E. Featherston.
Ottawa, October 23, 1925.

Sir:

The Department has under consideration the installation of an electric light system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School on Lake of the Woods, Ontario, of which Mr. W.J. Cockson is the Principal.

As it is urgent that arrangements be made to have this work performed with the least possible delay would it be possible that your firm undertake to make an inspection of this building in order to furnish me with a complete proposal together with an estimate of the cost of installing a first class electric light system in this building.

This proposal should include a detailed list of the quantity and make of the material to be supplied including, if possible, a cut showing the style of machinery and the fixtures referred to in your specification. It will be necessary also that separate prices be given for the wiring and fixtures only, and another one for the generating plant, the storage batteries and other accessories. It is desired that the generating plant shall consist of separate units and not be made of one combined engine and generator, it being proposed to install each machine separately and of different make if found advisable.

In case the Department should find your proposal satisfactory it is understood that you will agree to carry out this work on a proven cost plus ten percent basis. The Department does not bind itself to accept any proposal but in the event of no decision being taken at the present time you will be refunded the amount of any reasonable expenses which might be incurred by your firm in the preparation of the above mentioned proposal.

I should also like to know the time which will be required for the completion of this work. Kindly advise me by wire if it is your intention to proceed with this estimate and oblige,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary

The Schumacher-Gray Co., Ltd.,
Contracting Electrical Engineers,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have just had a letter from Rev. A. D. Menzies, the new Principal of Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School, part of which reads as follows:

"A young man came in with us to prepare an estimate for the Government on the cost of a lighting plant for the school. We have gone into the matter very thoroughly and his report will go forward next week. It occurred to me that it might be advisable that you should communicate with the powers that be presenting our plea for this very necessary improvement. I may just state that a calamity was narrowly escaped last night when only the presence of mind and quick action of a member of the staff prevented what would doubtless have been a disastrous fire. The large number of lamps necessary in such a building makes it exceedingly dangerous and the fact that no fire has occurred in the years past does not assure safety for the future."

I am very glad to learn that you are planning to install an electric light plant. Just a few days ago I had a communication from Mrs. Clark of the W.M.S., urging the necessity of something being done along this line. The outcome of a fire at Cecilia Jeffrey, particularly in cold weather, might be disastrous, as there is no place of shelter for miles round.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

JHE/EWS
November 22, 1923.

Dear Doctor Edmison,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the installation of an electric light plant at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

In reply I have to inform you that on October 23rd, we wrote to the Schumacher-Gray Company, Ltd., Contracting Electrical Engineers, Winnipeg, requesting that their firm undertake to make an inspection of the building with as little delay as possible in order to furnish the Department with a complete proposition together with an estimate of the cost of installing a first-class electric light system. Just as soon as their report is received the matter will be given attention.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Electric light plant

The repairs to the hospital at the amount of $400 have been promised through the Agent, and as a competent carpenter will be in residence at the school all winter they should be gone on with.

Electric light in this isolated place is absolutely necessary. We have asked for it before, and a request has been sympathetically received. It cannot be completed too soon. The new Principal, Rev. A.D. Macleod, writes that just after his arrival, what might have been a disastrous fire was narrowly averted by the presence of mind and quick action of a member of staff. Such risks ought not to be taken, and the staff ought not to be subject to this heavy responsibility.

The question of a New School requires early attention or a definite understanding from the Department. The present inaccessible location is unnecessary at this time in the history of Indian work. Our church has agreed with the representatives of the Department that the new school should be built nearer the railway in a more civilized locality. We would like to suggest the Neewatin district, where it would be convenient in order to the many children of pagan Indians from the Lake of the Woods region. The children attending the present school could come down to this new location twice a year more easily than all our supplies can now be taken in from Kenora and Winnipeg.

We are carrying on the work at Cecilia Jeffrey School under many disadvantages, and the frame building owned by us is in constant need of repairs. The matter has been brought to the attention of the Department several times. During the past years we have spent large sums in repairs, and the Department has given us a new launch, but are forced to the conclusion that we cannot carry on much longer in our present quarters. We should have a new school large enough to accommodate at least 125 pupils. There are 70 now in attendance, a large territory still to draw from. In this matter we would urge early action on the part of the Government.

We are ready to carry on the new school with a good staff making it possible for these Indian children, now without any school privileges, to receive an education.

We have had a definite understanding for some years that the next Indian School in the Lake of the Woods district would be for the Presbyterian Church, and will be glad to know that it is to be realized at an early date.
GENERATOR:

Shall consist of a Fairbanks 7½ K.W. Generator
Compound wound 1950 RPM with base, belt tightener, and
pulley. Temperature rise 40°C. Full load continuous operation,
and 50°C. rise at an overload of 25% for two hours. Ambient
40°C. Rheostat to be back connected.
This generator is based on a maximum of 50 watts per lamp.

SWITCHBOARD:

To be 1½ slate mounted on 1½ angle iron, on which
will be mounted a voltmeter, ammeter, voltmeter plug, transfer
switch, reverse current circuit breaker, and will be arranged
for charging battery in parallel and discharging in series.

BATTERY:

To be 160 amp. hour Globelite in sealed glass jars,
and will be mounted on substantial wood racks, which will be
heavily coated with pitch. Battery is guaranteed for four
years, but with careful operation should last eight.

FOUNDATION:

The engine foundation will be 3'6"x7'0"x 4 ft deep
Foundation bolts to be 7/8x16". Generator base to be 25"x40
18 deep, concrete to be 1-2-5 Mix

The above engine is guaranteed by the manufacturer
to consume not more than .0834 Imperial gallons of fuel oil
per horse power hour, but as a matter of fact actually consumes
a great deal less, as low as 50% less in some cases.

In case a Kerosene engine is preferred, we can supply
a Type "Z" Special electric Fairbanks engine, which consumes
.1 Imp. gallons of Kerosene per h.p. hour. This engine has an
extra heavy fly wheel and is supplied with circulation pump.

The reason we specify a type "Y" engine is on account
of its simplicity and economy of operation, and when the guar-
anteed consumption and the difference in price between fuel oil
at 12.50 per gallon and Kerosene at 25.50 per gallon is taken
into consideration, there is much in favor of the type "Y"
engine.
Cecilia Jeffrey School

Staff Dining Room: three chain set and 14" bowl.
Staff Sitting Room: 4 brackets.
Staff Bedrooms: 2 light chain fixtures & shades.

Terrace: No. 1 Ballast 5'x5' Beams
Terrace: 4x43 PAS Receptacles & 4x10 Moonstone shades.

Horse Barn: 4x43 receptacles.
Pavement & All other outlets to be 4x43 PAS Receptacles
Exterior: 10 4x43 Receptacles controlled by two switches.
Banjo House: 24"x16', with loft above.
3 4x43 PAS Receptacles, controlled by two switches.
Large Boat House: 8 4x43 PAS Receptacles controlled by one switch.
Small Boat House: 2 4x43 PAS Receptacles controlled by one switch.

Grounds: 10 lights using 5x431 Benjamin Reflectors controlled by switch in school.

HEAT: To be lit by one 5x431 Benjamin Reflector.

Principal's Residence: To this we are allowing a provisional sum of Seventy-five dollars ($75.00)

FIRE ALARM:
On each floor will be installed a 5000 - 6" Edwards Rooti-gong, and a 52241 Edwards Fire Alarm station.
This station will be operated by 110 volts, direct off Battery and to be wired similar to the lighting system.

All wiring to be done in a first class manner, and to comply with the rules of the Western Canada Fire Underwriters and the Hydro Commission of Ontario.

ENGINE: Engine to be a Canadian Fairbanks Type "Y" Special Electric Crude Oil Engine complete with circulation pump, cooling tank of 45"x30" 522 gauge galvanised iron. Fuel tank exhaust pipe, water pipe, and fuel pipe with all the necessary fittings.

The engine is to be connected to the generator with a 5" Single ply, Oak tensioned rubber belt.
CECILIA JEFFREY INDIAN SCHOOL.

GENERAL: The work covered by this contract, specification and plans comprises an Oil or Gas engine, generator, switchboard battery, lighting system complete with switches, panels, feeder, fixtures and lamps. And fire alarm system complete all ready for operation, in the Main building, residence, bathhouses, barn, outbuildings and grounds.

WIRING:

All wiring to be in #12 B. I. Armoured conductor, where it possible to conceal the wiring, and in conduit where it is not possible to conceal it. All exposed conduit to be run neatly and at right angles or parallel to the building. All switch boxes when exposed to be F.S. Switch conduits. Switches to be flush push type.

EMERGENCY LIGHT:

Over each door leading to the fire escape will be placed an outlet with a red lamp.

CORRIDOR:

All corridor lights to be controlled from the office and from one bedroom on each floor by a system of three and four-way switches.

WALLS:

Walls to be #14 gauge steel with gutter and trim, and #700 Perkins Panel Cutouts. A duplicate supplied.

The lighting plant to the distribution panel will be run for not over 5% drop in voltage.

The feeder wires which are run outside will be #8 Weather Proof, U.B. Wire and a B. which will be supported with three-pin poles furnished and erected by the school.

Dear Sir:

Accompanying this tender please find specifications and plans of design and layout for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School on Lake of the Woods as we would recommend after visiting the institution and considering the requirements as suggested by the principal, and also from our own observations.

The approximate location of outlets are shown on the plans and subject to such alterations as you may see fit.

You will note that we have specified 60 Watt lamps, which we consider the minimum requirement. You will also note that we have recommended a 75K.W. generator which is the minimum size advisable to guarantee satisfactory operation and long life of the equipment, and the same also applies to the storage battery. More troubles are caused by the insufficient size of generator and battery because of the severe overloads that are imposed upon them.

We have recommended a Fairbanks type "Y" engine as being the most efficient and simplest to operate of any engine on the market, and this is brought out by our own experience, and further by the fact that the C.A.R. and C.I.R. have recently bought about eighteen of the same type, after exhaustive tests of various types on the market. The fuel cost per kilowatt hour is very low, being less than two cents in most cases.

We are in position to go ahead with the work as soon as we receive your order, and can carry out the work in an expeditious manner.
Ottawa, Dec. 17, 1923.

I beg to thank you for your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the new lighting system for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, and in reply I beg to say that it is not the intention of the Department to install as many lights or an elaborate system as indicated in your report, and I would ask you to please furnish me with a revised estimate for installing a lighting plant for lighting the main school building only, as it is not the intention to light any of the outside buildings or grounds. It will not be necessary to install lighting fixtures of any kind or switches. All lights in the various rooms should consist of drop lights on cords. A much small generator on a 52 volt system can be utilized. A Fairbanks Morse "J" engine and generator would be satisfactory. The wiring should be in conduit.

I may also add for your information that the future of this building for an Indian Boarding School is rather indefinite and it is possible that it will only be used for three or four years at the most. You will readily see that the Department does not wish to expend any more money than is absolutely necessary on a lighting system.

I would be very pleased to have a revised estimate at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. De Manne,
Acting Deputy Secretary.

Re: Electric wiring Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, Lake of the Woods.

Dear Sir:

We are in receipt of your letter of December 17th, and note that you wish us to revise our estimate of the above school. This quotation covers wiring of the school building, which is to be wired in conduit, with cord drops, complete with lamps. A 32 Volt 5 H.P. generator with 200 amp. hour storage battery, and 6 H.P. type "Z" Fairbanks-Morse engine for the sum of two thousand four hundred and ninety dollars ($2490.00).

In view of the fact that this building is quite large, and there are one hundred and twelve outlets, a 5 H.P. 110 volt plant would prove more satisfactory than the 32 volt as the drop in voltage would be very great at the farthest outlet. This would allow 40 watts per lamp, which would not be any too much. You could possibly cut down on a few of these outlets, but not on many.

The following are specifications of the plant included in the above price.

32 Volt 5 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse type "Z" Standard close cylinder engine with radiator cooling system.
1 - special steel split pulley
1 - 4" enclosed leather belt
1 - 3500 Watt "Fairbanks-Morse" 30-42 Volt 1750 R.P.M. type "TRB" open shunt wound direct current, ball bearing generator, with pulley, base and rheostat.
1 - 16 cell 200 ampere-hour "Globe" glass jar storage battery, assembled and charged ready for use.
1 - type "FSS" switch board.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Ottawa, Jan. 2, 1924.

Memorandum: Mr. Scott.

An electric lighting system is required at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School on the Lake of the Woods and funds are provided in this year's vote for Indian Education for this purpose.

On October 1st, last, a memorandum was addressed to the Minister asking for his approval to have this work carried out by a competent electrical contractor on a proven cost plus ten percent basis. A memorandum was received stating that the Schumacher-Gray Co., Electrical Engineers of Winnipeg, might be engaged to perform this work. This firm was commissioned to make an estimate and sent men to Cecilia Jeffrey School and report to the Department giving an estimate of the cost of installing this plant. A letter was received from them under date of December 6th, in which they stated that they had visited the institution and that the cost of installing an electric lighting plant would be approximately $7,500.

On examining their report I found that the plant that they proposed to install was altogether too elaborate for this school, and I wrote them and asked them to submit an estimate on a much more economical installation, the particulars for which I gave them. A letter has today been received from this firm in which they state that the estimated cost of installing a 110 volt - 6 H.P. lighting plant including all wiring, switch boards, and batteries would cost approximately £2,700.

I consider this estimate fair and reasonable for this work and as economical an installation as could be installed, and I beg to recommend that they be authorized to proceed with this work.

You will note that the Minister's approval has already been obtained.

[Signature]

Architect.
Ottawa, Jan. 6, 1924.

Fairbanks Morse "Type 3" engine and 3-1/2 K.W. generator; the main building only to be wired and the wiring to be in conduit; all lights to be drop lights and no switches.
