Dear Sir:

Yours of January 8th No. 129-3-5, reached me in due time.

The Schumacher Gray Co. has just started the wiring and we going over the plans with their man. I find it very necessary to urge changes that in my judgment are indispensable.

I would withdraw the following lights:

1st 1 from Store Room off Gymnasium, removed.
2nd 3 from Small School Room—seldom used.
1 from Ice House.
3rd 2 from Store Room
1 from Bed Room provided with two by its side.
2 from Halls—only one each necessary.

The above changes remove the lamps.

We require the following increase:

1 at foot of stairs to Girls' Playroom.
additional in large School Room.
Used for all gatherings, is 42 ft long and
has a 15 foot ceiling - 27 feet wide.
in Boys' hall outside Dining Room door - at
foot of one stairway, at head of another.
additional in Office
additional in Seating Room
or more additional in Staff Sitting Room
or more additional in Staff Dining Room.
in smaller pantry
at top of stairs leading from Kitchen to cellar.

This plan places the two lights moved
without adding to wiring, it rather reduces it,
as it takes one line of lights from School Room.
For the larger School Room eight 140/16
in. reflectors are necessary, no otherwise
with a 15 ft ceiling much light would be lost.
The space in Staff Dining and Sitting rooms
is same as older part of general Dining Room
and is allotted only half the lights. These
rooms are used by members of the Staff
for reading, needlework etc., hence need good light.
Guests too are received here and reasonably
good fixtures with two or three lamps add
replace the single drop light proposed.

The Office too is more public, requires a desk fixture & lamp and should have a respectable fixture for another light.

Again it is essential that the lights in the Basement with the exception of those in Shop, Cellar, Bake and Flour rooms be up at the ceiling and protected by Lock Lamp Guards.

I judge you are not unacquainted with the ways of Indian Boys & Girls. They have some curiosity and are not adverse to meddling. Accordingly, the four dormitories also should have lamps at ceiling and properly protected.

It is equally necessary that the Gymnasium and Lavatory, the Laundry, the Girls' Play Room and the four Dormitories be controlled by Lock Switches placed outside these rooms.

It is quite impossible to get anything like satisfactory service from a system that can be tampered with by the children; hence it would be useless to install drop
lights where children work, play or sleep.

Your knowledge of Indian School lighting will command to you all that is asked for above.

I do not know what experience has taught our Indian Department so the plant necessary to carry a given load but I know that 6 K.W. Generators have been installed in no larger buildings than C & D School. I take it you require the contractors to guarantee satisfactory results but there is a great difference between 3½ and 6 K.W.

As one electrician has been at work since Monday and another is expected any day, be good enough to let me hear from you as this above as promptly as possible.

Yours,

C. D. Mungo
Principal

Rev. A.D. Macdonald,
Principal Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Boarding School,
Indian Bay, Man.
Sir,

I have just returned from an inspection trip to Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.

The Principal Rev A.D. Menzies appears to be getting along all right, but the Indians complained he did not visit them at the Reserve. I suggested he do this occasionally and he agreed. It would be a good thing, he is very interested in his work.

His wife apparently does not care for Indians and has very little sympathy with them, and she is not liked by the Staff, but no doubt that after a little time she may get along better.

As regards the Electric lighting, Schumacher-Grays Electrician was at the School, and the engine arrived the day I was there.

Mr Menzies informed me he had written direct to Ottawa re some alterations and additional work required. I went into the matter thoroughly with him and with the Electrician, and on my return called on Inspector Bunn in Winnipeg and we went over the matter together.

A change was required in the position of some of the lights and as there was no additional expense, this was agreed to.

3 or 4 cheap fittings were required in the office, Dining room and sitting room.

Locked lamp guards were required in the play rooms &c., also the lights should be close to the ceiling in several of the rooms to prevent breakages.

Reflectors are required for the lamps in the class rooms.

As all the lights were hanging lamps on cords, it was suggested that locked switches should be put in for the class rooms, gym, lavatory, laundry, boys and girls play rooms and the four dormitories.

The above matters were discussed with Mr Bunn and he considered they were absolutely necessary and told me it would be all right to give orders for the work to be undertaken. I interviewed Mr Schumacher of Schumacher-Gray and he promised the fittings &c. would not cost more than the same fittings used at Elk Horn School, and arranged that he would see Mr Bunn and Mr Bunn would go over the articles and the prices and if correct they could be ordered.

Trusting the above meets with your approval,
I shall be going to the School as soon as the installation is completed and will report further.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
Indian Agent.
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

September 19, 1924.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On July 26th and 28th I visited the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. The institution is situated on a peninsula in Sioux Lake. The postoffice address is Indian Bay, Man., and the express and freight, Waugh, in care of the G.W.R.D., Man. Mr. Macleod is a kindly type, but I was not impressed by his ability as an organizer. His wife has no sympathy for the work and I believe is the actual head of the institution. She is not the proper type for institutional life. She is matron but cannot handle the staff. The outside man, Mr. Gibson, is a splendid chap with children. He is responsible for the small farm, the carpentering and engineering end of the work. They allow a week-end holiday for the pupils that live close to the school. I discouraged this practice.

The main building needed paint, but material was supplied a year ago and the work was about to be undertaken. The building is badly cut up by alterations and is not suitable for purposes of Indian education. The heating system is inadequate - there are three separate units. The lighting plant is working well. The water intake has had to be rebuilt; church funds are being used.

I promised to send a little athletic equipment and to give favourable consideration to requisitions for material for Art. One of the teachers is a splendid artist and some of the pupils are showing excellent progress.

The school purposes changing the balcony to an infirmary and making alterations in the present sick-room. It can be undertaken by day labour, under the supervision of the staff, provided that one skilled carpenter is engaged and the materials allowed. They will really need more than $400 which has been promised, I believe. If the Church would furnish the rest of the money, I believe the Department should allow $600 for this work. I propose to examine the correspondence and write the agent.

[Signature]

[Signature]
Ottawa, Sept. 23, 1924.

Sir:

I wish to refer to my letter of this file number of March 14, 1925, in which the Department offered a grant of $400 towards the cost of certain alterations at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School - such alterations being for the purpose of providing adequate infirmary facilities. The Superintendent of Indian Education reports that approximately $800 will be needed to complete the work that appears to be necessary. Please secure a statement from the Rev. Principal, relative to the willingness of the church authorities or the school management to undertake this work on a day labour basis, provided that the Department give a grant of $600. Mr. Ferrier reports that the work was not in hand, because of the inadequacy of the grant offered by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

CECELIA JEFFREY BOARDING SCHOOL,
INDIAN BAY, MAN.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kemora, Ont.

Dear Capt. Edwards:

You are aware that certain unfortunate events have interfered seriously with the working out of our plans at the school this season. I may mention the loss of a pair of horses, and the complete holding up of outside work until my return from a brief holiday; also my illness and the operation which laid me aside for six or seven weeks. It has consequently been quite impossible to undertake the proposed alterations of the hospital, as shown in the enclosed plan. I appreciate the offer coming from the Department of Indian Affairs, but would suggest that, without prejudice to that offer or the changes it contemplates, we undertake now to prepare the building as it is for the approaching winter, by removing the lath and plaster from the outer walls and ceiling, applying soundfelt or similar material between the studding and finishing with Plaster Board, Beaver Board, or like material. This would, in any event be necessary work should it be deemed advisable to add the Sun Porch next season. Be good enough to ascertain whether the Department would approve of this suggestion, and whether they would be willing to provide for the same proportion of cost as in the larger undertaking.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

I have just had a letter from our Home Mission Convener of Winnipeg Presbytery, part of which reads as follows:

"Presbytery recommends that you approach the Indian Department in regard to the water level on the Lake of the Woods and Shoal Lake. The intake and the outlet from the school is exposed and we expect a good deal of trouble in this connection. If the water is lowered very much more it is going to be a very serious thing for the school.

I would be glad if the Department would look into this without delay.

I hope to be in Ottawa in the course of ten days or two weeks to discuss the requirements of our Indian Work for 1925.

Ottawa, Nov. 26, 1924.

Sir—

I am advised that the intake of the water works supply system of the Cecelia Jeffrey School at Kenora is exposed to damage owing to the gradual lowering of the level of the water of the Lake of the Woods and Shoal Lake.

It is considered that this institution will be greatly affected in case the present conditions are allowed to prevail. Will you please advise me whether your Department is contemplating allowing further changes in the water level of these lakes, and if you are prepared to assume the responsibility of the damage which might result from the above mentioned condition.

Your obedient servant,

Dec. 12th, 1924.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Capt. Edwards:

In accord with your request of recent date I can now give you specific estimates for the proposed overhaul of our Hospital to make it comfortable for the winter. I shall enclose two copies of the plan I have drawn up which I think will explain itself.

We propose to remove lath and plaster from walls and ceiling, place heavy building paper on standing board with fir shiplap, paper again, put on 1 by 2 strapping and finish with Beaver Board and 1½ inch Burlap Mould.

You will note that two walls have to be removed and three walls built, two doors closed and four doors and three windows put in. We will place a complete toilet in the Dispensary. There is none in the Hospital at present.

Securing quotations from several dealers I find we can get the necessary material, F.O.B. Waugh at a total cost of $270.00; skilled work will cost at least $50.00, while all work which the boys can do will be done by them. This makes the entire cost of refitting the Hospital $320.00. We would be pleased should the Department bear three fourths of this cost as proposed for the larger undertaking.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Bay, Man.,

Sir,

Your letter of November 26th to Mr. C. F. Cutlee, of the Department of Public Works, relative to the level of Lake of the Woods, has been referred to the undersigned. As the present low water conditions in the Lake of the Woods watershed have arisen entirely through natural conditions, I do not well see how anyone can be held responsible for any damages which may arise therefrom.

I am informed, however, that the Department of the Interior has recently made an arrangement whereby a large portion of the lake outflow will be shut off during the balance of the present winter, and proper control works installed at the lake outlets. When such work is completed, it is anticipated that a proper regulation of lake levels will then be possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Chairman.

Ottawa, February 3rd, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

Referring to your letter of November 17th, last, relative to the level of the Lake of the Woods and Shoal Lake whereby the intake and outlet from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School is exposed to damage owing to the gradual lowering of the level of the water, I beg to state that we are informed by the Chairman of the Lake of the Woods Control Board that, as the present low water conditions have arisen entirely through natural conditions, no one can be held responsible for any damage that may arise therefrom. I may say, however, that the Department of the Interior has recently made an arrangement whereby a large portion of the lake outflow will be shut off during the balance of the present winter and proper control works installed in the lake outlets. When such work is completed, it is anticipated that a proper regulation of lake levels will then be possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, February 23, 1935.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I am hopeful that funds will be available this year to replace the present inadequate physical equipment of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. I am informed that suitable farm land can be secured west of Haugh. A site on the railway as close to Shoal Lake as possible would place the institution in close touch with its Indian constituency in the summer months and would give an all year round contact with markets, mails, medical services, etc.

If you will arrange to submit a recommendation relative to a suitable farm, I will have the Department Architect select a proper building site.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, March 6, 1926.

Sir:

I should be pleased if you would, at your earliest convenience, make an independent recommendation as to the best locality for a new Cecilia Jeffrey school. Parliament is being asked to vote funds to erect new buildings this year and it is advisable at this date to determine the general locality for the new institution. There are two suggestions before the Department at present - the Waugh line and Keewatin. I should be glad to hear from you in this connection as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Aest. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
March 6, 1925.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have had a confidential letter from Rev. Mr. Freeman, of Winnipeg, Chairman of the local Presbyterian Committee on Indian Work, and he has intimated good and sufficient reasons why the Waugh line may not be the ideal locality for the new Cecilia Jeffrey school. I expect that Dr. Edmison's official recommendation will embody some of the points in Mr. Freeman's letter.

[Signature]

W. Russell V. Ferrier
Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 6th, File No. 129-3-15, I beg to state that either Keewatin or Lenora would make a preferable site for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey School than the Naugh line would be.

In my opinion Naugh would not be an improvement upon the old site, as the same difficulties with a few added would be met with.

Enough children can be obtained from the Shoal Lake and N.W.Angle Bands to fill the present school, and as I understand it the out of the way location is against them in obtaining children from other reserves.

If the new school was built at Keewatin this would be a practical spot for the Indians to travel to by water from the Lake of the Woods reserves, and also by train from the reserves adjoining the railway. Another advantage would be in the matter of being close to medical aid, and also for the matter of easy transport facilities winter and summer.

Possibly some central spot in the Lake of the Woods would meet the wishes of the Indians but the disadvantages of winter travel and transport and difficulties attached thereto with added cost on every thing, make the Keewatin site appear to be the most practicable from a broad point of view.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Frank Edwards
Ottawa, March 14, 1925.

Dear Sir:

Answering your letter of the 7th inst. we take pleasure in quoting you as follows:

| Item          | Price per M. sq. ft. |
|---------------|----------------------|
| Beaver Bd.    | $43.50                |
| Sealofelt     | 46.00                 |

These prices are all F. O. B. Winnipeg and we would have given you an idea of the freight but we cannot locate just how you would get your freight to Indian Bay, but you are probably familiar with the rate from Winnipeg to that point. We might say that all this material will take a fourth class freight rate.

The Beaver Board will weigh approximately 20 pounds to the M. feet, the Sealofelt about the same. The price on the Sealofelt is the same whether for between studdes or in wider sheets to go on the studdes. The standard size of a sheet to put on the face of the studdes is 32" wide not 48". This will just lap on studdes placed on 16" centres. The standard length of Sealofelt sheets would be 6, 9, and 10 feet. The Beaver Board will be in sheets 4 feet wide by 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 feet long.

3/8" Plaster Board is 4 feet wide by 6, 8, 9 and 10 feet long and weighs about 2000 pounds to the M. feet. The price given includes crating for shipment. The 5/16" Plaster Board is 32" wide and the same length of sheets as the other. It weighs about 1700 pounds.

Dear Dr. Scott,-

Re Site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey School

Some time ago Mr. Ferrier asked our Board to suggest a site for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey School. We have discussed this matter very fully and I am now in a position to report that the Presbytery of Winnipeg, our Synod's Committee of Manitoba, the Women's Missionary Society, and our Board of Home Missions and Social Service are all unanimous in recommending a site in the Keewatin district.

We feel that it is very desirable that this new school should be near the water as well as near the Railway. We discussed other sites, for example, the site on the Railway line from Naugh to Winnipeg, but this does not find the approval of our leaders. The exact location would, of course, have to be determined by someone who had knowledge of the whole nearby countryside, but we think that the school should be within a radius of 10 or 20 miles of Keewatin with a good water route to the lake. Such a site would provide all necessary seclusion, easy access to the lake, and alternative occupations which might later be developed. It would be central to the Indian population on the different reserves, would bring the school within easy reach of quick medical service, would materially reduce freight and transportation costs, would give graduates access to a white man's community where they could be absorbed in its life if they wished, and if it were possible to find a location with a good farm surrounding it, would provide instruction in farming as would be suitable in view of the country in which these people live.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

JH/EB
Ottawa, April 25, 1928.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, and I note your recommendation that the new buildings be placed in the general locality of Iesuatin. Mr. Indian Agent Edwards also recommends a site near the main line of railroad, and the advantages of such a situation will not be overlooked. The Department Architect will proceed to Iesuatin in a few weeks, with a view to selecting a site for buildings. In the meantime, I should be grateful if you would have one of your officers call on Mr. Indian Agent Edwards and, in conjunction with him, endeavour to locate a suitable property. I am writing to Mr. Edwards, asking him to cooperate with your representative in this connection. If you will let me know who will act for you, I will send more definite instructions to Mr. Edwards.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General

Dear Mr. Edwards:

I should be pleased if you would keep in mind the Department's intention to erect a new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, on a different site. The church authorities, in addition to yourself, have recommended the general locality of Esewatin. You should acquaint yourself with desirable locations with a good water route to the Lake of the Woods. At a later date, I will send you the name of the church officer who will assist you make a careful study of desirable localities, with a view to a recommendation to the Department. When your recommendation is to hand and a property decided upon, the Department Architect will select the actual building site.

J. D. McLean,

Ottawa, May 4, 1925.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department intends to erect this building as an Indian residential school in the Lac Seul area. The Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada will be associated with us in the management of the new institution. It is hoped that a suitable site may be found on the main line of the C. P. R., south of Lac Seul, and I am writing to instruct you to cooperate with Mr. Orr, the Department architect, who will call on you in the near future. At the present writing, Mr. Orr expects to be in Toronto on or about the 16th instant to confer with you and the Rev. Mr. Thomson, of Winnipeg, with reference to a site near Lac Seul for the new Cecilia Jeffrey building. At that time, he will make arrangements with you to accompany him to the Lac Seul area, for the purpose of selecting a site for the Lac Seul Indian Residential School. In this latter trip, Mr. Orr and you will be accompanied by Dr. estate, of Winnipeg, or his representative, and by a surveyor. Please keep yourself free to assist Mr. Orr in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,

Dear Dr. Scott,

Mr. Freeman has just sent me a copy of the wire he has forwarded to you. This may not be very intelligible to you. After leaving your office the other day I met Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr in the hall. They suggested that I wire Winnipeg and get the name of the Church representative that is to meet with Mr. Edwards and Mr. Orr. From a letter I have today, I find that Rev. E.G.D. Freeman, 50 Hart Ave., Winnipeg, has been selected by the Winnipeg Committee. Mr. Orr had better get in touch with him at once, either by letter or wire. Mr. Freeman seems to be of the opinion that Mr. Orr may find it possible to go out and meet the Local Committee. I am not sure that this will be necessary. These three men ought to be able to select the site and report to the Local Committee and the Department. I hope it may be possible for Dr. Cormie to go with Mr. Freeman to meet with Mr. Edwards and Mr. Orr.

Yours sincerely,

JHE/EWS

[Signature]
Only one window is shown, and all the light and air comes from one side of the ward only.

2. There is only one bathroom shown and it is on the boys' side. With the nurse in her room, there is nothing to prevent access from one ward to the other unless the wards are kept locked.

3. If the nurse uses a bed room across the corridor, she is rather far removed. If she uses the room marked nurse's room for sleeping quarters, she has very little privacy and no place for examining patients or treating them apart from her own room or the wards.

4. There is no provision for isolation in case of emergency. Miss Reid has had more than once cases of erysipelas which she could treat quite well at the school but which should be isolated.

5. We do not feel that either the hospital accommodation or the general storage space are sufficient.

Therefore, we suggest the possibility of moving the whole infirmary and nurse's quarters to a flat built on the top of the chapel. A rough sketch of what might be its main features is enclosed. It would give ample sun room accommodation with the possibility of wheeling beds out direct from the wards. It would give a good dispensary and examining room and an isolation room and lavatory facilities could be provided in each of the large wards. We are not at all opposing the department's policy of removing really sick children from the institution altogether, but we feel that a great deal could be done with suspected T.B. cases and incipient cases if good ward accommodation were provided.

The quarters at present shown used for infirmary could be used to make a pair of fine large store rooms and a passageway to the hospital section. There could be an enlargement of the bathroom shown to make it sufficient for a staff bath room, and the two storage rooms and the bath room across the corridor could be taken out altogether, thus providing 3 large staff bed rooms and a staff sitting room.

Note

# The sketch referred to above was not enclosed. It may be sent on later.
SUGGESTIONS RE MODIFICATIONS IN PLANS PROPOSED FOR THE NEW CECILIA JEFFREY SCHOOL

Recommended by Indian Committee of Winnipeg Presbytery

1. Place near the night toilets in the dormitories wash basins, 4 in the larger dormitories and 2 in the smaller dormitories.

   It would be a great convenience if pupils could wash under supervision of staff member in adjacent bedroom before dressing for the day. In the plans as shown 3/5 of the children have to go down 3 flights of stairs to wash and the other 2/5 have to go down 2 flights.

2. Would it not be an improvement to run a passage on the girls' side in the basement similar to the passage on the boys' side in order to give access to laundry, dairy, bakery and store without having to pass through the kitchen and scullery? On the plans as drawn all soiled clothing, bedding etc., has to be carried through the scullery and kitchen... unless taken by outside entrance.

3. There does not seem to be any storage shown in the plans for potatoes and vegetables. Could an outside and underground store room be constructed that could be entered from the kitchen. Large storage space for vegetables is necessary, for the school will be growing its supply, and if storage could be provided in connection with the building rather than in some outbuilding at a distance, it would be a convenience.

4. It is in our opinion very desirable that an ice house be built alongside the dairy section and that at least two large refrigerator sections be built either in the room marked dairy or elsewhere. Our present cold storage capacity consists of two rooms one 4X9 feet and one 6X9 feet. If the ice house could be placed so as to make it possible to fill the refrigerator pans without having to work outside, it would be advantageous.

5. Could the laundry tubs be placed on the wall between machinery room and laundry near the back end and some windows put in the back wall to provide light?

6. There is a great deal of stair climbing necessary in the building. Most of the staff are women and find it very difficult. Could a small hand operated lift or elevator of some kind be provided for the use of staff members? Capacity for one or two people would be quite sufficient. It might possibly be located in corner of small class-room opening into the corridor. If this is possible at all, it would be very much appreciated.

The Infirmary

Here we are venturing to suggest a radical change. Under the plans proposed certain things appear as difficulties.

1. There is no way of giving proper ventilation to either ward.
50 Hart Ave., Winnipeg,
June 15, 1926

Dear Dr. Edmison,

Enclosed please find a memo re suggested changes in the plans for the new Cecilia Jeafrey School. These have been approved by our Winnipeg Committee and have originated in suggestions made by Mr. Monsiee, Miss Reid, the nurse at the school, and the women on the Winnipeg committee.

I am sending you a copy of the blue prints. Mr. Orr gave me the set, and just in case you did not have a set of your own, I am sending you mine, for you will want to go over these suggestions with Mrs. Clark and the board. Imagine, if you are going to take any official action in urging favorable consideration for our suggestions. If you have a set of your own, please return mine right away. If you have not, I would like to get mine back as soon as you are through with them for I will be needing them when they make a start.

Yours truly,

Sgd. E. G. D. Freeman

The following note was enclosed with Dr. Edmison's letter of November 25, 1925, on file 160-4, which related to Estimates for 1926-27. The item has been noted.

Cecilia Jeffrey, Nan. "Lake of the Woods"

The new school was to have been built 1925 but was delayed owing to selection of site and is now under way for 1926. This School must have dormitory space for at least 125 pupils. Any smaller school would not take care of the pupils available in the Lake of Woods district.
Dear Mr. Jefferies:

I permit me while writing to you re other matters to make enquiry regarding the erection of the new School Building. It is now almost six months since the site was recommended and we have no word of any movement except the survey. I have been hoping that the contract would be let so that clearing might be made and building material placed on the ground while it can be hauled over the ice. If the building is not completed for occupation next fall we will again face the handicap referred to in the enclosed communication, together with the additional disadvantage of having two new schools opened in advance of ours, and recruiting pupils from the same territory.

Were our school ready next fall I see no reason why it could not be practically filled the first year, especially if your Department took the position that, having provided school accommodation for them the Indians must send their children to some school. Now the accommodation is limited and the Indian asks why he should have to send his children while others are not.

We are still hoping to hear that the necessary steps are being taken to make it possible to begin the work of construction in the early springtime.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Bay, Man.,
29/12/1925.
Ottawa, January 4, 1926.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, setting forth the extreme desirability of proceeding with the Cecilia Jeffrey new building in the early spring. There is a little delay in connection with the preparation of a proper description of the new site. This has been caused by inaccuracies in the surveyor's report. I am quite hopeful that it will be straightened out in the immediate future, that a surrender of the property will be secured from the band and clearing can then be proceeded with.

I know that Mr. Orr has the plans well in hand and you may rest assured that every effort will be made to have the building ready for completion next fall.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Perrier,
Dept. of Indian Education.

Rev. A. D. Messier,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School,
Indian Bay, Man.
January 4, 1926.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

A very serious situation will arise if the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School is not ready for completion next fall. As soon as a proper description is made possible, the surrender should be taken immediately and clearing commenced. I wish to urge, also, that tenders for the building be called within the next few weeks, so that the contractor could do considerable of his hauling over the ice or frozen roads. In the summer, his materials could go by water while the road is being made.

[Signature]

[Signature]
Mr. Ferrier writes me that the plans for our new School to be erected near Kivatin are well in hand and that no effort will be spared to have the building ready for occupation next fall. When plans were under consideration last summer we submitted suggestions for some desired changes. No doubt you have gone fully into these and I should be glad to learn what decisions have been reached and what changes made.

Yours,

[Signature]

FRANK EDWARDS
Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I should be grateful if you would decide what accommodation should be provided at the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. For some years, the average attendance has been approximately 70, which is the pupilage allowed. The old building will not accommodate more, and I am unable to state whether they would have had difficulty enrolling a larger number. Dr. Edmonson asks for a building to accommodate 125. Agent Edwards recommends a pupilage of 125 if we are prepared to enforce attendance.

The census shows approximately 64 Protestant children of school age in the Kenora agency and approximately 146 pagan children of school age. No other Protestant Indian residential school draws on this agency for its pupils. It might be possible to secure a few children from the Savanne agency, although there are none listed as either Presbyterian or Methodist.

Inverell Perrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

Warned by the recent disastrous fire I had already begun to make certain changes to make exit from our dormitories somewhat easier and speedier. Below is a rough draft of our upper or 3rd floor. The perpendicular pipes down which the children slide are in the corners of the...
Balcony. To reach these on the 3rd floor it has been necessary to go out through hall and off bedroom, raising window and climbing through. I am replacing the window nearest the Balcony on either side by a door opening outward to a strongly built platform which leads directly to the Balcony & fire escapes. On the second floor the Balcony is reached through a hallway whose doors open outward. We have fire pails, fire hose and portable fire extinguishers on each floor.

Fire drill will of course be practiced.

Yours trs

[Signature]

Menzies

Ottawa, November 17, 1927.

Sir:

Referring to the report of the Inspector of Boilers on his inspection of the boiler at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, it is noted that he makes the following recommendations:

- Washout plugs to be removed and boiler to be washed out.
- Steam Gauge requires new glass face.
- Try Cocks - One more to be fitted where plugged.
- Ash Pit doors broken - If these doors were renewed so they could be closed, better results would be obtained by having clinker door opened with wood fuel, cold draft is now going up through back of grates.

Please take up the suggestions of the Inspector with the Principal, and arrange with him to have the repairs as stated to the boiler carried out. The doors on the ash pit should be renewed. The expense in carrying out the Inspector's recommendation should be kept as low as possible. The Department will pay the cost upon receipt of a voucher, in duplicate, certified by you in the usual manner.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

The time has come when we must look forward to another winter where the question of fuel supply from wood has to be considered. We always have the Indians cut our wood a year ahead of immediate requirements.

If the promised School Building is to be erected during the new current year it would be unwise to cut wood here as the cost of transportation to the new site would be excessive. Wood should be cut rather in the process of clearing at the new site where it would be convenient.

Would you be good enough to inform me of the Department's plans as early as possible as the Indians are clamoring for work.

Yours etc,

A.M. Mcgillivray

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am returning to you, under separate cover, the plans for the proposed Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. Our Council Executive have gone carefully into these, and I would like to express on their behalf our appreciation of the type of school that the Department is proposing to erect. There were one or two features we were especially pleased about, which we wish to mention. One is the separate residence for the principal, another is the location of a chapel for religious gatherings, and the third is the arrangement whereby so much air and light is obtainable for the children. We are delighted with the plans, but one thing we wondered about, and that was if there was sufficient closet space to take care of all the supplies and clothing, which is an inevitable accompaniment of every Indian Residential School. Should there not be sufficient closet space, it would be a great handicap to the staff.

The site for this school was agreed upon, I know, some few years ago. In one or two letters that I have had from the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, he has suggested that it might be better if the site were somewhere in the vicinity of Kenora or Keewatin, and preferably on the lake. I do not know whether the location is such that it satisfies the Department, but when the new school is being erected it should be placed in the most suitable place to meet the needs of the children, and also where there would be sufficient land suitable for cultivation as well as the necessary food for both the children and the animals. I just mention this to you because it is now a new Board under which the direction of this School lies, and we would like to hear if the
February 1st, 1928.

Department and the Agent on the Reserve are fully satisfied as to the location.

I am jealous for Birtle Indian Residential School when I see these fine plans for Cecilia Jeffrey, and think of conditions in Birtle. I know that at the present time the principal, Mr. Currie, never gets a night's rest without having to get up to see that the furnace has not become overheated. He is very fearful of fire, and it is on my mind all the time lest some tragedy occur there. Our Council Executive would beg the Department to include in the estimates presented this year, some provision for the School. It is no credit to either the Department or the Church as it stands.

Again expressing our appreciation of these plans,

Yours sincerely,

(Helen) Helen M. Stannard
Kenora, Ont., July 6, 1928.

TENDER NOTICE.

Sealed tenders addressed to the undersigned and endorsed on the envelope "Tender for Indian Residential School near Katera, Ont., will be received up to noon of the 1st day of October, 1926, for the erection of the above mentioned building.

Plans and specifications may be seen at the Post Offices at Kenora and Dryden, at the Office of the Indian Agent, Kenora, and the Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg, also the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

Each tender must be accompanied by an accepted cheque on a chartered bank of Canada for ten percent of the amount of the tender, payable to the order of the undersigned; (for bonds of the Dominion or any National Railway bonds will also be accepted as security or bonds and cheques if required, make up an odd amount) which amount shall be forfeited if the person or persons tendering decline to enter into a contract when called upon to do so, or fail to complete the work contracted for.

The lowest or any tender not necessarily accepted.

Sept. 11, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School, and an advertisement is appearing in the newspapers in Winnipeg, Kenora, Kenogami and Dryden.

I am sending you, under separate cover, three blue print copies of the plans and specifications, and I would ask you to kindly provide facilities so that contractors wishing to submit a tender may have ample opportunity to examine the plans and specifications. I am also sending you tender forms, which should be supplied to firms wishing to submit a tender.

You will notice on the first page of the specifications that firms tendering are referred to you for the location of the building, and I would ask you to please advise them that it is the intention to erect this building on the Long property on a site near the lake, as indicated to you by the Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs. You should not, however, give them any information as to the distance the site is from Kenora, where gravel can be obtained, or any other materials required, as the specific items needed that firms figuring must visit the site of the proposed building and ascertain for themselves the nature of the soil, etc. You will notice that the tenders close on the 1st Oct., and I would ask you to kindly retain the plans and specifications until further advised.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. Nelson,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Sept. 11, 1928.

Sir,

Tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Temagami, and I am sending you, under separate cover, a mimeographed copy of the plans and specifications, and would ask you to kindly provide facilities so that contractors wishing to examine the plans and specifications may have ample opportunity to do so.

I am also sending you tender forms which should be furnished to firms wishing to submit a tender.

You will notice that the tenders close on the 1st day of October, after which date kindly return the plans and specifications.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. Wilson,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

The Post Master,
Temagami,
Ont.
Sept. 11, 1936.

Sir,

Tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, and I am sending you, under separate cover, a blue print copy of the plans and specifications, and I would ask you to kindly provide facilities so that contractors wishing to examine the plans and specifications may have ample opportunity to do so. I am also sending you tender forms which should be furnished to firms wishing to submit a tender.

You will notice that the tenders close on the 1st of October, after which date kindly return the plans and specifications.

Your obedient servant,

F. D. Miller,
Assistant Deputy M Secretary.

The Post Master,
Kenora, Ont.
Sept. 11, 1928.

Sir,

Tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Ossipee Jeffrey Hall Residential School, near Kinawa, and I am sending you, under separate cover, three large print copies of the plans and specifications, and would ask you to provide facilities so that contractors wishing to examine them may have an opportunity to do so.

I am also sending you tender forms which should be supplied to firms wishing to submit tenders.

You will notice that the tenders close on the last of October, and I would ask you to kindly retain the plans and specifications until further advised.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

John R. Dunn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Mr. R. G. Orr  
Architect Dept. of Indian Affairs  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Just a line to thank you for your courtesy extended to the writer while he was calling on you last Thursday and we would appreciate very much information from you as to who the successful contractor will be to get the Indian School at Kenora. We would appreciate this information as soon as you can get it to us.

Yours very truly,

EMPIRE BRASS MFG. CO. LTD.

Per

G.H. Ivey  
Sec'y and Purchasing Agent

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Oct. 1, 1928.

M. Scott

Tenders have been invited for the building of the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School and an advertisement was placed in the newspapers at Dryden, Kenora, and Winnipeg. The tenders were receivable up to noon of today and the following have been received:

| FRAKE CONSTRUCTION | BRICK VENEER |
|--------------------|-------------|
| Wyndels Construction Company, St. Boniface | $75,990.00 | $90,643.60 |
| J. H. Simmons, Winnipeg, Man. | $76,876.00 | $90,990.00 |
| R. N. Wyatt, Winnipeg | $80,285.00 | $84,342.00 |
| Kelly & Kimberley, Kenora, Ont. | $88,000.00 | $93,500.00 |
| J. McDiarmid Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. | $89,375.00 | $94,500.00 |

All of the above tenderers have submitted with their tender the required deposit security. As the tender of the Wyndels Construction Co. of St. Boniface is the lowest and a fair and reasonable price for the work, I beg to recommend that it be accepted, and the building be finished with brick veneer.

ARCHITECT.

Ottawa, October 2, 1928.

129-3-16

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that the same being necessary, tenders were called for the building of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, at Kenora in the Province of Ontario, and that the following tenders were received:

For Brick Veneer Construction.

Wyndels Construction Co., St. Boniface, Man., $80,845.60

J.H. Simmons, Winnipeg, Man., $80,990.00

R.M. Wyatt, Winnipeg, Man., $84,342.00

Kelly and Kimberley, Kenora, Ont., $93,800.00

J. McDiarmid Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, Man., $94,500.00

The Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs has reported that the lowest of the above tenders, namely, that of Wyndels Construction Company of St. Boniface in the Province of Manitoba, is fair and reasonable, and the undersigned has the honour to recommend that it be accepted pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act. Funds for the purpose are provided for in the vote for Indian Education.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
October 2, 1928.

To accept the tender of Wyndels Construction Co., St. Boniface, Man., amounting to $60,443.60 for building of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School at Kenora, Ont., pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of Section 56 of the Public Works Act. Funds for the purpose are provided for in the vote for Indian Education.

This building is to be of Brick Veneer construction.
Oct 8, 1920.

Sir,

A contract is about to be let for the building of a new Indian Residential School near Kenora, and I would be obliged if you would instruct your Winnipeg Engineer to visit the site of the proposed building and submit a report, with plans, estimates, etc., of a water supply and sewage system for the building.

As the Architect of this Department will be leaving shortly for Kenora to arrange for the exact location of this building, I would ask you to please instruct your Engineer to be there at the same time. A contract is now being awarded and it is the intention to proceed immediately with the erection of this building. I would be glad if you could, therefore, arrange to have your Engineer visit Kenora at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. De Molen,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Ottawa.
MEMORANDUM

Dr. Nugent -

Kindly release all deposit securities received with tenders for the Cecilia Jeffrey school at Kenora except that of the Wyndels Construction Co., St. Boniface, Man.

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, I beg to say that you may now release the Dominion of Canada bonds to the value of $5,200.00 held by you on account of tender of Mr. R.M. Fyatt, as he was not successful in obtaining the contract for the Cecelia Jeffrey Residential School.

Yours truly,

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 5th OCTOBER 1928.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 2nd October, 1928, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that the same being necessary, tenders were called for the building of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, at Kenora in the Province of Ontario, and that the following tenders were received:

For Brick Veneer Construction

Wyndels Construction Co.,
St. Boniface, Man.................. $30,645.60
J.H. Simmons, Winnipeg, Man........... 80,990.00
R.M. Wyatt, Winnipeg, Man............. 84,342.00
Kelly and Kimberley, Kenora, Ont.... 93,500.00
J. McDiarmid Co., Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. 94,500.00

The Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs has reported that the lowest of the above tenders, namely, that of Wyndels Construction Company of St. Boniface in the Province of Manitoba, is fair and reasonable, and the Minister recommends that it be accepted pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act. Funds for the purpose are provided for in the vote for Indian Education.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

The Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Gentlemen:

I have to advise you that your tender of $30,843.60 is accepted for the building of the new Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School at Kenora. You will note that the price accepted is for the finishing of the outside of the building in Fort William red brick.

I am enclosing herewith contract forms in duplicate, which I would ask you to please sign and return to the Department.

The Architect of the Department is arranging to be in Kenora some time next week. You will be advised later as to the exact date, and I would ask you to please make arrangements to be there at that time.

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from Mr. John M. Kelly, Boiler Inspector, of Fort Arthur, Ontario, informing me he has inspected a 36" x 6000 H.R.T. Boiler at the Fort Arthur Shipbuilding Co plant at Fort Arthur, and he understands the boiler is for the new Kenora School.

As regards the boiler, we have received complaints from both the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Schools that the furnaces that take 3 foot wood are very inconvenient, as all wood used in this part of the district is cut in 4 foot lengths and if the fire boxes do not take 4 foot wood, there is much wastage.

Would it not be convenient to get larger fireboxes and so eliminate this wastage?

You no doubt remember the Sioux Lookout School furnace doors have had to be altered.

Mr. Kelly will make his usual inspection of all the school boilers in accordance with Section 57 of Shop, Factory, and Office building Act.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Attention Mr. R. G. Orr,

Dear Sir -

We are particularly interested in the new Indian School which your Department is building at Round Lake, Kenora, and in this connection would like to bring your attention to our TEN/TEST Insulating Building Board, which has many distinct advantages - particularly in the construction of schools.

The importance of the Insulating factor, both from a fuel-saving and comfort point of view, is being appreciated more than ever before, and inasmuch as we can offer a Canadian product with an Insulating value equal to that of cork, plus the structural strength of lumber, we feel that many of the old problems are now solved.

TEN/TEST has been on the market for over fifteen years and has an Insulation value of 7.2 B.T.U's per one inch thick, and is now sold as a plaster base, an outside sheathing and for roof insulation. It is made of ground wood fibres, solidly pressed into large sheets under hydraulic pressure of 3000 pounds per square inch.

In addition to this, it has a coefficient of sound absorption of 435 for standard 7/16" board.

It has a bonding strength on plaster and stucco of 1540 pounds per square foot.

TEN/TEST is made in large sheets from four feet wide by seven feet to sixteen feet long, and from seven sixteenths to two inches thick.

It has been used by various Government Departments, particularly the Department of Marine and Fisheries for building their wireless stations in Hudson's Bay, and by the Department of Railways and Canals, who are now building at Fort Nelson.

Sir,

October 16th./28.

Sir:-

Attention R. Gurney Orr - Architect.

I visited the Cecelia Jeffrey School at Small Lake yesterday, in company with boiler inspector John M. Kelly of Port Arthur and public school inspector Shannan of Kenora; and upon my return to Kenora was informed that Mr. Wyndels, the contractor building the new C.J.S., had had a serious accident at the railway crossing near the site of the new school. His truck was smashed beyond repair and the driver was killed. Mr. Wyndels' timekeeper Mr. MacDonald was badly hurt. There is no blame attached to anyone but the driver of the truck, as it was an accident.

The jury will meet today and will bring in a rider that a man must be placed at the railway crossing while there is a lot of teaming, hauling material during the construction of the school. I presume that the contractor will pay the expense of this.

The town is installing a telephone line to the property, which will cost in the neighborhood of $200. I will see Mr. Wyndels and no doubt he will bear a portion of the cost. I have seen Alderman Link and he informs me that the town is making arrangements to run their power line to the site. As this is absolutely necessary I do not imagine we should have to pay the total cost, but no doubt satisfactory arrangements will be made.

Inspector Hudson and I will visit the work tomorrow as the contractor is running the work and expects to be ready to pour cement tomorrow or the following day.

I will be glad to have you send me a supply of inspectors certificates.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

TENDERS WANTED

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that the undersigned has been appointed to the office of Superintendent of the Indian Affairs Department for the District of British Columbia. The undersigned will be responsible for the administration of the affairs of the Indians in the said district.

The undersigned requests tenders from suitable persons who may be willing to undertake the duties of the office. Tenders should be submitted in writing and delivered to the undersigned at his office located at 123 Main Street, Victoria, British Columbia.

Each tender must be accompanied by an agreement to pay the salary of $500 per month. In addition, the tenderer must agree to provide transportation for the undersigned to and from the office.

The undersigned reserves the right to reject any tender which does not meet the requirements stated herein.

Yours sincerely,

HUNTER C. SCOTT
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th advising me of my appointment as inspector of construction on the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School. The contractors being the "Hydeisle Construction Co. of St. Boniface," and have carefully noted your instructions. I have also received in connection with this "Blueprints and Certificate of Progress Estimates" together with the Blue print Copy of the Plans made Reversed.

I note your remark regarding the number of necessary inspections and in connection with this would say that this is a work of considerable proportions involving an expenditure of over Eight Thousand Dollars and two inspections a week for this work in my opinion will not be found sufficient, even when care is not being spared. There is also the work of the other trades such as plumbers and steam fitters, that frequently require seeing. In view of these conditions I am
no hesitancy in stating that the inspector should practically be on the job the whole of the time.

I will carry out your instructions of furnishing a fortnightly report in detail of the progress of the work.

Awaiting your further advice,

Yours very truly,

October 22nd, '28.

Sir:

Attention Mr. R. Gurney Orr,

I received the plans of the new C.J. School and also the copy of instructions issued to Mr. G. Hudson, inspector.

Referring to the sun parlour, it appears to me that when the school is built the windows will be on the north side. The warm sun comes from the South. Can the windows be placed on the South side without materially affecting the construction. If so I would like to receive instructions for this change, as I consider it very necessary to get the sunlight.

As regards the two storerooms leading from the sewing room it is considered advisable to have the partition left out and to make it into one room so that the entrance could be made direct from the corridor, as well as through the sewing room. This will be a big advantage, as this suggestion was also made at Sioux Lookout. I shall be glad to have instructions to make this change also.

Form No. 219
Sir:

Attention Mr. R. Gurney Orr

As instructed by you I am inspecting the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian school being constructed by the Wyndels Construction Co. of St. Boniface, Man.

This Company has made good progress during the short time that they have been on the work. The excavation has been completed and the concrete all poured for the outside walls. They started to raise the framework this morning.

There are about 40 men on the job as the weather has been extremely favourable for the work. A large quantity of material is now on the ground as will be seen by the first certificate, enclosed herewith, much labour has been done.

My attention was drawn to the fact that sheeting is shown on the passageway between the main building and the chapel. I have instructed the contractor to face this with brick to match the rest of the building.

There is nothing in the contract calling for stone sills in the basement windows. This should be done to match the rest of the building. The blueprints originally sent to me were for the frame building.

The windows of the sun parlour should be on the south side. On the blueprints these are shown on the north.

The partition between the two storerooms next the sewing room should be left out and one large storeroom made instead, as the principal has suggested that this will be a great labour saver.

I have discussed all these matters with the Indian agent, who agrees with me, and I shall be glad to get the necessary instructions to have these alterations made.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Oct. 11, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

With reference to the passage leading from the main building to the chapel, the contractor should finish his in sheeting not brick veneer, as the walls of same are carried on the roof of the kitchen, also stone sills are not required for the basement windows. The sills should be formed in the concrete.

I may authorize the changing of the windows in the sun parlor to the south side of the room, also the Department approves of omitting the partitions between the store rooms next to the sewing room.

With regard to your letter of the 22nd instant referring to the amount of time needed to make proper inspections of the work, I beg to say that in view of the fact that the contractor is making such rapid progress on this work you may make the number of inspections you consider necessary in order to see that the building is erected in accordance with the plans and specifications.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Milne,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Geo. H. Wilson, Esq.,
Inspector of Construction,
Kamloops, Ont.
The following telegram has been received from Mr. Attwood, our District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg, with reference to the new Indian residential school near Kenora, regarding which he was instructed to prepare a report on the water supply and sewage system for this building, in accordance with your instructions of October 3—

"Consider source water supply Kenora Indian school unsatisfactory. Stop. Please advise if Indian Department have analysis and report of water from Ontario authorities that water supply will be approved and when chlorinated. Stop. Advise if outdoor elevated water tank essential and if same to be included in contract for water and sewage systems or with school building contract."

I shall be obliged if you will advise me what is to be done in regard to the water supply.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

ST. BONIFACE, MANITOBA

St. Boniface, Man., Oct. 31, 1928.

R.J.C., Esq.,
Chief Architect
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Industrial School, Kenora, Ont.

Kindly take notice that we intend to build up face brick for the above school in about 10 days and that all sand and water will be heated in order to furnish the same quality of work as if done in the summer months.

As specifications do not call for stone sills for basement windows, we have made provision in our work for same and would suggest that you authorize the use of these sills in order to have all windows alike throughout the building.

For your information, the price of this stone, laid or set in place, will amount to $2.50 per linear foot.

We will also be glad to submit a price for building barn, septic tank, intake and tower, as soon as you will have the plans ready.

We took already this matter up with your Inspector, Mr. Hudson; but in order to have a prompt and definite reply, we are taking the liberty of writing direct to you.

Trusting to hear from you by return mail, we remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

F. Wyndels

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 5th inst., I beg to inform you that I have taken up the matter of brick veneering the new school building with Mr. Wyndale, and that it has been decided to wait until spring to do this work.

For your information I might state that the building is progressing very rapidly. The chapel kitonen and boiler house are all closed in and the main building will be all closed in by the middle of next week.

The largest of the concrete floor is now laid all through the building. The sewers are now all in. At present storm sash are being fitted and building being closed in. The only brick work being done is the brick chimney which is now practically finished.

November 15th.

Sir:

Attention R. Gurney Orr

Enclosed please find second certificate for the Wyndale Construction Company on the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential school.

Weather still keeping extremely favourable, the work has progressed very fast. As you will see by the certificate a great deal of the material is on the job and in place. As reported previously the brick veneering is being laid over until the spring.

The alterations in connection with the sun parlour and the partition in the storeroom have been made. I noted that the roofing paper was not of the material specified and have instructed the Contractor to put on two ply, which will make a satisfactory job. The concrete floors are now all in, and the plumber is well ahead with his work.

The framework is all up and everything will be closed in by tomorrow night. They are now putting the tile on the roof.

My attention was drawn to the fact that the Company was not paying the wages as laid down in the specifications, and notice was posted. The Company has now done this but I am still informed that they are not paying in all cases the scheduled wages. I do not think that this latter comes under my control and am just mentioning this in case that anything may be said.

I might say that the work done to date is in every way entirely satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

November 21st./28.

Sir;-

Enclosed please find diary for the month of October, for Inspector Gordon Hudson inspecting the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential school.

You will note in Departmental letter 129-3-15 of October 16th. last that the Department considered it necessary to inspect the work only twice a week, with the exception of the time during which the concrete was being poured.

I was at the school yesterday with Mr. Hudson and he now informs me that he has received instructions direct from you to make inspections oftener than twice a week, owing to the rapidity of the construction. I shall be glad to have confirmation of this for Mr. Hudson's November account.

You will also note that Mr. Hudson is not charging for his transportation to and from the school. This would cost him, I imagine, at least $2.00 per trip.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
November 26, 1928.

Mr. Duncan G. Scott, F.R.S.C., Lit.D.,
Deputy Superintendent,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs,

RE INDIAN SCHOOL, KENORA

We appreciate your wire of the 23rd re the above and do not wish to appear presumptuous in connection with this matter.

As suggested in your wire we have already pressed this matter very urgently with Messrs. Beairsto of Winnipeg and now understand that we must look to them for compensation with reference to cancellation of present order.

We would like however to know from you if Spencer Boilers were originally specified in connection with the School in question. We ask this question as we have furnished your Department with "firebox boilers" similar to those ordered by Beairsto for Kenora (for the Indian schools at Nuneay and Mahawk as well as two or three Institutions in Western Canada which we understand have given very good service). We therefore are at a loss to understand why your Department would either specify or recommend Spencer Boilers for the Kenora School to the exclusion of other Manufacturers.

If we are not bothering you too much we would like to hear further from you with reference to this subject.

Yours very truly,

E. LEONARD & SONS LIMITED

[Signature]

Ibbotson Leonard.
Kenora, Ont.
November 28th./28.

Sir:

Attention Mr. R. Gurney Orr,

Mr. Marshall, Principal of the Sioux Lookout school, has made several suggestions in connection with the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian school we are now building at Kenora.

When the barn is being built a cement floor should be put in to save the expense of putting this in afterwards.

That transoms be put in over the staff bedrooms as they have no ventilation.

When the blackboards are put in they should be put at the correct height from the floor.

Laundry - A channel 1 inch deep should be made close to the washing machine, the width of the machine and running into the drain, to take off the surplus water.

A drain trap should be put in in the passage in front of the bakery, and also one in the kitchen or scullery. This would be a big convenience in cleaning.

A larger pipe from the hospital as this drains three closets and a bath tub, and is too small to take away the water.

I should be glad to receive your opinion and instructions to enable the alterations to be made before the construction goes too far.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Attention-Mr. R. J. Orr.

Dear Sirs:

We have been working with Wyndel's Construction Company, 654 Alnaeau St., St. Boniface, Man., in connection with the Laundry Machinery for the new Indian School at Kenora.

For some reason apparently our Factory the Guarantee Laundry Machinery Co., Winnipeg, have never been successful in getting an installation in one of your Schools.

We are most anxious to get started with you, and have quoted prices, in this instance that are very favorable, and are prepared to put in the Machinery on a basis whereby it can be thoroughly tried out over a reasonable period of time, so you would know that it will do all we claim it will.

The Guarantee Laundry Machinery Co., are manufacturing Laundry Machinery exclusively, and have in operation many thousands of dollars worth of Machines, all of which are giving absolute satisfaction.

If you have a representative here that could act for you we could show him quite a few installations here in Winnipeg, and he could inquire himself, as to whether they were satisfactory to the users or not.

It seems to me us that it would be a mighty good proposition for the Government to have a business connection at Winnipeg for the reason that any service that was required could be given promptly and at a minimum of expense for travelling etc.
The Guarantee Laundry Machinery Co.

December 3rd./28.

Sir:-

Attention Mr. R. Gurney Orr

Enclosed please find certificate of Wyndels Construction Co. on the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential school.

The weather is still keeping favourable and there is no snow on the ground. All the outside work is finished except the brick veneer. They are now busy lathing. The boilers are now in place, and as soon as heat can be turned on the plastering can be done.

I would like to make a few suggestions, which I have talked over with Mr. Wyndels and the Indian Agent. They are as follows:

In the attic, the chapel and the rear part of the building the ceilings are exposed as there is no building paper mentioned in the specifications. I would suggest that this be put in.

In the Principal's residence, where only plaster is specified on the ceilings, I would recommend that the upper ceiling be covered with one ply of ship lap, building paper and strapping. The Indian Agent suggests that this might do away with the snow and ice gathering on the roof and sliding, as it did at the Sioux Lookout school.

As the ceilings below all the verandahs are exposed through having the grade lower than the actual plans, I would recommend that they be covered with T and V joint. Owing to their height the underpart is very noticeable and this would give them a more finished appearance.

The work is going ahead fast and everything is in good order.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Kenora, Ont.

December 6th./28.

Sir:

While on an inspection trip to the new Cecelia Jeffrey Indian school yesterday it was brought to my attention that it was specified for a fire alarm signal to be placed in the office, and in one room to be designated on each of the other floors.

I have given authority for this to be changed so that the alarm can be rung from a central position in the passage of each floor, instead of in rooms as designated in the specifications. The reason for this is that should a fire occur at night, the office or other rooms might be locked, and this would cause considerable delay in an alarm being given. The alarm signals will be placed fairly high so that the smaller children cannot reach them.

I have also given instructions for them to run an electric light wire down into the basement of the principal's residence, so that an attachment can be connected as there are no lights shown in this basement.

These instructions were issued yesterday without authority as work would have progressed too far to have these changes made, after the proper authority could have been obtained.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,-

I have the honour to submit herewith a report, prepared at the request of the Department of Indian Affairs, covering proposed water supply and sewage disposal systems for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School which is now under construction near Kenora, Ontario.

Alternative water supply systems are submitted for selection although there is no doubt as to which is the better system for service and fire protection. Where a school is very remote, other reasons may govern the selection, but such should not be the case in this instance.

Your obedient servant,

F. B. Patterson,
Assistant Power Development Engineer.
