INTRODUCTION.

The new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, under construction, is located some three miles north-east of the town of Kenora, Ontario. This report outlines alternative water supply systems and a sewage disposal system for the school. Plans and profiles of the proposed works, together with estimates of the cost, are included in this report. The elevations given on the plans and profiles are to an assumed datum. The reference bench mark is elevation 100.00 and is located on a rock outcrop on the east boundary of the property, 250 feet south of the north-east corner.

WATER SUPPLY.

General.

The school is situated some 600 feet from, and 60 feet above Round Lake, which is the proposed source of supply. Round Lake has an area of about 100 acres and is said to be from 60 to 90 feet deep.

The alternative water supply systems are designed to fully supply the domestic demand of over 100 inmates and give limited fire protection. Electric power for operating pumps, etc., will be supplied from the Kenora Municipal System.

The alternative water systems are:

A - Gravity Tank System.
B - Pressure Tank System.

It is anticipated that the water will have to be chlorinated in order to ensure that it will be safe at all times for domestic use. For this reason a Wallace & Tieman vacuum type chlorinator has been included in the
estimates. It will be attached to the suction main and automatically operates when the pump is working.

A GRAVITY TANK SYSTEM

The layout of the proposed gravity system is shown on Plate No. 1, and a profile on Plate No. 2. The intake, which is provided with a standard cast-iron strainer and feet valve, is to be placed in deep water some 250 feet out from the shore. The pump house is located near the foot of the bank and 150 feet from the lake. The force main is some 800 feet in length and leads to an elevated tank situated back of the school. The maximum water level in the tank is 135 feet above the level of the lake and the discharge outlet of the pump is to be placed 14 feet above the suction level.

The pumping equipment recommended for the gravity supply is a Fairbanks Morse, No. 4571, self-acting, typhoon power pump, belted to a five horse power, ball bearing, squirrel cage motor, both mounted on a steel base. The pump has a maximum working pressure of 65 pounds and a capacity of 4167 imperial gallons per hour. For controlling pumping operations, the proposed installation provides for a Cutler Hammer, four-pole, float switch.

The suction and force mains are four-inch pipe. The estimated cost is based on black pipe. If galvanized pipe is desired the difference in cost must be added to the estimates. The force main is to be anchored at the elbows under the pump house and water tower by concrete collars and provided with a check valve above the pump and a relief valve below the water tank near the ground level. The force main is to be provided with six Dart unions, spaced about equal intervals, also a "T" bend with plug, at a convenient point under the water tower, to which may be connected a fire hose connection if desired.
The proposed pump house is a 12' x 14' frame structure covered with galvanized sheet iron and lined with insulite. Details of the pump house and the pump base are shown on Plate No. 7. A stove for heating the pump house has been included in the estimates.

The proposed water tank is to be constructed of wood staves and is to be 11 feet 6 inches in diameter and 16 feet high. The capacity of this tank is 9,100 imperial gallons at a height of two feet below the top. Over the entrance of the force main into the tank, a metal umbrella is to be placed to deflect the force of the water entering the tank. The tank is to be placed on a sixty feet, timber tower with concrete footings. The water tank and force-main riser are to be housed and at the base a house for heating the pipe and tank is to be constructed. Details of the above structures are shown on Plate No. 8. A stove for the house has been included in the estimates.

B - Pressure Tank System.

The location of the pump house, suction and force mains for the proposed pressure tank system would be the same as for the gravity supply except that before reaching the location of the proposed water tank of the gravity system, the force main would lead to a building at the back of the school in which the pressure tank is to be housed. A much greater measure of fire protection is possible with the pressure tank system and consequently the pumping rate has been doubled and the pumping pressure increased from 65 pounds to 100 pounds. As a consequence the suction main must be increased from a four inch pipe to a five inch pipe.

The pumping equipment recommended for this service is two complete units of Fairbanks Morse No. 4372 self-ailing, typhoon power pump mounted on a steel base and
belted to a 7½ h.p. ball-bearing, squirrel-cage motor. These pumps have a maximum working pressure of 100 pounds and a combined capacity of 8,334 imperial gallons per hour. For controlling pumping operations the proposed installation provides for a Cutler Hammer automatic motor-starter, and Cutler Hammer pressure regulator. For general pumping operations only one pump need be used. Consequently this layout has the added advantage of a spare pumping unit which could be utilized in case one pump was shut down for repairs, thus assuring a more reliable service.

A pneumatic pressure tank four feet by sixteen feet is recommended. The proposed range of pressure in the tank is from 50 to 85 pounds and the pressure for domestic service 20 pounds. The air compressor recommended is a Curtis, single-stage compressor, size 3 x 3½, which will be motor driven. The compressor and motor will be mounted on a single base.

The building for housing the pneumatic pressure tanks is to be located back of the chapel and the details of construction are shown on Plate No. 9. The foundations of the building are to be carried down to the same elevation as the school and above ground, the walls are to be of the same brick as used in the construction of the school.

SEWAGE DISPOSAL.

General.

As previously noted, the school is situated 600 feet from and 60 feet above Round lake, the source of the water supply. The school is situated on a sandy hillside with rock outcropping farther back. The drainage, surface and sub-surface of the land surrounding the school is into Round lake. It is therefore necessary to treat the sewage effectively.

The general method of treatment, septic tank and disposal bed, was selected as best suited to give continuous service with a minimum of attention.
Laundry Waste.

The laundry waste is to drain into a sump located as shown on Plate No. 1 from which it will seep, filtering naturally through the sand and gravel subsoil. A six-inch cast-iron soil pipe carries the waste from the school to a manhole marked "B" on Plate No. 1, details of which are shown on Plate No. 4. From this manhole a six-inch glazed pipe is laid for a distance of 76 feet to the laundry sump.

Septic Tank and Syphon Chamber.

The sewage, other than laundry waste, leaves the building through a six-inch cast-iron pipe to a manhole marked "A" on Plate No. 1, thence through a six-inch glazed pipe to the septic tank. As shown on Plate No. 5, the septic tank and syphon are contiguous and are to be constructed of concrete, of $1 : 2 : 4$ mix and finished with a waterproofing coat of $1 : 1$ mortar. To secure protection from frost a double plank roof with a six-inch air space is provided.

The septic tank itself is seven and a half feet wide, seventeen feet long and six feet high at the centre. Two manholes are provided, one at the inlet end and the other over the syphons. The effluent enters the tank through a six-inch cast-iron pipe and by means of a tee connection and a short length of pipe is carried one foot below the sewage line, in order to avoid disturbance of the surface scum.

From the septic tank the sewage flows over the dividing wall to the syphon chamber, two baffle boards carried one foot below the sewage line preventing any undue disturbance.
From the septic chamber the sewage is discharged through two three-inch "Anthes" automatic syphons into a six inch glazed tile pipe connected directly to the headers of the disposal bed.

The soil at the site of the disposal bed is sand interspersed with layers of fine gravel, all excellent material for the bed. The elevation of the tile is shown on Plate No. 5 and the finished surface grade is designed to give an overburden of eighteen inches.

From the header the effluent is distributed over the bed through twenty branches, each 80 feet long, of four-inch field tile laid with open joints. Over these joints a strip of tarpaper is to be placed to prevent sand filtering in and blocking the tile.

Manholes.

The location of the two manholes, as shown on Plate No. 1, provide sufficient access to the system. As shown on Plate No. 4, the manholes are to be constructed of concrete, with the exception of the roof, which is to be made of two thicknesses of two-inch plank. Each manhole has a two-feet-square cast-iron cover.

Manhole "A" at the inlet to the septic tank is provided with an iron screen, see Plate No. 4, in order to prevent any articles, not intended, reaching the septic tank.

Recommendations for Operation.

Though the proposed sewage disposal plant requires less attention than any other approved method of treatment, the following matters must be attended to in order to ensure successful and continuous operation:
(1) In order to assist the setting up of bacterial action a solution of yeast cases, four to a pail of tepid water should be put in the septic tank when the system is first put in operation.

(2) If started up during cold weather plenty of hot water should be flushed into the tank.

(3) Do not allow disinfectants to enter the tank or septic action will be destroyed.

(4) Protect the tank and disposal field by covering over with a foot of damp straw or manure.

(5) No trap must be placed between the ventilating stack in the school and the septic tank. Otherwise the necessary supply of air to the system will be cut off.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
November 30th, 1928.

House of Refuse.

Again it was noted that in both Hospitals were persons who were not sick but for various reasons were unable to look after themselves. So as to do not consider the Hospitals a place in which these people should be kept.

It was the unanimous opinion that the Ontario Government should take into consideration without further delay, the matter of a District Home for old folks.

The Hospitals require all their accommodation for sick persons and unless the Ontario Government takes immediate action in providing for the old folks, they will continue to be at the mercy of the Hospitals which is unfair to both the old folks and the Hospitals.

Foreman of Grand Jury

(signed) Jno. Ie Chamberlain.

Dated at Toronto
this 3rd day of October, 1906.
Indian School

This building is a great asset to Kenora and District, showing the interest the Federal Government is taking in the instruction and education of the original inhabitants of Canada. The school is now being occupied and the children are well provided for.

With such a splendid building having every facility, it is to be much regretted that the contractors have been allowed to make such a poor finish of the basement floors due to there not being proper slopes to the catch basins, allowing water to lay in considerable volume in various parts of the floors, causing an unsanitary condition unless repeatedly swept into the catch basin. This is giving those in charge much anxiety and extra labour. Further these concrete floors have not been finished with a hard surface material and the wet cement is being tracked throughout the buildings.

Police Station

There is urgent need of a proper Police Station for Kenora either by providing a new, large building or an annex to the Fire Hall where the police station now is. There is no proper accommodation for the Chief of Police and the cells in the basement of the Fire Hall are undesirable owing to a sewer close by and no proper ventilation for the prisoners. There is only one toilet for male and female and some necessary work has to be carried out. Further the stairway leading to the cells makes it extremely difficult for the police to handle the situation in extreme cases.

It is imperative that a building of this size should have proper police accommodation.

St. Joseph's Hospital

This building was found to be in splendid condition. The fire escapes and protection throughout the building were of the best, a credit to the Society which enabled this hospital to be built and to the Town of Kenora.

Kenora General Hospital

The new wing is well on the way to completion and every hope is to have it ready for occupation early next spring. This increase in accommodation will be a great asset to both Kenora and District.

Everything was found to be satisfactory in the present hospital and the staff were doing every means to make their patients comfortable.

Ambulance

It is most essential that Kenora should have an ambulance as there is no means of properly conveying patients to and from the hospitals. Therefore, it is to be urged that the Town Authorities make this provision.
To His Honor-

Mr. Justice McIlveen, Justice of the Supreme Court.

May it please Your Honor -

We the Grand Jury, duly summoned at the sitting of the Supreme Court held at the Court House in the Town of Honora, October 1st, 1920, present as follows:

After consideration of indictments brought before us we visited and examined some of the Provincial and Public buildings.

The Court House

Both the exterior and interior of this building was carefully inspected and found to be in excellent condition. The heating apparatus was looked over and found to be satisfactory. The upkeep of the entire building was being well maintained reflecting a credit on the Sheriff and all those in charge.

The Old District Jail

This building has been condemned for various reasons in the past and it was encouraging to all the Grand Jury to feel that this will be the last occasion they will be called upon to inspect this unfit place, as the Ontario Government has approved of erecting an up to date building for the needs of Honora and also better and more sanitary conditions for both male and female prisoners.

In spite of the unsatisfactory state of this old jail, the recent staff have endeavored to keep the place in the best condition possible under the trying circumstances.

The New District Jail

Good progress has been made so far and with all the brick work completed and the roof closing there is nothing to hinder still more rapid progress towards completion. Would urge every effort be maintained to rush forward the work.

It is necessary to point out in connection with the new jail, that the area of ground surrounding it is very limited and there is some desirable land available near by. It would be well to purchase it while the opportunity presents itself.

There is one disappointing feature in connection with this new building, that it is considered too small for future requirements, based on the fact that it only has a total of 28 cells and as the present jail has had to accommodate some 50 prisoners at one time, it is thought that 30 cells are not sufficient.
KENORA, ONT., Oct. 8, 1929.

Capt. P. Edwards,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Kenora, Ont.

The dough mixer has arrived but the Principal was unable to put it in the bake house as the doors were too small, and he has had to cut a new door. This is the only thing that could be done. Accounts will be rendered in due course.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 8th instant enclosing copy of a letter from Mr. J. E. Chamberlain, Foreman of the Grand Jury in the last sitting at Kenora.

The remarks concerning the Indian Residential School have been noted and I thank you for bringing the matter to my attention.

Our Architect on his last visit noticed the condition of the floor in the basement and gave instructions that the defect should be remedied. The Architect is leaving for Kenora again in the course of a few days and I have no doubt that everything will be satisfactorily adjusted.

Yours very truly,

J. H. Ladouceur, Esq.,
Registrar, S.O.O.,
Kenora, Ont.
Oct 15th, 1929.

F. Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent
Kenora, Ont.

The Wyndels Construction Co.
Cecelia Jeffery School Kenora, Ont.

Dear Captain:

We have an account outstanding against the Wyndels Construction Co. for goods supplied for the Cecelia Jeffery School Kenora, Ont.

As you know Mr. Wyndels died some time ago and we have sent the account to Winnipeg but have had no reply from anyone so I am bringing the matter to your attention and would thank you to advise the Indian Department that our account has not been paid and ask them to hold back enough money to pay our account, or see that the estate of the contractor pays our account before they have been paid in full by the government.

Thanking you for this favour.

Yours sincerely,

A.T. Fife & Co.

[Signature]
A. T. FIFE & CO.

Dear Sir:

Re Round Lake School, Kenora, Ont.

I was the subcontractor for painting and glazing inside and outside of the above building. My work has been finished and accepted to the satisfaction of the inspector since last June.

I wish to know the reason why I have not been paid for the balance of $828.95. The specifications mention that the contractors should be paid every month 65% of the work done and the balance a month after the completion of the building.

Will you be kind enough to tell me if the General Contractor, Mr. Windels, has been paid in full. If so I will take the necessary steps to be paid.

Yours very truly,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Lake Winnipeg Inspectorate
Inspector's Office

Winnipeg, 3rd November, 1929

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Enclosed please find the business card of E. L. Bouveron, Contractor for Painting, Decorating and Glazing.

This man claims the sum of $825.96 arrears due him for work done on the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School built at or near Kenora, Ont.

I am enclosing also a memo showing how this amount is made up, settlement is apparently overdue to this man.

As you may know, the General Contractor for the work of erecting the school mentioned was the "Wyndels Construction Co of St. Boniface, Man." Mr Wyndels the operation head of this firm died a few weeks ago quite suddenly, and the result is that the final settlements for this work have been delayed.

Mrs. Wyndels states that there is enough still to be paid for this work, to meet the payments that were left unpaid at time of her husband's death.

I may say that I mentioned this matter to Mr. Guerney-Orr the Departmental Architect when he was in my office on the 26th October, and no doubt he will give the matter attention on his return to his office; he was on his way west, to be absent for several days.

I have written this to satisfy Mr Bouveron that his claim will be given attention in good time.

I have the honor to be,

your obedient servant,

Jno. R. Bunn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
4th Floor, Commercial Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Enclosures.
Nov. 29, 1923.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 11th October, in which you quote a revised price of $2½ per square foot for plain asphalt mastic flooring for the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I beg to say that your offer is accepted, and I would ask you to kindly arrange for the installation of the mastic flooring in the following rooms in the basement of the school, boys' and girls' recreation rooms, boys' and girls' toilets, pupils' dining room, corridors and passages.

It is noted that this work will be done when your equipment is in Kenora in December. I beg to particularly draw your attention to the fact that some of the floors at present are not properly graded to the drains. If possible I would like this condition remedied when you are laying the asphalt mastic flooring, providing that same can be satisfactorily done without disturbing the existing concrete floor.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting, Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Vulcan Asphalt and Supply Co., Ltd.,
2568A Bloor St. W.,
TORONTO, Ont.

Dear Sir,

With reference to Mr. Orr's letter of the 15th instant I got in touch with the Wyndale Construction Company and Bearisto Limited, who installed the boilers, etc., in the new Cedars Valley School. The contractor claims everything was done according to contract. Bearisto Limited claim everything was done according to contract as they were instructed, and that if there is anything wrong in the heating, it appears to them to be due to the boilers not being right kind to supply the necessary heat. In company with Mr. Bearisto I interviewed Mr. Waldron, Manager of Marshall Wells Hardware Company who supplied the boilers, and they informed me the boilers had been changed from those originally called for in the contract, but they believed the boilers to be suitable in every way to supply the necessary heat. At the end of the interview Mr. Jaldin wired to the office in Toronto instructing a Mr. Robinson, their Engineer, to come to Kenora and inspect the boilers and heating arrangement, and Mr. Bearisto promised he would meet him here, so they could go over the whole matter and remedy anything that required it. I am now awaiting a telegram saying when Mr. Robinson will arrive.

As regards the trouble with the intake, the Engineer for the Dominion Water Power Branch has been working on this for some time and has now found another pipe broken. They are getting a new one made and expect to complete the work in the next few days. When these intake pipes were originally installed Mr. Paterson was the Engineer for the Dominion Water Power Branch and he assured me that all pipes were sound and in good condition, and that there was no leak. It is too bad we have had all this trouble, but I consider it was through the negligence of the Dominion Water Branch.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

Replying to your telegram of yesterday's date asking me to advise by wire if Dunham specialties were used at Cecilia Jeffrey School heating. I replied that we used Trane specialties, and that these were satisfactory.

On Wednesday 27th instant, Mr Bearisto, of Bearisto's Limited who did all the plumbing at the School arrived, also the District Manager of the Trane Company who supplied the traps and specialties we met Mr Robinson the Engineer from Toronto who represented the firm who supplied the boilers, and visited the School, everything was thoroughly examined and tested, to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Five pounds pressure was obtained after a few alterations, and Bearisto's Limited are attending to the operating coil in the sewing room that will not heat with 5 lbs of steam, this firm are also repairing some piping that is sprung in the boys playroom, a tail piece broken on pipe in playroom and a tail piece broken in radiator in one of the classrooms.

During the examination it was found that the chimney leaked air and about 10 bricks were set in the chimney that had been overlooked when the building was constructed, these holes naturally prevented the chimney from drawing properly and have now been remedied and the Engineer informed me this morning when I was at the School, that there was a good draft and the building heated well.

On examination of the plans Mr Robinson informed me that the chimney was not as high as called for in our contract, and that it should be another 14 or 15 feet higher, he suggested that the Contractor should build the four feet, and that when he was doing this he should build an addition 10' feet at the Department's expense. This work could only be done in the spring, (I shall be glad to get your instructions as to this). He also suggested that another radiator should be installed in the sewing room, as this is particularly cold.

Mr Robinson informed us that the additional height on the chimney would make a wonderfull difference to the draft.

Providing the above work is done, there can be no objections to the heating of the building.

Mr Robinson promised to forward his report in a few days, on receipt of same it will be sent to you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM:-

To - Mr. C. H. Attwood.

Re:- Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School Water Supply Suction Line.

The writer was instructed on October 28th to proceed to Kenora and determine the source of trouble with the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School water supply suction section pipe line. The line was part of the system described last year and is described in a report by Mr. E. B. Patterson. Work was carried on from October 30th to November 30th, when the suction line was finally put into operation again. Back filling of the trench used for a jacking pit remained to be done at this date.

Pipe Line Installation.

The suction line of 300 feet in length of 5-inch black pipe connected with sleeve couplings was installed in the spring of 1929. A hundred ton hydraulic jack located near the pump house was used to force out this pipe length of length. The leading end fitting was disconnected from the pipe and when jacking was completed a final length of 20 feet of pipe was connected by a swinging joint to the straight line of pipe. The outer end of the movable length was fitted with a foot valve and standard strainer combination which in this case could be raised to the surface for examination.

Condition of Water Supply as Reported and as Observed During Repair Work.

The supply of water pumped had been subject to temporary stoppages which were gradually becoming more frequent. The stoppage in each case had been removed by flushing back for a short time by opening up the by-pass between pressure and suction lines at the pump house. After each flush back for the first few hours of pumping the water was laden with silt which partly blocked taps and stopped closet flushing valves. The supply of water in intermediate periods was clearer than lake water. At various times crabs had stopped operation of check valves and examination of pumps showed crab claws were forced under the valves and continued to reduce pump indefinitely. During the second week in October a stoppage had existed for 24 hours and a diver had examined the screen and joints up to the point of entrance into clay in the river bottom. He had reported the screen and foot valve partly clogged up but joints in good order. However, at this time there was probably no intake in this part of the line.
Tests of the water at various depths showed that while the water was thick with a green, red-like vegetable growth from top to bottom no silt was held in suspension. This vegetable matter is of general occurrence in these lakes for a short period and local health authorities consider it not injurious. Water pumped after clearing of silt was clarified, filtered no doubt in its passage through sandy clay underlying the silt of the lake bottom. This showed again no water was reaching the lime from the intake end in the open lake.

Tests for Pipe Break Location.

Tests were made by compressing a large supply of air in the pressure tank at the school and by allowing this to pass by the pumps. This caused boiling up at two joints at 2 - 30 and 2 - 50 feet from the pump house and little flow back at the regular intake end. These joints were covered by eight and five feet respectively of silt, sandy clay and clay layers. While breaks were known to occur at the two well defined joints other lesser breaks or breaks in heavy clay might have existed and not been shown. It was not practical to plug the pipe to show other breaks.

Well Site at Lake Side.

Following instructions to try for a supply by well to be opened at the lake side, borings were made and tested by pumping. Excavations to provide for connection to suction line and to sink well caisson were carried on. A gravel strata was located below the clay at the lake side and eleven feet below water level. A flow of water was obtained in one of the holes. This water was pumped continuously as the excavation was carried down the pipe line and a flow of 30 gallons per minute was obtained when the excavation was opened up seven feet below water level. Heavy rains had occurred the previous week. Other holes were bored and yielded no flow of water but filled up showing water came from the underlying ground strata. The flow of water from the first test holes decreased, and as it was decided the flow was local drainage and not a dependable supply of lake water infiltration, orders were received to cease work on wells and proceed to replace the outer sections of the pipe line under the lake. Three weeks later tests showed the flow of water reduced to six gallons per minute.

Replacement of Outer Sections of Pipe Line.

Work was commenced on November 12 to cut into the line and prepare for jacking out four lengths of pipe to replace the outer four lengths at the intake end. Pipe was received on the work on November 15th, but delay was caused by the diver who was called upon to disconnect and clear the swinging joint out of line. The pipe was jacked out during the week of November 18th and November 25th the diver was engaged to connect up the outer end with the final length. He reported the line in good order.
and pipe broken off at end of thread so that sleeve coupling only had to be removed as the break had occurred on the length just passed out. An undamaged threaded end of pipe had arrived at the former location of the end of the straight pipe. After the work of fitting the flange the diver was instructed to again examine the next joint of pipe on the straight pipe and he reported it broken on the inside of the joint rendering usable two lengths of pipe. The break was an old one and had been completed by pipe wrench work of turning off coupling and placing flange. Plugging the line was delayed until November 26th when a chlorinator test was made. Three and a half lengths of pipe were salvaged for insertion and jacking out of the line. Finally this section of the line was tested by air pressure and found to be satisfactorily free of breaks. The plugged end was disconnected and the pipe line was flushed out and a new end with a screen connected to it was installed. Regular pumping was resumed on November 30th and a test with both pumps showed the tank at the school could be filled (125 gallons) in nine minutes. It should be noted pipe broke at threaded sections at the edge of the coupling sleeve.

Details of the riser pipe and fittings connected to the straight line terminating 308 feet from the pump house are stated in the order of fitting; a forty five degree bend, a three foot length of pipe, a flange, a thimble, a sleeve coupling and a thimble and flange. The latter fits the foot valve and strainer which was left at the school. A screen large enough to fit over the foot valve and strainer combination was fitted by a collar connection between the outer flange and coupling. The screen is cylindrically shaped and wide in two halves bolted together along the centre line of the pipe. It is 16 inches long and 12 inches wide with copper bronze screen, 13 opening to an inch, soldered over a galvanized iron frame. A special flange fitted length of pipe was inserted in the line at 1 - 07 to 1 - 27 feet from the pump house to connect up the line again when jacking was completed. On November 30th filling in remained to be completed for the section 1 - 00 to 1 - 35 feet from pump house and cover from 0 - 60 to 1 - 35. This is to be partly filled in with clay to cover the pipe and a temporary filling of sand waste is to be placed until earth can be handled in the spring. Hours of work up to November 30th were 22½ hours for the foreman and 77½ hours for common labor.

Auxiliary Pumping.

To provide for the sanitary needs and a measure of fire protection at the school during repair work an Ontario Forestry Department 1½ inch pump was connected to one of the main pumps by about 200 feet of hose and a minimum of the school water supply was secured. Severe tests by air pressure on the system showed no leaks occurred in the pressure line from pump house to school. A major source of waste of water was shown up after this and was due to excessive automatic combination basement closets.
December 6th, 1929.

Sir:

Re Intake to Water Supply, Cecelia Jeffrey Indian School.

Our Mr. J. T. Rose, who was made responsible for repairs to the intake for the water supply to the Cecelia Jeffrey school, reports that this work was completed on November 30th. Following the completion of the repairs the entire water system was thoroughly tested, each pump being operated separately, and the system found to be in perfect working condition.

Upon the occasion of your last visit to Winnipeg I mentioned to you the possibility of securing a water supply from a well with the object of possibly eliminating vegetation and other foreign material in the water. Several tests were first made to ascertain if a sufficient supply could be obtained from a well but the results of the tests showed this would be impossible, therefore the only alternative was to repair the line and utilize the lake water. While making the repairs to the line an exceptionally large and fine copper screen was placed over the intake pipe to eliminate foreign matter in the water.

A copy of the memorandum prepared by Mr. Rose is attached, which outlines the work necessary to effect repairs to the intake.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
District Chief Engineer.

A. G. Orr, Esq.,
Chief Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Mr. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter addressed to
the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada and the bal-
ance due to me re Cecilia Jeffrey School, as you may
be aware, Mr. Wyndels has deceased and I am now Pre-
sident of the Company.

As you can very well understand, Mr. Wyn-
dels, having deceased, it is practically impossible
for the Wyndels Construction Company to get further
credit and we can only pay those amounts on getting
the money due to us from Ottawa. The £2500.00 was
kept from us at Ottawa and we are perfectly satis-
fied that out of that be paid the sum of $100.00 to
the Kenora Electric, $500.00 to the Keewatin Lumber
Company, the sum due to Mr. Fyle of about $100.00,
and $800.00 to Mr. Bouverson, painter at Winnipeg.
Those are all the amounts due there.

The Wyndels Construction Company is satisfied
that you pay these amounts direct up to the amount
mentioned, if you prefer, or that you have a cheque
sent for £2500.00 to their company, care of the Win-
nipeg Trustee Company, 222 Main Street, Winnipeg,
and they would undertake to see that the accounts
are paid at once as soon as the cheque is received.

As President of the Wyndels Construction Com-
pany, I am just as anxious as you are to see these
accounts paid, and if there were any funds available
in our name, I would pay them at once.

Trusting to hear from you, we are,

Yours truly,

THE WYNDELS CONSTRUCTION COMPANY LTD.

Per: [Signature]

M.M. Wyndels
THE WINNIPEG TRUSTEE COMPANY OF CANADA
HEAD OFFICE TRUSTEE BUILDING, 328 MAIN STREET
WINNIPEG, MAN.

WINNIPEG,
MAN.

December 12th 1929.

Mr. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
I.H.O.N.,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:-

Re:- Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.

We are in receipt of your letter of December 10th for which we are very much obliged.

We understand your standpoint. At the same time, the Wyndels Construction Company, on account of the death of Mr. Wyndels, is in a difficult situation as the Bank will not advance any further money to the Company and took all the money available on account of their debts. The Wyndels Construction Company has a certain amount of assets but they are tied up on account of the death of Mr. Wyndels. There is due to them by the Government, on account of the school, £2000.00, and they owe about £1500.00 or £1500.00 to parties having furnished material for the school. They are prepared to pay those parties out of that money.

We enclose you a letter signed by Mrs. Wyndels, President of the Company. It would be perfectly satisfactory that the amount mentioned, amounting to £1600.00, be paid directly if you prefer, and deducted from the amount due to Mrs. Wyndels; or if you have the cheque made to the Wyndels Construction and mailed in our care, we will undertake to see that all those accounts are paid before Mrs. Wyndels uses the money for other purposes.

In regard to the account of a Mr. Wile, hardware dealer at Kenora, the account is very unclear.
and we are writing him today to try to adjust it,
but it will amount to around $100.00.

Mrs. Wyndels is not aware of any other account.

We enclose herewith Mrs. Wyndels' letter and
would appreciate it very much if you would try to have
this matter arranged. We entirely agree with you that
those parties should be paid.

Believe us,

Yours faithfully,

THE WINNIPEG TRUSTEE COMPANY OF CANADA.

Per:

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 17th., 1930.

Dear Sirs,-

With reference to your letter of the 13th ultimo, addressed to Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont., which has been sent to the Department, relative to the balance due The Wyndels Construction Co. Ltd., of St. Boniface, Man., for the erection of a barn in connection with the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, I beg to enclose herewith Department's cheque for the sum of $2,205.15, which is the balance due according to vouchers rendered to the Department. The Department has also received from Mr. Edwards the letter of the 12th ultimo which he received from Mrs. Wyndels, the President of the Company, authorizing the cheque to be sent to you and stating that you would undertake to pay the different firms who have claims against the construction company for material supplied to them. The Department will rely on you to see that this is done in order to close the transaction to the satisfaction of all concerned.

Before making payment to these firms, it would be advisable to obtain detailed invoices in duplicate showing their claims, and when payment is made, have them receipted, and furnish the Department with a copy of each.

It is observed that The Wyndels Construction Company Ltd., claim the sum of $245.45 to be due them in connection with the water supply system, as per their letter of the 20th June last addressed to Mr. R.G.Orr, Architect, of this Department. On looking over the vouchers received from the Director of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, the only reduction that appears to be made from the accounts rendered is an item of $124.45 covered by credit note from the Crane Ltd., of Winnipeg, for goods returned, and this reduction would appear to be in order. I would advise you to

The Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada,
P.O. Box 638,
Winnipeg, Man.
Mr. C.H. Yours truly,

F.H. Page

Department of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School-Kenora, Ont.

With reference to the above school, which we completed during the course of 1929, we would ask you to kindly have final cheque issued covering balance due on the New Barn and also the outstanding balance due on the Water Works due us by the Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service in connection with this building.

As the estate of the Wynnels Construction Co., Ltd is now in the hands of the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada, Winnipeg, and as there are still some accounts to be paid for material, viz.: the Kewatin Lumber Company, Kenora; the Kenora Electric Co. of Kenora, and A.T. Pife of the same locality, we would greatly appreciate receiving the final remittance for this building; this will enable us to square off all the above accounts in full immediately upon receipt of your settlement.

We thank you very much in anticipation for your kind and prompt attention to our request and will be very much pleased to hear from you by return mail. Wishing you the compliments of the season, we remain

Yours very truly,

WYNDELS CONSTRUCTION CO., LTD

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re:- Your file 129-3-15.

Your letter of January 17th received for which we are very much obliged.

We will at once get this matter in shape and your cheque will not be used until everything is ready to be completed. It will take a few days because one of the furnishers, being the Acme Sash & Door of St. Boniface, mixed their account with some other accounts for other buildings erected by the Wyndels Construction Company; however we will have no trouble in getting them to give us a voucher releasing entirely the Department of the Indian Affairs.

As soon as this matter is settled, we will turn over the vouchers to you.

Yours faithfully,

THE WINNIPEG TRUSTEE COMPANY OF CANADA.

Sir:

Attention Mr. F. H. Paget,
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

Re:- Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd., account for Installation of Water and Sewerage Systems for Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School - Kenora.

In connection with the settlement of the accounts for the installation of the water and sewerage systems in this school, the Winnipeg Trustee Company of Canada, acting as trustees for the Wyndels Estate, has recently asked me, as per the suggestion in your letter to them of January 17th, to check up on this account in connection with the sum of $245.48 that the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd., claim is due them.

I have no record of the amounts paid to the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. direct from your office and cannot check the account of monies received by the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. without checking their ledgers, which are not in the City at present, or receiving from you a statement of sums paid on account. In preparing our statement of account forwarded to you through the Director of Water Power and Reclamation Service, dated June 24th, 1929, we accepted a letter from the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. dated June 22nd, 1929, wherein they acknowledge payment of amounts as follows:-

| Date   | Cheque No. | Amount     |
|--------|------------|------------|
| April 29 | 429        | $1801.04   |
| May 25  | 856        | 1819.46    |
|         | 859        | 357.37     |
| June 4  | 1058       | 1251.40    |
|         | 1277       | 2191.80    |

This letter was enclosed with our statement of June 24, 1929.

Based upon the above our statement submitted on June 24th shows a balance due the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. of $245.48.

Reference to the contract with the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. will show that the Contractor had nothing whatever to do with the purchase of machinery, piping or equipment. All this material was purchased direct by this office and the invoices were sent to you.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
for payment direct to the firms supplying the goods. Under the circumstances, therefore, any credit from accounts with Cranes Limited was no part of the contract with the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd.

Our accountant, Mr. Greenwood, made inquiries at Cranes Limited this morning and found upon examining their ledger that the Department of Indian Affairs still owed Cranes Limited the sum of $44.57 for goods and freight charges as of April 15th, and further your Department had a credit on the ledger of $124.45, or at the moment a credit balance of $79.88. The accountant for Cranes Limited wanted to issue a cheque in favor of the Department for $79.88, but he was asked to let the matter stand until it was referred to you.

It seems to me, therefore, if the payments referred to above are correct, that the Department owes the Wyndels Construction Company, Ltd. $245.48. In order to close the account it would appear that the Department should issue a cheque for this sum - $245.48 - and clear up the account with Cranes Limited.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

District Chief Engineer.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re the Water Disposal Tank from the Laundry.

I wish to inform you that we used this tank about two months only when it filled and flooded the furnace-room.

We pumped it out but it has filled again.

Something should be done to remedy this condition. There is no grease-trap in the system and where so much soapy water is going through it appears to me that a trap is very necessary.

I hope something can be done to remedy matters.

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

$50 to $60.
January 27th, 1930

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Byers, Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School has handed me a letter written to you on January 17th re the heating system at the school, and asks for authority to purchase and install a condensation pump and compressor, at a cost of $5/600, which he claims would solve the heating problem. I have seen Bearisto and the Campbell Heating Company and this appears as the only solution, as the Engineers say the boilers are alright.

Mr. Byers has also written you in connection with the highway between the School and the Town of Kenora. The road is in very bad shape and I understand was originally built by the Provincial Government as the Municipality of Jaffray and Melick had no funds. They are in the same state now, and the only way to get the road done is through either the Provincial or Dominion Governments. Mr. Byers informed me this morning that Mr. Lyons, District Engineer for the Northern Development Company, informed him that the Province would pay 50% of the work if the Department or the Dominion Government would pay the other 50%. I do not like to recommend this matter myself as I don't look as though I was working positively in connection with it, but there is no question that something should be done so as to make the road better. The Municipality promised to surface the road and maintain it. I shall be glad to hear further from you in this connection.

I enclose letter received from the Principal re water disposal tank from the laundry which explains itself. Apparently there was no grease trap put in the system and it stands to reason where soapy water from the laundry goes into the tank, there is a coating of grease which stops all outlets. Mr. Byers informs me this could be put in for $50/60.

I would have written you in connection with these matters before but have been away for ten days inspecting the schools along the National Railway and also in connection with timber operations on the Lac Seul Reserve.

Your obedient servant, [signature]

[Stamp: JAN 30 1930]
January 27th, 1930

Office of Indian Affairs, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Byers, Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School has handed me a letter written to you on January 17th re the heating system at the school, and asks for authority to purchase and install a condensation pump and compressor, at a cost of $5,600, which he claims would solve the heating problem. I have seen Bearisto and the Campbell Heating Company and this appears as the only solution, as the Engineers say the boilers are alright.

Mr. Byers has also written you in connection with the highway between the School and the Town of Kenora. The road is in very bad shape and I understand was originally built by the Provincial Government as the Municipality of Jeffrey and Hallock had no funds. They are in the same state now and the only way to get the road done is through either the Provincial or Dominion Governments. Mr. Byers informed me this morning that Mr. Lyons, District Engineer for the Northern Development Company, informed him that the Province would pay 50% of the work if the Department or the Dominion Government would pay the other 50%. I understand the total cost would amount to $67,000. I do not like to recommend this matter myself as it might look as though I were working politics in connection with it, but there is no question that something should be done so as to make the road better. The Municipality promised to surface the road and maintain it. I shall be glad to hear further from you in this connection.

I enclose letter received from the Principal re water disposal tank from the laundry which explains itself. Apparently there was no grease trap put in the system and it stands to reason where soapy water from the laundry goes into the tank, there is a coating of grease which stops all outlets. Mr. Byers informs me this could be put in for $50/60.

I would have written you in connection with these matters before but have been away for ten days inspecting the schools along the National Railway and also in connection with timber operations on the Lac Seul Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Library and Archives Canada / Bibliothèque et Archives Canada
www.collectionscanada.gc.ca
Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from Mr. H.C. Lindsten, Inspector for Wallace & Tiernan Limited, in reference to the chlorine equipment at the new Cecelia Jeffrey School. Whilst I was out of town the Principal had some trouble with this equipment and so Mr. Lindsten to inspect same for him. I met Mr. Lindsten here, went to the school with him and asked him to give me a report which is enclosed. You will note the inspector reports some work will have to be done when checking over the chlorinator before it can be put into operation again. The Provincial Health Officer recommended that the drain line from the auxiliary injector be run into a special sewer. The Inspector suggests that the operator put an auxiliary injector hose line into the tiled sewer. It is difficult to make out from Mr. Linksten's letter as to who is entirely responsible for the trouble, but he is taking up the matter with the Canadian Industries Limited in regard to the cylinder leaking, and will endeavor to have the matter put in good shape and allot the cost to whoever is responsible, but apparently we shall have to pay part of this.

I shall be glad if you will give me the necessary authority to do anything that may be required.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, February 11th., 1930.

Dear Sirs,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing receipted invoices in duplicate from the various firms mentioned therein in connection with the settlement of the indebtedness of the Wyndale Construction Company for work done at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, at Kenora, Ont. As you may require these invoices for your own records, the duplicate copy is herewith returned, and we will hold the original on file here.

With regard to the balance of $245.48 claimed by the Wyndale Construction Company, I beg to state that we have been able to adjust this matter, and I herewith enclose the Department's cheque for that amount in favor of the company.

Ottawa, February 11th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 7th instant, your file No. 14525-M relative to the Wyndels Construction Company Ltd., account for installation of water and sewage systems for Cecelia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, I beg to state that the accounts have now been put in proper shape to make a final settlement of this claim, and a cheque for $245.45 in favor of the Wyndels Construction Company Ltd., is being sent to the Winnipeg Trustee Company Ltd., Winnipeg. A cheque for $44.57 has also been sent to the Gysin Limited of Winnipeg, in payment of their claim for goods and freight, and they have been requested to forward to the Department their cheque for $124.45 to cover the credit which the Department has on their ledger.

I thank you for assisting the Department in closing this transaction.

Yours truly,

P.H. Paget
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent

re voucher # 4927 for $502.87 in favour of Messrs Kelly and Kimberley, for labour and materials used in repairing the water intake at the new Scill Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

PHYSICIAN AND SURGEON
KENORA ONTARIO

The tank began to fill after drainage
the water bubbles & looks muck, causing doubt
the sediment left in the tank, hence the
reason for the excess amount of sediment
from the taps just after the pumps have
been started.

All the tanks throughout this district
carry a considerable amount of sediment
& vegetable matter, varying with the season.
This sediment cannot be drained off by
emptying the tank at the school. An opening
should be made wide the tanks so that I
could be washed out frequently.

I would also advise that the pipe between
the pump head & intake be examined inside
the mouth of the intake is clogged & it is
not likely the sand got in there, but through
some joint between the pump head & the
mouth of the intake.

Yours respectfully,

A. D. Ferguson
Kenora, March 13th, 1930.

Catt. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora.

Dear Sir,

As requested I visited the Ceiba Offspring School and made an examination of their water supply and would like to make some comments on the same.

The day before my visit to the school I telephoned them and asked them to fill the bath tub full of water and let it stand until my visit next morning. When I examined this water next morning I found that it was of a yellow color and smelled like swamp water and tasted like swamp water. In fact it had very many of the characteristics that water has in a creek that flows through a swamp. I am the bottom of the ditch
Dr. A.D. Ferguson
Physician and Surgeon
Kenora, Ontario

There was a considerable amount of sand.

After observing these things in Byers & I examined the Compassion Park in the building and then went down to the lake to examine the Intake & also the land surrounding the shore. The Intake is about 116 feet from the shore. The mouth of the Intake is secured & is elevated a number of feet above the bottom of the lake.

The yellow color, swampy taste and smell of this water is explained when you visit the lake and look at the height of the land above the Intake. All along the shore on both sides of the Intake the land is marshy. At the northwest corner of the lake a creek empties into it not more than 150 yards from the Intake. This creek drains a swamp & at the mouth of this creek there are a great many old stumps, clay rank growths.

The swampy nature of the land near the intake explains the color, odor & taste of the water. Before this can be much improvement...
DR. A. D. FERGUSON
PHYSICIAN AND SURGEON
KENORA, ONTARIO

The condition of the land near the intake well
have to be improved, also the level in the
vicinity of the well will have to be raised
up. The intake pipe should be extended until
25' of water is reached because at present
the water between the intake & shore will
get too warm in summer & will be full
of weeds.

I am satisfied that there is a great
amount of sediment in the suspension
tank & that the sand in the bath tub
comes from there. Mr. Byers tells me that
they have cleaned this tank frequently,
& that when they start the pump again
after cleaning & then turn on the taps
in the building the first water that comes
away is full of sediment & is practically
black.

The tank carries 70 lbs. pressure so there's
a sediment that has accumulated in the
tanks to cause. Drawing the tank will
not remove this. When the pumps are started

March 10th, 1930.

Sir:

A letter was recently received from Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, enclosing a report on the chlorinating plant at the Cecelia Jeffrey School. Mr. H. C. Lindsten, Inspector for Wallace and Tiernan, the firm that installed the plant. In his letter Captain Edwards stated this report had been forwarded to you but had been returned with the request that he communicate with Mr. Attwood and be guided by his instructions. Mr. Attwood has requested the undersigned to investigate the conditions at the school and report direct to you.

I arranged for Mr. Lindsten to call at the office and his attitude was that his firm desired above all things to have your Department thoroughly satisfied with the chlorinator. However, he was unable to furnish much further information as to the damage done, or upon whom the responsibility rested for the accident which occurred in January. The undersigned accompanied by Captain Edwards made an inspection of the school last week. Unfortunately Mr. Byers was away in Winnipeg, but we were accompanied by the man responsible for the pumping, electrical and other equipment.

The chlorinating plant at the Cecelia Jeffrey school was installed under the personal direction of Mr. B. D. Ingles of Wallace and Tiernan Limited, all suggestions made by him were carried out and his final report to his firm was that the installation was complete, in order, and satisfactory in every respect. The chlorine cylinders were purchased through Wallace and Tiernan Limited. In his report Mr. Lindsten states that last November he put the hose that runs from the injector into the well and thence into the tile drain, thinking this line might be blocked, but told the operator to replace the severed hose. Had Mr. Lindsten had Mr. Ingles' installation report with him he would have known that the drainage from the injector was quite in order and no further drainage necessary. I might say this hose has not yet been replaced.

The operator states he shut off the chlorinator, so it was not in operation the night the damage resulted. Accordingly as Mr. Lindsten points out it is fairly evident that the cylinder was defective, the safety fusible metal plug was eaten through permitting an immense volume of chlorine gas to escape into the pump house. This pump house is practically

R. G. Orr, Esq.,
Architect, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
air tight and the density of the chlorine gas became so great as to cause damage to everything within the pump house; the beaver board lining even is rendered almost useless. The chlorinator was rendered useless but the damage to the pumps, motors and electrical switches and controls has not as yet rendered them unserviceable, although new parts were required. The paint was eaten off the piping and the pumps, nuts, bolts and the metal everywhere is rusting and eroding; the electric switches, especially copper connections, plugs, etc., are badly eaten away by the action of the chlorine and this action is probably continuing. The 7½ h.p. motors do not appear much damaged, but undoubtedly the insulation was affected and damage caused to the windings, making it only a matter of time until rewinding and overhauling will be necessary.

I would suggest therefore that the pumps and piping be thoroughly surface cleaned, scraped and painted to stop rusting. The electric switches, controls and fittings will require a thorough cleaning, replacement of badly damaged parts, and this work should be done by an electric firm. For the present the motors do not require rewinding or overhauling but an electrician should clean them up. I have already instructed Mr. Windsten to get in touch with Captain Edwards and have the chlorinator put into first class condition in every respect, the question of responsibility for the cost of same to be determined later. In my opinion the Department of Indian Affairs will have to pay for work to be done on all equipment other than the chlorinator. The chlorinator should be put in first class working order and a new chlorine cylinder supplied, this being the responsibility of Wallace and Tierman Limited, and Wallace and Tierman Limited can make their own adjustments with Canadian Industries Limited. Of course it is no secret that Mr. Byers does not favor chlorination of the water supply and it is evident that the chlorinating plant has seldom been in operation and that when operated the operation of the same has not been in competent hands. In such circumstances anything might happen and the responsibility rests with the school authorities.

Captain Edwards and I also made enquiries concerning the quality of the water supply inasmuch as Mr. Byers on the day previous had reported to Captain Edwards that the water was dirty and smelled so bad that even the cattle would not drink it. Examination of water from the taps did show a little rust in the hot water when first turned, but otherwise the water was clear, odorless and pleasant to the taste. The operator stated that only when the pumping system failed did they experience the bad odor from the water after the pumping was resumed. Three or four interruptions in the pumping had occurred since Christmas, once when the chlorinator failed, once when a check valve was jammed and once when the belt failed. These shutdowns were only discovered hours late, when the pressure tank became practically empty and the water ceased to circulate. The water usually from the small lake is admittedly not good, as there is no outflow this winter, the water is stagnant, full of decaying vegetation, etc. Such water left for hours in pipes in a heated building accounts for the odor experienced after resuming pumping operations. This trouble would be entirely eliminated were the proper attention being given to the pumping equipment for the operator stated that only upon such occasions was the supply unsatisfactory and then only unsatisfactory as to quality.
It was also learned that trouble is being experienced with the laundry sump not draining away rapidly enough to care for the inflow from the laundry. Accordingly it is necessary at times to pump the excess water out of the school by means of a pump and hose. When constructed it was feared that the soap from the laundry would soon clog the sand at the bottom of the sump so a manhole was provided with the expectation that when trouble was experienced with slow drainage a man could with a pole stir up the sand and facilitate drainage. However, clogging would eventually occur anyway and as no other method of disposing of the laundry water is possible it is now recommended that a grease trap be installed between the laundry and the sump, readily accessible for cleaning; the installation to be made soon as weather conditions permit.

During the course of my inspection with Captain Edwards we noticed that the pumps required repacking, the air compressor motor in the tank room was in a very dirty condition, there were fire hazards in the boiler room and the interior of the building was not receiving proper attention. Your Department has gone to great expense in equipping this school with modern conveniences. The installations made for providing these conveniences have in every instance been made as simple as possible, but for efficient and continuous service proper attention is essential. In my opinion the services supplied at the Cecelia Jeffrey school are not fully appreciated by the Principal, the operation of the chlorinating water supply and heating systems instead of being entrusted to a competent and qualified operator are being inadequately looked after by the chief farm hand. Under these circumstances full advantage cannot be taken of the conveniences supplied, damage to equipment will result, and complaints will be frequent.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant District Chief Engineer.

27th March 1930

R. G. Orr, Esq., F.R.I.C.A.
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building, Ottawa.

RE: CECILIA JEFFREY INDIAN SCHOOL, KENORA, ONT.

Dear Sir:

I have been desired by the Vulcan Asphalt Company, whom I am representing in this district, to place the following suggestions before you with regard to the drainage of floors in the above building.

Our Winnipeg engineer reports that the existing floor of the room shown in the attached plan is not level, and that the floor is high in the centre and he finds that it will be impossible to grade this big room at any reasonable cost, and also reports that he is afraid the job would not be satisfactory when it is done and would look out of balance.

He therefore suggests that one or two drains should be put in to either the scullery or the shower room, and the room graded to each new drain independently. The attached plan shows two proposed drains.

I understand that this applies to the rooms on both sides of the building.

Would you kindly advise us what you would wish done in this matter.

The Vulcan Asphalt Company also say that Mr. Byers, the principal, would like the two shower rooms, bakery, dairy, pantry and scullery done at the same time, in order to bring these rooms to the same level as the corridor, which is being floored in mastic.

The area of the additional rooms is 1754 square feet, and same price 21½ cents per square foot would apply.

Please advise if you wish this done.

Yours very truly,

(F.H. Emra)

As Representative of the Vulcan Asphalt Company.
Kenora,
Ontario,
March 31st, 1930

Dear Sir,

In further reference to my letter of March 13th, 1930 re Report from Dr. Ferguson the Medical Officer in Kenora on the Water supply at the C.J. School here.

He has now received a Bacteriological Report from the laboratories of the department of health at Fort William.

This report says the examination failed to show Colon Bacilli in all portions tested therefore the water is good.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
April 8, 1920.

Sir,

With reference to the flooring in the dining room of the Cecilia Jeffrey School the Department does not consider it necessary to install the additional drain. In fact there is no real need of a floor drain in this room, as it is not necessary for the Principal to use a hose for mopping the floor. I would ask you therefore to lay the regular floor as originally intended.

You may also lay the mastic flooring in the two showers, bakery, dairy, laundry and scullery as requested by the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

As T. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

April 4th, 1930

Dear Sir,

Referring to report of Mr. D.B. Gow, Assistant District Chief Engineer for Dominion Water Power Branch, of 10th March.

He says that in reference to the Pump house at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, that Pump and Piping should be thoroughly cleaned, scraped, and painted, to prevent rusting. The Chlorinator Gas has destroyed the lining of the Pump House, and this would have to be relined with Ten Rest.

The Electric Switches, Controls, and Fittings will require a thorough cleaning, replacement of badly damaged parts, etc., and this work should be done by an Electrical Firm.

For the present, the Motors do not require rewinding or overhauling, but should be cleaned up by an Electrician.

The responsibility of payment for all this work to be determined later, but in Mr. Gow's opinion the Department would have to pay for work to be done on all equipment other than the Chlorinator.

It is also recommended that a Grease Trap be put in between the Laundry and the Sump, readily accessible for cleaning, installation to be made as soon as possible and as the weather will permit.

If this work is approved by the Department, I will be obliged if you will send me the authority to have the work done.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy & Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Principal did request the Pantry also to be done, an area of about 106 square feet. Kindly state if this was overlooked when making the list of additions.

Yours truly,

May 22nd, 1930.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School has just informed us that large fish are getting into the intake water pipe at the School, which shows that there is apparently an opening in the pipe or that the screen is not right.

We have communicated with the Dominion Water Power Branch at Winnipeg who will send an Engineer down to inspect this.

This really should not be necessary as this pipe was repaired only recently.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Re Completion of Implement Shed, Pigery, and Root House.

In cold weather setting in last fall I was unable to complete the above buildings. I estimate it will take approximately $200 for labor and $300 for material.

I would appreciate receipt of authority to complete same and also an accountable cheque to cover labor ($200).

I state Capt. Edwards approves of the same and asked me to write you direct and to state he was only at the office for a few minutes and had to leave on Treaty.

Thanking you in anticipation of the above favor,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, June 16, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the completion of an implement shed, pigery and root house at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately the sum of $500 in the carrying out of this work. You may arrange for the purchase of the lumber and other material required to complete the above buildings, and for the labour in carrying out the work. You should keep proper time sheets, in duplicate, of the labour employed. These should be signed by the individual labourers and certified by yourself. An accountable cheque for $200 to pay for the labour will be sent you under separate cover. You should obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the lumber and other material, and these should be certified by yourself or Mr. Agent Edwards, and forwarded to the Department for payment. You will be good enough to see that all costs in the completion of these buildings are kept as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

E. W. Byers, Esq.,
Principal, Cecilia Jeffrey Res. School,
Kemora, Ont.

Kenora, Ont. June 13th, 1936.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re cleaning the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

In the absence of Capt. Frank Edwards I am forwarding you a tender for the painting of the basement walls, the first floor and the Residence.

The walls are finished with plaster and it is impossible to wash them and keep them clean. The plaster is badly broken in both stairways and should be replaced. The Burlap is falling away from the plaster and requires sizing and retaping.

The tender covers all this work and is very necessary. I believe Mr. Orr was in favor of some cleaning being done this year. I would like the work commenced as soon as school closes. I hope the Dept. will see its way clear to authorize the above work being done.

Thanking you in anticipation of the above favor,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, June 20, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a tender for the painting of the basement floor and walls in the kitchen, laundry, dining-room, etc., and at the Principal's residence at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to say that the Department has no funds available to have this work carried out this year.

Regarding the broken plaster in both stairways and the siding and repasting of the burlap, I have to say that we may arrange to have these repairs carried out, keeping all cost as low as possible. When the work is completed, you should forward, through the office of the local Indian Agent, accounts, in duplicate, which should be certified by him covering the cost.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]
A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Kawartha, Ont.
Sir:

Under date of September 23rd, 1929, you forwarded voucher No. 4701 for $84.28 in favour of the Keewatin Lumber Company, Ltd., Kenora, Ont. for lumber for the Cecelia Jeffrey School. Payment of this account was made by Departmental cheque No. 2067 for $84.28 on the 28th of September, 1929. The Auditor General has called attention to the fact that an over-payment of $5.22 has been made this firm. Under date of September 4th, 1929, there is a charge - 1 piece - 4 x 4 - 10 - $49 - total of 13 ft. @ $4.50 per 100 - $5.79. This should only be $5. Therefore, kindly obtain a refund of $5.22 from the Keewatin Lumber Co., and forwarded it to the Department under cover of a letter.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,

OFFICE OF INDIAN AGENT
Kenora Ontario.
July 11th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Confirming our wire of this morning, the New Barn of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School burned down this morning at 6 A.M. The fire was first noticed when the cattle were being taken in for milking; but they were immediately released and all saved.

The Principal informs us that the fire started in the loft, and as soon as the cattle were out, part of the roof fell in. They have lost about two carloads of Hay, a quantity of sheaves of Oats, and a large amount of other feed.

It is possible that some hoboes were sleeping in the barn or it may have started from another source but there is no evidence as to the cause.

The principal does not think it started from spontaneous combustion, as the hay had been in the loft since last September.

There is practically nothing left of the barn but the foundation, although the water supply and the fire fighting apparatus was all that could be desired, and the Town of Kenora Fire Brigade did good work and thanks to their efforts, no other outbuildings were destroyed.

We discussed the matter of rebuilding with the Principal, this morning, and it is suggested that the barn be rebuilt on a cost plus basis, and would recommend that the work be allotted to one of the following local firms who are well fitted, and have the equipment for this work:

Lindstrom & Milson, Kelly & Kimberley, and Bergman & Nelson, but would not suggest that the work be given to Mr. Gordon Hudson, but this can be referred to our Architect Mr. Orr for his consideration.
Dear Sir,

Replying to Mr. Mackenzie's letter of the 11th inst., re loss of Barn by fire at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The old barn is not yet demolished although not in very good shape, but could be used temporarily for the 15 Milk Cows. A lot of the Stanchions have been taken out and the Barn itself is very inconvenient owing to the distance from the School and the lack of water, in the barn.

We will try and get Mr. Paget to visit this when he is here.

In connection with the new barn, the Foundation is in fairly good shape except in one corner where it is badly cracked, a few of the stanchions can be used in rebuilding but the most of them are warped.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Re laying of Asphalt surfaces on basement floors

I was under the impression that this job was to be graded in such a way so as to allow any water to flow to the existing drains.

The foreman on the job informs me that his instructions are to grade only the washrooms, kitchen and laundry.

He is not putting on any finish coat but leaving off the rough surface which leaves it very difficult for cleaning.

Principal.
Cecilia Jeffrey School  
Kenora, Ont. July 14th, 1930.

Capt. Frank Edwards,  
Indian Agent  
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

It is with deep regret that I must report to you the loss of our new barn through fire.

The cause is unknown but I feel certain that either some one was sleeping there for the night or it was set. There are so many men loafing around here all the time. Some wasting work, the majority of them loafers that it is not safe to have these buildings without a night watchman.

The fire was first noticed about five O'clock A.M., just as our men were going out to work. The alarm was sounded and we soon had a stream of water on it. It was impossible to save the barn and we spent all our force in saving the other buildings. This we succeeded in doing.

We lost all our feed—about two carloads of hay and all our oat sheaves and some mill feed—about $500 worth.

The foundation is not damaged to any great extent. The South-East corner will have to be repaired. The fittings are badly warped from the heat and only a part will be of any use.

There are a great many men looking for jobs at the present time and it would be a suitable time to clear away the debris.

The old barn affords a temporary shelter for milking but it is very inconvenient place being so far from the school and it is not a very sanitary shelter for a tested herd.

I hope arrangements can soon be made to erect another building.

I remain,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
We are enclosing a letter from the Principal re the fire at the school for your information, also letter re asphalt surface.

The Principal does not seem to be pleased with the job, but in our opinion, the work is as well done as at McIntosh School, with the exception of a few minor details, which the foreman has promised to remedy.

The only question we think comes up is as to who is responsible for the cutting of the doors down to fit now that the floor is laid.

The foreman says he has no instructions to do this work, so we are asking Mr. Byers to get the work done and if the contractor is liable this can be charged against him when settling his account.

We shall be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Dear Sir,

Re re-building the Barn.

I hope the Department will be able to commence building without much delay as we are seriously handicapped for a place to store our hay and also for handling our stock. Our hay is all cut and we have no place to store it. The flies are very bad and annoying our stock so much that they are failing fast. It is very important.

I would like to suggest that if the materials were bought and the work done by day labor a considerable saving could be effected.

I hope the Department will see its way clear to commence building at once.

Thanking you in anticipation of your attention to the above,

I remain,

Sir,
