September, 11th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

We have instructed Mr. J. Brown, Plumber, of Kenora, to install the Grease Trap at the Cecilia Jeffrey School as per your letter of April 24th, 1930 on the recommendation of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

The Plumber is a little doubtful as to whether this will eliminate the trouble or not, but failing to do so, he suggests a tile pipe be laid from the Sump to a distance of roughly 500 feet.

This would be an expensive proposition, but if the Grease Traps fails to clear up the trouble, this could be done next Spring. Mr. Brown estimates the cost of this, at roughly $500.00.

Mr. D.B. Gow, District Chief Engineer for the Dominion Water Power Branch, says in a letter to this Office dated August 30th, that he believes the present Sump will be sufficiently large once an efficient Grease Trap has been installed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
September 12, 1930.

Sir:

Please refer to Mr. Atwood's letter of December 6, 1929, with enclosed letter to Mr. Orr and a copy of a memorandum prepared by our Mr. W. T. Hose covering repairs made to the water intake of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School near Kenora.

In May 1930 I was notified from Kenora that trouble was again being experienced with the water intake; in fact parts of large fish were being taken from the intake valves and out of the pumps. I investigated the circumstances and had a diver make a detailed examination. He reported that the pipe line was broken at the third joint from the screen end of the line, and that the third length of pipe was also useless because the joint had broken in such a way as to render it impossible to attach a length of pipe to it. The diver fastened a screen over the end of the broken pipe so that water supply could be secured until such time as permanent measures could be taken to effect repairs. I am now in receipt of a communication from Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, stating that the water is somewhat muddy, and requesting that the repair work be proceeded with.

Experience has shown that owing to the soft nature of the bottom of the lake, it is practically impossible to carry a pipe line out into deep water and rest this pipe line on saddles without the pipe line breaking at the joint, due to settling. I doubt whether flexible or ball joints would not also eventually fail. The existing pipe line from the Pump House to the broken pipe length is giving no trouble at present, but it is possible that trouble may be experienced with the joints of this pipe at a later period. For the present, therefore, I would recommend that only such repairs be made as will insure a satisfactory water supply until such time as it can definitely be ascertained whether or not trouble will develop in the pipe line extending from the Pump House down to the water.

I would recommend that a twenty foot length of five inch smooth bore suction hose be fastened on the pipe at the broken joint, and that this hose be extended out into good water and rest on two small rock-filled cribs, and that the end of the hose be fitted with a good screen. This suction hose is flexible and will serve adequately for years, and can be readily attached to the pipe line. I estimate the cost
of these repairs as follows:

Hose; $66.00
Attachments; 12.00
Services of Diver; 40.00
Gribuing; 40.00
Labor; 50.00
Freight and Cartage; 7.00
Incidentals; 10.00

Total; $225.00

I am of the opinion that these repairs will insure an adequate water supply during the coming winter and several years to come, providing no further trouble is experienced with that portion of the pipe line extending from the Pump House down to where the hose is to be attached. I would urge that authority be secured to have this work proceeded with at a very early date, inasmuch as it will require at least three weeks to have this hose made up for us.

Your obedient servant,

D. [Signature]
Acting District Chief Engineer.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Dept. of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Form No. 101
I regret to inform you that, recently, two barns have been destroyed by fire at Indian residential schools in western Ontario - one at the Indian Residential School at Fort Frances and the other at the Cecilia Jeffrey Institution, near Kenora. These losses are incidental to the work and the buildings must be replaced as soon as possible. I have hesitated to ask for authority to rebuild this fall, because of the condition of the appropriation for Indian Education. However, the postponement of the large new main building at the Shingwauk Home School, South Bay Lake, relieves the situation somewhat. Regarding the condition of the Vote, I may say I have informed the Minister of Finance that we should have a supplementary appropriation for Indian Education of $45,000.00 if our obligations of this year are to be met promptly. At the first opportunity, I wish to have a full and frank discussion with you in this connection.

The two barns must really be replaced without delay, or there will be serious consequences, and I should be grateful if you would let me have the name of a competent carpenter-foreman at Fort Frances and one at Kenora to whom the reconstruction could be entrusted. I believe it advisable to have the work done on a day labour basis, the Indian Agent to purchase the materials.

I should also like to have the names of lumber, cement and hardware dealers at Kenora and Fort Frances, so that the materials can be purchased without delay. Plans for these barns will be forwarded from the Department.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Form No. 101
Oct. 2, 1930.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott,

With reference to the attached letter regarding the heating system at the Cecilia Jeffrey School at Kenora, I beg to say that this building is heated by a low pressure system of steam heating. The condensation is returned to the boilers by gravity and is similar to the systems installed in many of our schools which are giving good satisfaction. There is no doubt that a saving in the cost of fuel could be effected if blowers were installed as has been suggested. This arrangement would be possible at Kenora as the building is furnished with electric power from the town.

The installing of a pump on the return lines to the boiler would speed up the circulation and make the heating system more efficient. This pump would be operated by a small motor and its installation would be practical on account of electric power being available.

ARCHITECT.
October 2, 1930.

Memorandum,-

Mr. Buckard.

With reference to letter from Mr. F. J. McManus, Kenora, to the Minister, which I return herewith, I beg to inclose a memorandum from our Architect, regarding the heating system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian school, I would be in favour of putting in blowers, but it seems to me that the heating system would be satisfactory if it were efficiently managed.
Ottawa, October 3rd, 1920.

Dear Mr. McManus,

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to the heating system in the Cecilia Jeffrey school. I regret that I cannot, at the present time, give favorable consideration to the installation of the blowers and the pump. The heating system installed in the Cecilia Jeffrey school is similar in every respect to those installed in other schools, which, with proper attention, are giving perfect satisfaction. It is possible, owing to the location of the building, that the raising of the chimney will increase the efficiency of the boilers and I am giving instructions to have this done.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

P. J. McManus, Esq.,
Kenora, Ont.
There are two matters in connection with the above school which I wish to bring to your worthy attention.

1. The furnaces in the school are not heating properly. Experienced have tried stoking them without results. About 3 days out of 4 the class-rooms are cold likewise the sewing-room. The residence is so uncomfortable in cold weather that we stay in the school. Four radiators burst from freezing which would be almost impossible if the condensed steam were returning as it should. We are using Pocahontas lump coal and burning a carload each month. This is too much fuel for the size of building. I draw the winter under these conditions.

I am not an experienced steam man but I feel certain that three things are necessary to be done:

1. Higher chimney
2. Pump to draw back the condensed steam
3. A blower

I do not wish the Dept. to accept my recommendations as I would like the report to come from an expert and one who is independent.

2. The water intake pipe has been broken off and only a temporary screen tied over the opening. This is a somewhat serious situation both as regards water supply and for a supply in case of fire. This work requires the services of a Diver and he told me he would not have anything to do with it if it were left until freeze-up. It is getting quite cold here now.

I shall appreciate very much if the above receives your attention,

I remain,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Oct. 8, 1930.

Sir,

In order to increase the draft in the heating boiler at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I would ask you to kindly arrange to have the chimney increased in height. Enough should be added to it so that it will be clear of all roofs and the bush behind the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A.F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kemora, Ont.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In connection with the building of the new barn at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I think we shall build this cheaper than it was done by the Wyndels Construction Company under contract. The Principal wishes us to build a small cement pit for the water from the manure gutter at the stable to prevent its wastage so that it can be used on the land. This should not cost more than $100. He also wishes the water pipes run from the stable to the henery and pigery. This would cost in the neighborhood of $150.

The Principal also wishes to have hay slings and carrier installed in the barn as these were also destroyed by fire - at an approximate cost not to exceed $225. I have authorized this and trust it meets with your approval.

I shall be glad to receive authority for the above as I consider the amount will be more than saved as the work is being done by ourselves on a day basis. Materials are being purchased from the firms suggested by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 15th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, in connection with the building of the new barn at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In reply I have to say that the Department approves of the building of a small cement pit for the water from the manure gutter at the stable in order to prevent its wastage so that it can be used on the land. It is noted that you estimate the cost of this work will not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Approval is also granted to have hay slings and carrier installed in the barn, the approximate cost of which should not exceed your estimate of two hundred and twenty-five dollars ($225.00).

The Department does not consider it necessary to have water pipes installed from the stable to the henery and piggery. We are, therefore, not prepared to authorize the expenditure required for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Oct. 20, 1930.

Sir,

With reference to the complaints regarding the heating system at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I would ask you to kindly arrange to have Mr. W. Oates or James Brown of Emora make a thorough examination of the system to see if they can locate the trouble in the circulation. You may also arrange with the above mentioned men to make whatever immediate repairs you consider necessary to the intake of the water supply system.

Your obedient servant,

A. Y. MacKenzie,

October 21st, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Replying to Mr. A. F. MacKenzie's telegram of 18th inst., we have instructed Kelly and Kimberley to build the Pump House and do the necessary work on the crib over the Intake at the Kenora R.C. School.

There will be charge for Plumbing work on the job, and we have made arrangements with the Campbell Heating Co. that if we built the Pumphouse, they would move the Pump and do any of the necessary work at their own expense.

We may mention that J. Brown is being employed at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and in future any plumbing we may have, will be given either to him or Mr. Oman, as instructed in your wire.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Dear Sir,

We forwarded to you yesterday, Pay Sheets for erecting barn at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

We are now informed that the wages paid are below the amount specified for Government work, and are endeavouring to obtain a copy of the correct scale of wages from Messrs. Kelly & Kimberley who are building the Post Office at Keewatin.

Would you kindly send us several copies of the schedule of wages as we understand that same has to be posted up on any work being done for the Government.

We also understand that the Government schedule is quite a bit more than that usually paid in this district, and will be glad to know if we will pay on the schedule rates.

Do Indians come under this schedule as we are not paying so high for clearing land at the R.C. School here, and the amount will go farther amongst the Indians and we will get more work done for the amount expended, if it is in order to pay them at the lower rate. We may say that the Indians are well satisfied at the rate paid.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter 129-3-5 of 20th Octr. 1930, we will write you as soon as we get an estimate of the Heating system of the Cecilia Jeffrey School. Mr. Oman is making a report for us at the present time.

With reference to the Water intake, we have received a letter from the Acting Chief District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch in which they consider it advisable to have the necessary work done now, in case the Pipe settles during the Winter. They recommend that a 20 foot length of 5" smooth bore suction hose be fastened on the pipe at the broken joint, and this hose be extended into good water and rested on two small rock filled cribs, with another crib midway between point of attachment of existing pipe and outer end of the hose, and that the end of the hose be fitted with a good screen.

The hose is flexible and will serve adequately for years. The cost is estimated as follows: Hose $66.00 Attachments $12.00 Diver $40.00 Crib $40.00 Labour $50.00 Freight & Car $7.50 and incidentals $10.00 or a total cost of $225.00.

We are ordering the hose and giving instructions for the work to be done, as it would be a serious thing if the water gave out during the Winter Months.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, November 7, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to the heating system and the repairs required to the intake of the water supply system at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In connection with the repairs to the water intake, Mr. MacInnes, Acting District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Board has advised you as to the action to be taken in this matter and that you have ordered the same required and have given the necessary instructions to have the work done, the total cost being approximately $225. Your action in this matter is approved. When this work is completed, you should forward certified accounts, in the usual manner, covering the cost.

It is noted that you are obtaining an estimate of the alterations required to the heating system.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Ottawa, November 7, 1930.

Sir:

In April, 1929, the Department supplied nine Thermos fire extinguishers for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. It is now necessary that new recharges be installed in these extinguishers, and I have to inform you that the Department is today placing an order with the Pyrene Manufacturing Company of Canada, Limited, Toronto, to ship, addressed to Mr. E. W. Byers, Kenora, Ont., charges prepaid, the necessary refills for these extinguishers. The above firm have been requested to make early shipment and to forward their account, in triplicate, to you. When these recharges are received, please certify the amount and forward to the Department, in duplicate, retaining one copy for file in your office. You should request the Principal to see that the new recharges are installed in the extinguishers.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Form No. 101
Dear Sir,

As requested by you, I have made an inspection of the heating system in the Indian Residential School and my findings are as follows:

1st Return lines.
The secondary return lines leading to the main wet return, are in such shape that with the present equipment it is impossible to get the condensation back to the boilers.

In many cases it will be necessary to remove the present lines, straighten up the runs, and shorten the drop, in order that the returns will have sufficient rising to cut out the traps.

2nd Radiator connections.
I find where the radiator supplies are carried up through the floors to radiators on floor above, that many of these supplies are twisted necessitating their removal and re-adjustment to cut out the traps, and thus permit an easy flow between the radiators.
II contd

3rd I find there is an air vent lacking in wet return.
Would suggest that an air vacuum vent be placed at this point.

4th In an installation such as required for a system covering such an extended area,
I find that it is advisable to equip same with a reliable condensation pump so as to insure
the return of all condensation to the boiler.

Yours truly,

H.A. McLean
Dear Sir:

1) I agree to supply P.O.B. School 1 only Isaac Economy Condensation pump, electrically driven complete ready to install, for the sum of Three Hundred Forty-five dollars eighty-five cents ($345.85).

Terms Cash 10 days following date of delivery.

2) I agree to supply and install, pumps as described above (less electrical work), to be arranged piping in woodmanlike manner, to insure proper drainage for the sum of Six Hundred and Fifty-seven dollars seventy-five cents ($657.75).

Signed,

[Signature]

J. R. W. Oliver
Captain Edwards,
Thoma City

Personal

November 11/30

Dear Sir:

It is pretty hard to give an accurate estimate on what it will cost to put this job in working shape and personal I would advise day labor.

Just as an instance of what I mean:
A gentleman called me up and said he wanted me to put in a hot water job in his residence he to supply material.
I advised him to have the work done at normal pay.
He asked for contract on installation, and gave me the job.
If he had accepted my advice he would have saved $20.00.
However the job is in now and all parties satisfied.

Am enclosing plan on pump H.O.R. School also Tender (approximate) for supply, installation (except electrical work) & fittings and re-arrangement of piping to insure drainage.

Sincerely Yours,

W.H. Willman
P.S. Have just closed a deal with Chief Williamson for about 100 cords of wood so partially the steps will be worth four on any tender outside of the ordinary trading business.

H. A. H. Murray

INDIAN OFFICE

At Kenora, Ontario.

November 7th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter 129-3-5 of 20th October, 1930, re Heating at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

We are inclosing a letter and estimate from Mr. H.A.W. Oman, Kenora who estimates the cost of Pump at $345.85 and installation (less Electrical work) at $657.75 including pump.

The Electrical work will not cost very much, but we hesitate to get this work done owing to the expense, but apparently it is the only solution.

We have had the Chimney raised and this has helped considerably, and will be glad to have your further instructions.

Kindly return letter for our Files.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Kenora, Ontario,
November 12th, 1930.

Dear Mr. [Name],

We wrote you some time ago asking what scale of wages would have to be paid for Government work, particularly in connection with the building of the new Barn at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, but have received no reply.

Would you kindly let us hear from you re this as soon as possible, as the men have already been paid at the low scale and we do not wish to have any complaints afterwards.

The cost of the Barn when completed should not be in excess of the old one, but of course we have had to do some work, raising Chimney, Concrete Tank for Manure water, and also supplied Hay and Manure carrier etc.

We should like to have authority to rebuild the Silo and figure the whole cost of this work would be in the neighbourhood of $500.00.

The old Barn cost £670.16.

We shall be glad to have your early instructions re this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

PRESBYTERIAN

KENORA, ONT.

Nov. Fifth, 193

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Re Account rendered by the Campbell Heating Co.,
for repairs to the Kelvinator here.

Dear Sir:

For your information I wish to explain that the above account was incurred through some short circuits somewhere in the wiring of the building.

We have two currents here, 110 volt and 220 volt, and through a grounding this current crossed over and burned the motor and fittings in connection with the Kelvinator.

I had an Electrician from the town Electric Power Superintendent go over the wiring to see if we could locate the trouble. They were able to rectify the trouble but were not certain as to just what was the primary cause. They supposed that part of the insulation had been partly stripped thus allowing some of the conduit pipe to come into contact with the heavy current so as to burn the building.

It is difficult to place the blame on the men who made the expedition fail; they could not definitely state who was responsible.

I am very sorry this accident has occurred and have been notified at once and will make every effort to prevent a recurrence of this unfortunate event.

I remain Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Kenora, Ontario.
November, 26th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Referring to our letter of Sept. 11th last and to yours of April 24th. The Grease Trap was installed as authorized, but this has not eliminated the trouble.

Mr. Rose, engineer for the Dominion Water Power Branch was here yesterday and suggests we ask Kelly & Kimberley to bore down through the Sump to see if it is possible to get into Gravel so as to get better seepage. If this can be found the sump can be dug deeper, but if not would have to dig a trench about four or five hundred feet and timber this which could be used as a disposal bed, or another sump dug adjoining the present one divided with bulkheads so as to make an extra grease trap, to prevent Grease, Soap etc. going into the sump.

At the present time, the sump has to be pumped out after every wash day as the water will not seep away.

On the receipt of the written report of the Dominion Water Power Branch, we will forward it on to you, but on the advice of Mr. Rose we have instructed Kelly & Kimberley to pump out the sump and make the necessary borings. This will cost in the neighbourhood of $25.00 or $30.00.

We shall be glad to have authority to carry out the advice of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Nov. 1930
November 29, 1930.

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Following his inspection of conditions of the Laundry Sump at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Mr. Rose has made certain suggestions, which, if carried out, may improve the existing unsatisfactory situation.

Mr. Rose states that the Contractor has been employed to pump out the sump and bore test holes in an endeavor to locate a gravel bed. If gravel is located, it is intended to open up the sump to obtain drainage to this gravel layer, and then test out the sump with clear water. With satisfactory drainage of clear water demonstrated it is then proposed to divide tank with a baffle to retain the grease in one part of the sump and keep the remainder more or less clear of grease and therefore more effective for drainage. The accompanying plan shows the general location and plan for the proposed baffle and also for the trough connecting the two divisions of the sump.

Personally, I am not expecting that any gravel bed will be found; in which case it will be necessary to enlarge the capacity of the sump. This is proposed to accomplish by digging a tunnel and constructing a gallery, as outlined on the accompanying plan. Planking for the sides of this gallery should be spaced with a 2" interval, between planks and the roof must be made to withstand the earth pressure from above.

These suggestions, if carried out, should give a measure of relief, but at frequent intervals, it will be necessary to remove from the sump, the accumulation of grease. I would expect that in time even this enlarged sump would prove ineffective owing to the saturation of the surrounding sand with grease and etc. This School was apparently located without any consideration being given to drainage conditions. The only natural drainage was to the source of water supply, i.e., Round Lake. The nature of the ground resisting the disposal of the laundry sump underground, a very difficult matter. However, to lead the laundry drainage by drains to obtain surface
drainage would bring the outlet down fairly close to Round Lake; in fact, so close to the source of the water supply for the school, that contamination of the water supply might occur. It is for this reason that the idea of putting in a sump to get rid of the drainage from the laundry was first conceived, and experience has shown that the nature of the land or soil, is such as to allow for rapid drainage. I am hopeful, however, that with this enlarged sump, and with frequent clearing out of the grease from the first part of the sump, will give a more satisfactory service, than has hitherto been obtained.

Yours truly,

D. D. [Signature]
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Enclosure.
Kemora, Ontario,
December 1st, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Referring to our letter of 26th ult., re Laundry Sump at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, we inclose report and blue print received from the Dominion Water Power Bureau.

Kelly & Kimberley have bored down into Gravel and also made a few holes through the Sheeting of the Sump, and two lots of Laundry water have gone into the sump and have seeped away. It may therefore be possible to forego any further work at the present time, but should it block up again, we shall be glad to have authority to carry out the recommendations of the Dominion Water Power Bureau.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

December 9th, 1950.

Dear Sir,

Re Silo for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. We find that this will cost about $200 more erected than originally estimated and has been ordered from the Gilson Manufacturing Co. at Guelph, Ontario.

It will be 14' x 26' complete with Springs and Anchors but without roof, Yellow leaf Pine.

This seems to be the best we can get at a reasonable price, and as it is desirable to put a roof on, that is the reason it will be a little more expensive than expected.

Trusting that this will be in order,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School

KENORA, ONT. Dec. 9th. 193—

Captain Fra. Smith,
Indian Agent,
Kenora,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report that in the class-rooms there is one blackboard in each class-room which has not been put down, lately on account of our classes not being graded just as wished, and we did not wish to have the trouble of putting them up again.

I am sure that the Indians will be pleased to see it done.

Hoping you can have this work authorized,

Yours, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School
PRESBYTERIAN

MENORA, ONT. Dec. 17th, 193

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re: pump for the school. I want to state for your information that the pump for the Beatty Brothers was here today. It will be for man, and he made checks fill the fixtures in the bath.

For the school, we have purchased a new pump. We have also purchased a new water tank. There are a couple of minor issues that need attention.

I am enclosing a list of the items purchased.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Kenora, Ontario,
December 11th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find two letters we have received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

One, in which he wishes to purchase a "Jumbo" pump at a price of $19.25 from the Williams Hardware Co., for pumping the manure water from the barn, on to the land; the other letter requesting authority to put up blackboards in each Class Room and also authority to secure the seats in the class house to be 1' x 4" so that they can be moved when scrubbing and cleaning the rooms, also to place deflectors for window ventilation, in the small class room as requested by the School Inspector, at an approximate cost of $50.00.

We hesitate to recommend the above requests of the Principal's on account of the large amount expended and still being expended on this School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Form No. 101
November 8th, 1930.

Mr. E.W. Byers,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We attach an invoice to cover cost of an electric meter which, while recording the consumption of power of your pumping equipment and located in your Pump-house, was damaged beyond repair owing to a leakage of chlorine gas in the pumphouse, and we would appreciate it if you would be so good as to have this account put in line for payment.

I would draw your attention to Clause number Two of the General Conditions which apply in this case, and which reads as follows:-

"(b) "All meters, telephones and other appliances in any premises shall be in the care of and at the risk of the consumer, and if destroyed or damaged by any cause, whatever, other than ordinary wear and tear, the consumer shall pay the Corporation the value of such meter or meters or other appliances, or the cost of replacing or repairing same."

Might we also suggest that you arrange to have connection provided on the outside of the buildings, for the meter now recording the load, so that the danger of a recurrence might as far as possible, be eliminated.

Very truly yours,

(Signed) F.J. Hooper

CLERK
Kanora, Ontario,
December 8th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find Voucher #5443 for $54.25 in favour of the Town of Kanora, for new meter installed in the pump house at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, damaged through escape of Chlorine Gas, also copy of letter from the Town to the Principal, in which we note the Town suggests that we arrange to have connection provided on the outside of the buildings for the meter now recording the load so that the danger of a recurrence might as far as possible be eliminated.

We understand this would not be an expensive item, and would be pleased to have your authority for this work.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School
PRESBYTERIAN

KENORA, ONT. Dec. 9th. 1930.

Dear Sir:

Re: Run of Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, I would like to know if it is possible to secure a position from the Department of Indian Affairs in the Residence.

There seems to be an inefficient system that the only thing that can be done is when there is no vacancy. If there is a vacancy the Resident in the Residence will have to be transferred elsewhere, but I am not sure what the situation is now.

If you could give me any information regarding this matter, I would appreciate it very much.

I am,

Sir,

Yr obedient Servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kenora, Ontario,
December 10th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School re Heating of School and Residence.

We sent an estimate in a short time ago from Mr. Oran, but have heard nothing further.

It appears to us to be better to fix the return pipes, and install a pump for the return condensed steam than to put an oil burner in the residence.

Please let us hear from you re this.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, December 24, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing two communications from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department has no funds at present to purchase a pump, blackboards, and secure the seats in one of the classrooms in order that they can be easily moved while cleaning the room.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Renora, Ont.

The junior classroom is too small for the number of pupils now making use of it. There are 29 pupils in the room approximately 16' x 20'. It is absolutely necessary under such conditions that the ventilation provide constant change of air. Four Celloglass shields should be provided for the windows in this room.

The following improvements have been suggested:

a. The desks should be fastened to slats in groups of three or four to prove the proper alignment when in use, and also to provide freedom of movement for purpose of scrubbing floors.
Ottawa, January 15, 1931.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School in December, last, drew attention to the overcrowding in the junior classroom. He stated that the room is too small for the number of pupils now making use of it, and that it is absolutely necessary, under such conditions, that the ventilation provide a constant change of air. He recommends that four Celloglass or ordinary glass shields about nine inches high be provided, so that the windows could be opened about an inch or two at the bottom all the time without causing a direct draft on the pupils. You should take this matter up with the Principal and ascertain if it would not be possible to re-arrange the classes with a view to a decrease in the number of pupils using the classroom at one time.

The Inspector also recommends that the desks in the junior classroom be fastened to slats in groups of three or four to provide proper alignment when in use, and also to provide freedom of movement for purpose of scrubbing floors.

In connection with the above recommendations of the Inspector, I have to refer to your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal regarding the installing of deflectors for ventilation and fastening the seats to slats. It is stated that at that time the estimate of the cost of having the above work done was only stated to be $50. It is considered, however, that if the materials were provided the staff of the school should be able to build deflectors for the windows and fasten the seats to slats. The Department will approve of you arranging to supply the materials required, and, if the school authorities are unable to do all the work, you may arrange for any labour required.

After the above work has been completed, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the material supplied and for any outside labour, if any, in doing the work.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora,
Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sirs:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of February 20th stating that you have not yet received payment of your invoice of October 11, 1930 for the amount of $49.04, for material supplied to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora.

The material listed in your invoice of October 11th was apparently shipped on instructions received from the Principal of the School, and according to his explanation these parts were required to replace articles damaged by escaping chlorine gas from a faulty cylinder supplied by you, and as the arrangements were that all such damaged material was to be replaced free of charge, the point was raised whether the Government was responsible for the payment of this invoice.

However, after talking over the matter with your local representative in Winnipeg, Mr. Lindsten, and noting the date of the order, I have written to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa recommending that the invoice be paid.

However, in view of the statement of the Principal of the School, Mr. Byers, who gave the order that these fixtures were to replace ones that were damaged by the leakage of gas from a faulty cylinder, I cannot say what action the Department of Indian Affairs will take as to the payment of this invoice.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Acting District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 14825 - M, of the 5th instant, enclosing copy of letter from Wallace and Tiernan and invoice for fixtures delivered to the Cecilia Jeffrey School for the Chlorinator System.

The Principal informs us that Wallace and Tiernan's Representative informed him that these parts were required, as spoilt through leakage of gas, so Mr. Byers said he had better supply them.

We return the accounts with a certificate on them how the damage was caused, and the only question therefore, is as to who is responsible for the payment, and in this connection we would refer you to your letter to Mr. Orr of March 10th, 1930.

February 21, 1931.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith an account of Messrs. Wallace and Tiernan Limited, in triplicate, covering fixtures supplied for the Chlorinating System at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, Ontario.

I am also enclosing copy of a letter from Messrs. Wallace and Tiernan, Toronto, addressed to this office, and also copies of correspondence between this office and Captain Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora, Ontario.

These goods were shipped on October 3rd by Wallace and Tiernan on instructions from Mr. Byers. The Chlorinating Equipment at this school had been overhauled in April by Wallace and Tiernan's engineers, and I understand was put in a satisfactory working condition and damaged parts replaced. Mr. Lindsten, the representative of Wallace and Tiernan in Winnipeg, informs me that the equipment, covered in the enclosed invoice, were replacements due to breakages and insomuch as the order was given some five months after the plant had been put in a satisfactory condition, I am of the opinion that this account should be paid.

I notice that Mr. Byers has written on the invoices that the "above equipment was supplied to replace damaged parts, damaged by chlorine escaping from a defective gas cylinder".

It is quite probable that some of these replaced parts were necessary because of damage caused early in 1930, but the proper time to have it replaced was in April when overhauling was carried out.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Encls. Acting District Chief Engineer.

A. E. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
